I think, Mr Henkel, that the only reasonable way to solve this problem – and you didn’t talk about it unfortunately – is through cross-party cooperation in British politics, as soon as possible, through a compromise, a common view, between Labour and the Conservatives. How you do you go about solving an existential problem like Brexit if it is used by both parties to kill each other? For them, Brexit is a bullet in a weapon and not an existential problem of a country and of a whole continent, and that’s a shame. (Applause) So our appeal, and yours, in this plenary has to be not to attack one or other of our colleagues but to say this to the British political class: start to make an agreement between the two big parties and start to have an opinion that we can support here in this Parliament, and that opinion will be for a close relationship between the UK and the EU. That is the way forward. What is needed is that, in British politics, Queen and country should be put first, instead of the party politics that are governing the UK and the House of Commons for the moment. And that brings me to the next question, of an extension. I don’t want a long extension and I say that to you very openly. Why go beyond the European elections? If we do so, the European elections will be hijacked by the Brexiteers and by the whole Brexit issue. We will talk only about that, and not about the real problems and about the real reforms that we need in the European Union. The other thing we will do is to give a new mandate to Mr Farage: that’s the only thing that we going to do. (Noise) That’s exactly what he wants, and why does he want it? For two reasons. First of all, he can continue to have a salary that he can transfer to his offshore company. (Murmurs) And, secondly, he can continue to do his dirty work in the European Union: that is to try to destroy the European Union from within. That is the real purpose. And that is absolutely what we don’t need. What we do need now is certainty from the House of Commons, from a majority in the House of Commons, as Mr Henkel has also asked for. That is what we need. I am against every extension, whether of a day, a week or even 24 hours, if it is not based on a clear opinion of the House of Commons on something so that we know they want. Is that less ambitious than the deal? Okay, it is less ambitious than the deal, that’s your opinion. If it is a customs union, it is a customs union. If it is the deal, it is the deal. If it is a Norway-plus, it’s a Norway-plus. But, please, make up your mind in London because this uncertainty cannot continue, not for us, not for Britain, and certainly not for our citizens. (Applause)

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, once again the President of the European Council has decided to snub our Assembly. Is this really surprising given the particularly meagre record of heads of state or government, those whom Donald Tusk likes to appoint leaders? Since 2015, not a Council meeting has gone by without discussing the issue of asylum and migration, which Donald Tusk has sought to prioritise. After more than three years, we could have legitimately expected the Council to provide a concerted response to this challenge. What nenni! The Commission has just concluded that it will not conclude anything. Heads of state or government show their inability or rather their lack of willingness to get along. As a reminder, it took Parliament half as long to find a majority of more than two-thirds around a common approach combining solidarity and responsibility. We are still waiting for them, the leaders. Where is the leadership, when the scientific world gives us twelve years, no more, to act decisively to save the climate and little more to save biodiversity? Again, leaders are simply deaf, blind and dumb in the face of the anger of Europe's youth. We are still waiting for the first meeting of the Council, which will put this at the heart of its discussions. Where is the leadership, when more and more of our fellow citizens stand up to reject a society where wealth is concentrated in an ever smaller number of hands? These inequalities are the result of fiscal and social competition between Member States, the flexibilisation of the labour market, the digital revolution and a savage globalisation. We are still waiting for this issue to be put on the agenda of the leaders. They are not even at the point of awareness yet. Where is the leadership, when within the European Council a growing number of leaders - always them - deliberately choose to undermine the foundations of our democracy: separation of powers, independence of the press and justice, respect for privacy, respect for the principles of necessity and proportionality in restrictions on civil or individual freedoms or in the use of violence to suppress demonstrations? While this Parliament denounces these serious abuses and has, for example, called on the Council to open proceedings against the Hungarian government, we expect something more, Madam, than a polite response. In any case of Brexit - and that this subject ceases to be a distraction - ladies and gentlemen, waiting is no longer an option. We cannot perpetually expect the good will of those who present themselves as leaders but who are in fact followers in the best hypothesis. The real leadership today, ladies and gentlemen, is to put the preservation of our environment, social and economic justice and the defence of democracy and our freedoms at the heart of political action and European construction. That is our ambition.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am sure you are all familiar with the film 'And every day the marmot salutes'. I remember that when I think of the forthcoming Council summit, which in turn will be overshadowed by the debate on the consequences of Brexit and the way in which the negotiations between the EU and the UK are moving forward or are being blocked.  Important issues are on the agenda: the EU itself has been one of the initiators and main actors in the creation of the Paris climate deal. The EU is responsible for ensuring that there is a UN agreement on sustainable development. These should be the issues we are dealing with, because then, as the EU, we would be able to make real progress, influence things and ultimately influence people globally, both within the EU and in terms of what is happening around us. That would be our responsibility as the European Union.  Instead, we are faced with the fact that, for the second time, the withdrawal agreement has failed in the House of Commons. Theresa May's British government's strategy has gone against the wall. We do not have a political majority in favour of an orderly exit from the EU. That is the conclusion. We do not have a majority in favour of an orderly exit from the EU. The consequences are primarily for the people of the United Kingdom, the EU, the UK citizens in the EU, the EU citizens in the UK and the Irish citizens in both the Republic of Ireland and the North of Ireland, because most of them do not have the chance to move their companies' headquarters from London to Belfast in the short term – obviously because they expect Belfast to somehow remain in the EU. Most also do not have the chance to simply move their assets or investment opportunities elsewhere. And most do not have the chance to quickly ensure, within their own family, that family members are granted citizenship of an EU Member State – that is not possible for most people. Most suffer from this, because of their access to health care, because of the impact on education, because of the social impact, because of the impact that the whole thing will have on people, especially in economic and structural terms, on the development of their regions.  We, as the EU, should above all feel obliged to them, the citizens. We must make offers not to the government in London, not to the House of Commons in London, but to the citizens. That is our obligation, and that is why we should also stand up for it here, and I believe that there are two consequences that we need to talk about: if we are preparing for 29 March, for the unorderly exit, namely this mad Friday, which we will obviously get, then it means that we must ensure that citizens' rights are seerated. In other words, we must do something to ensure that the rights of citizens in the UK and those in the EU are not jeopardised. We have a duty here. We have taken responsibility and made commitments here, and now we have to deliver on them. It is high time that we made this clear.  And we must continue to signal firm support for the Republic of Ireland and make it clear that we are opposed to a hard border and any change to the Good Friday Agreement in all its parts, and that the rights and security of the people in this part of Europe must not be jeopardised.  There is, however, a very simple solution to the backstop problem: no borders on the island of Ireland, no controls, no trees. Irish unity would be the simplest solution. Then the EU would no longer have a problem, the Irish would no longer have a problem, and the Brexiteers would have none at all. That would be a solution. The British Government has today begun to declare that there are no controls between the Republic of Ireland and the north of Ireland. Perhaps it is now relying on this solution itself. Perhaps a smaller Britain is more important to her than its own interests, which are represented by some parties, and I think we should just take them at their word.

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I’m very much hoping after nearly 20 years that this is my penultimate speech in this Parliament, and that I won’t be coming back here again in July. I’m sure many of you here would share that sentiment. Mr Barnier, I told you that treaty wouldn’t go through the House of Commons, you didn’t believe me, it’s been rejected and I think you pushed your luck too far. You ask for too much and this morning you find yourself short of GBP 39 billion, so I’m sure you’re feeling a bit sore about that, but don’t worry, help is at hand – because the House of Commons today will do I’m sure their utmost to betray the Brexit vote. They’re even going to vote against what Article 50 said, which is of course that we leave on 29 March with or without a deal. I have to say I think the gap now between our political class in the UK and public opinion is a gaping chasm because be in no doubt, public opinion is hardening. There is a greater sense of unity in the country than I’ve seen for some years. We simply want to leave. That applies to many who voted remain as well – because they respect the very principle of democracy. We’ve had enough. We’ve seen the snarling anger towards our country of Mr Verhofstadt, the bureaucratic intransigence of Mr Barnier, the constant stream of insults that come from Mr Tusk, and we’re of one mind: we don’t want to be governed by you. We want to govern ourselves. I’m sure the next instalment of this will be the British Prime Minister, next Thursday, going to the European summit in Brussels and another humiliating display where she begs for an extension to Article 50. Well, I’ve got a solution to all of this. When I heard you, Mr Barnier, say this morning that if this Withdrawal Agreement gets passed and the next phase of negotiations could last for up to four years, I thought, ‘enough’. We don’t want to waste four more years of our lives – four more years of agony. You don’t want to waste another four years. You’ve got your plan – you want a ‘United States of Europe’, you want your army, you want everyone to join the euro, you want to get rid of the nation states – we’re just a damned nuisance. Add to that, as Mr Verhofstadt said, the European elections. You don’t want me coming back here, or hordes of eurosceptics coming back here, so there is a simple solution and that is that the British request to extend is vetoed at that European summit and we leave on 29 March. Most of the preparations have been done. Even if there are a few short-term bumps in the road, we leave and both you and we can get on with the rest of our lives. That is the only neat solution ahead of us. (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Mr President, now, Mrs May may be totally incompetent, but she is following a plan. Right from the start, the plan was to delay Brexit, impede Brexit and, finally, to overturn Brexit. The whole leaving process has been built on false arguments. The principal one being that we cannot leave without the mythical good deal. Now, the deal is appallingly bad and it has been rejected by the Commons – not because it was bad, but because it wasn’t bad enough for them. Later today, Parliament will reject leaving on the so-called no deal option. On Thursday, it is likely to vote in favour of an extension of Article 50, but what for? Mr Juncker has already told Her Majesty’s Government – like naughty schoolchildren – that there will be no third chance to renegotiate. In the UK, we have a government and a parliament that does not want to leave the European Union and it intends to betray the democratic decision of the referendum. Now, Vice-President Timmermans has expressed his exasperation with the UK in rejecting the EU’s deal. Mr Timmermans said that only the UK Parliament can give direction in this matter. But this is not so. The Council and Commission can give direction. When the Commons asks for an extension to Article 50 then you must reject it. Article 50 says that if no agreement is reached by 29 March then the Treaties automatically cease to apply. Do nothing and ensure that the UK is ejected from the European Union on 29 March. Do yourselves a favour, do us a favour, and kick us out!

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Madam President, last night MPs from all parties voted again to reject the Withdrawal Agreement. I regret that sufficient progress has not been made in this respect. The Attorney General’s advice is clear: the legal risk remains unchanged. Without evidence of Brussels bad faith, the UK would have no internationally lawful means of exiting the backstop. My party has always been clear. We want an orderly exit from the EU and a Brexit deal that works for both the United Kingdom and the European Union, and indeed for our closest neighbours in the Republic of Ireland, but that agreement must respect the constitutional and economic integrity of Northern Ireland. Can I also respond to a couple of things that have been raised from the floor. There’s been much talk of the rights of citizens and I agree that citizens should not be a bargaining chip in this negotiation. The House of Commons has already said that we should move to protect the rights of citizens in all eventualities. That is a challenge for this House to take up and to stop talking about.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: –Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. I like British tv series, but this series - Brexit - a long series - can not be liked, arouses more and more disgust. I am increasingly concerned and amazed to even observe the political chaos in the Islands, and I am giving expression to this, inter alia, because, as I said before, in this former part of communist Europe, opposition circles were looking for a model of good democracy and for my environment, where Donald Tusk was also, this model was the mature and efficient parliamentary democracy of The United Kingdom. The greater the admiration someday, the greater the disappointment today, because two weeks before the date we have party games, impossibilism in the selection of the majority in favor of a positive solution. Most of it is not a political art. I do not understand politicians who strike out non-contractual parting of scenarios while voting against the agreement – the only one on the table. So there is growing uncertainty, as a cost, on both sides of the channel – human and business, including the uncertainty of the fate of about a million of my compatriots who have found a better life in the British Isles, a better job. I do not know what is the point in possibly extending this period, because how to fill it with positive content, since it has not succeeded for two years? Unfortunately, we need to prepare for the worst-case scenario. The agenda of the nearest Council is also to combat disinformation. One with the other has a lot in common, because the British referendum was filled to the brim with disinformation – its own and imported, mainly from Russia. I believe that the next Parliament, the future Council and the future Commission have a great task of counteracting or strengthening very broadly understood cybersecurity. Data protection, anti-trolls, but also in the completely military part – countering dangerous incursion from the outside.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: – Madam President, for the second time, the UK Government has not been able to find a positive majority in the House of Commons. It has been a big mistake not to try to bring all the forces in the House together in the interests of the country. Instead, the UK Government has decided to appease the Tories’ hard Brexiteers, a strategy that backfired spectacularly last night. Mr Henkel, you are wrong. As Michel Barnier said, the EU has always been a fair, transparent and constructive partner in this negotiation. We have done all we can to guarantee an orderly withdrawal of the UK that protects citizens. We have a specific and particular responsibility to keep protecting all the European citizens in this process and to preserve the peace process in Northern Ireland.  We have also taken into account, of course, the UK Government red lines. Let me repeat this: this is the only withdrawal treaty that is possible and the only one that could command an approval in this House. So what’s next? First, we still trust the UK parliamentarians today to reject a no-deal Brexit. That would be catastrophic for the UK. Second, we need a clear direction on how, concretely, to avoid the no deal scenario. We always said that a closer EU-UK relationship based on a customs union would not only benefit our economies, but would also solve many of the concerns associated with the backstop. It is time to stop party politics and to work constructively in the interests of citizens and the country and if this is not possible, it is clear that the only alternative is to give the people the chance to change the government or to say no to Brexit.  This is the debate we need to have, not the debate on the length of the extension. This, for us is clear: the extension is a tool and all the options are on the table as long as there is a clear political reason and perspective. We will keep working constructively, openly and responsibly, including our UK citizens, who remain European citizens.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Colleagues, I am conscious that this is a difficult debate and speakers want to make their points very clearly, but I am duty-bound to try and pull the time back a little because we have lengthy votes. So please, Mr Nicholson, do not let me down. You have one-and-a-half minutes.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: – Madam President, don’t count on it! I have listened this morning with a heavy heart to what I have heard in this Chamber. I have listened to nothing positive, in fact it will all be negative. People are stuck in trenches, and nothing constructive is coming forward. Mr Timmermans said, so here we are, solutions must come from London. Do you not think, Mr Timmermans, that you and Mr Juncker have a part to play as well, that you have got to find a solution also? Ms Zimmer let the cat out of the bag: you will not annex Northern Ireland, Irish unity is not at stake here, even nationalist parties do not want a referendum on the border, they accept the Good Friday Agreement – put that all to bed. And can I say something to you, Mr Barnier? You said that the responsibility lies solely with the UK. But what I say to you, sir, is that you also have a tremendous responsibility and it is not good enough for you to simply consult with people from Northern Ireland who tell you what you want to hear. There is another voice in Northern Ireland, and you should be listening to that as well.  And I’m sorry to have to say it to you, but, with the greatest respect, your Treaty is flawed. It’s damaged and it’s not going to work. We need to find another way, and we do need an extension on Article 50. Yes, we do need an extension to find that other way, and it’s not good enough to be told that we need to have a reason for an extension. We need an extension to move forward and get a good deal: I personally and my party and the people that I represent, we want a good deal. And let me tell you, Mr Barnier, this morning the UK Government announced that all goods flowing from the Republic of Ireland to Northern Ireland will come unhindered. Can you say the same?

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you, Jim. I’m afraid you failed the test on time!

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Madam President, Prime Minister May profoundly regrets the defeat. I, like many of you, profoundly regret that the UK seems to have lost its way. Since 1973, we have had our differences with the UK, sometimes influenced by history, by different perceptions and by fake news. We must also remember that what matters is the future and we mustn’t forget – 1992: Denmark; 2001 and 2008: Ireland; 2005: France and the Netherlands, when European citizens said no to certain EU proposals. As individual countries and a Union, through listening, consultation and protocols, our citizens were able to find a way forward, to work together and, despite what Mr Farage said, I believe that can still happen with the UK. I also profoundly disagree with him when he speaks about snarling anger and bureaucratic intransigence. As always, he seeks to shift responsibility for a divided country onto the shoulders of others.  I agree with Mr Michel Barnier. We have been – and we need to remain – patient, supportive and respectful, while remaining true to our principles and I thank him and his team for their loyal and dedicated work.  Finally, I agree with Mr Gualtieri. An extension is just a tool to find a way forward and all options still need to be explored.

name: Jill EVANS
text: – Madam President, we have witnessed another crushing defeat for the UK Government in its second meaningful vote on a deal that would have been disastrous for Wales, taking us out of the single market and the customs union. It’s clear that the UK Parliament cannot come to a meaningful conclusion and so it’s time to turn back to the people. The concentration of wealth in London has got us into this mess and the concentration of power in Westminster is keeping us trapped in it now.  Democracy is the way forward. We must give people a final say on their future now that we are seeing the real facts. Things have changed. When events change, people change their minds. That is their right. Wales, my constituency, has done that: 55% now back remain, a 14% increase on 2016. We need an extension of Article 50 and we need that for a people’s vote.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, people in the north of Ireland have had enough of this shambolic mess. Our clear will to remain in the EU has been ignored. The utter chaos in Westminster – not just last night, but throughout the entire Brexit process – has left communities in despair. This farce is Tory designed, but it is being delivered to the people of the north of Ireland, via partition, by the DUP. We consider the withdrawal agreement and its backstop to be the ‘least worst’ option that the people can accept. That has been totally rejected – again by the reckless political establishment in Britain. The European Union has committed to supporting the Good Friday Agreement, in all of its parts. That includes the legitimate, democratic pathway to Irish unity and, despite what Jim Nicholson said, it is a provision of the Good Friday Agreement. The British Prime Minister herself believes that Brexit is increasing support for Irish unity. The European Council said, in April 2017, that if Ireland is reunited then the whole island will remain a part of the EU. I remind the Council and the Commission of that. The EU has said that we need to prepare for a no-deal, for a crash. Who in their right mind would sit on a train that is going over a cliff or being dangerously delayed or derailed? So the people want to get off that train, and the only way off it is Irish unity. My appeal to the Council and the Commission is that you advocate the holding of a referendum on Irish unity. It is legitimate, it is democratic, it is in the Good Friday Agreement. If you are going to uphold it in all of its parts, then uphold that part too. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the time has come to ask ourselves what the deep-seated reasons for Brexit are, because even today we have heard statements in this House, but we have also heard statements by Macron, Juncker, the whole mainstream, who blamed Brexit on information that would have diverted and confused the will of the people of the United Kingdom.  But the people of the United Kingdom have always spoken very consciously when they decided not to join the single currency, when they did not accede to the Schengen Treaty, to the fiscal compact. The people of the United Kingdom have always reacted consciously against the austerity policies and budgetary constraints of a Franco-German-led European policy.  That is what we should think about: the responsibilities of a European policy which is a real colonisation on the part of France and Germany. If we continue in this direction, in the direction of austerity, then Brexit risks being just a mere precedent for the dissolution of a definitive Europe.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: – Madam President, I apologise to the British people for the lies told by our politicians. Mr Tajani, an Italian, tells a German newspaper that the British people did not want Brexit. In the 2017 general election, 80% of our people, the British people, voted for parties to deliver Brexit. They lied. Ms May said no deal is better than a bad deal. She then asked the UK parliament to vote on a bad deal. Tonight she will ask parliament to vote again, but this time for a no deal Brexit. She will vote against no deal. Tonight a Conservative Prime Minister, backed by Labour, will cancel Brexit. They lied to you. This is DINO: ‘democracy in name only’. As for Messrs Tusk, Barnier and the rest of you, and the useful Leo Varadkar, there’s a special place in hell reserved for DINOs, and Ms May will be joining you too. So I call on the British parliament, join me on 29 March in Parliament Square and, this time, let’s really take back control.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Madam President, two days ago, doctors diagnosed my uncle with a terminal illness and he will die this weekend. He spent his life in public service, protecting children from abusers, paedophiles and violence. He was a great Welsh democrat. He voted to leave in June 2016 and he will die not seeing Brexit. He will die not seeing Brexit because of a political class that despise him and voters in Britain, a class who believe that they are far superior in the way that they think they should control our lives and do not wish to listen to the voters who wanted to get rid of them. He will die because he will not get a Brexit before his death because of traitors like Tony Blair and Dominic Grieve who collude with foreign leaders to stop the democratic vote of the British. My uncle, I hope, will have God on his side and bless his soul, but for those of you who have denied him the right to Brexit and denied those 17.4 million people Brexit, God will not be on your side when they unleash their anger in the ballot box.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, Mr Timmermans, Mr Udo Bullmann, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for the way in which he has been a member of the European Union. There is a coalition in the House of Commons that is unable to achieve a common positive majority. There are the Remainers who don't want a deal because they're hoping for a referendum and are playing hard. There are those, the Farages of this world, who do not want a deal with the European Union at all. And there are those who view this for partisan political reasons. There were three Labour people who voted 'yes'. On this basis, there is currently no majority in favour of a constructive solution in the House of Commons. That is why the two major parties must finally talk to each other. They must prove to us where there is a majority, a constructive majority, which is worth talking about. I believe that we cannot extend the deadline unless this clarification is there. No extension without clarification. It must be clearly regulated here. Just prolonging and looking at what happens then does not seem to me to be appropriate. And I believe that the House of Commons needs to come to a clarification in the next fortnight in order to move forward on that basis. We need this security after we had to negotiate these two or two and a half years as we negotiated, because the conditions were never there in the United Kingdom. Michel, thank you very much for the work you have done, that the Commission has done, your team has done. However, I believe that we could have put our hands up, but nothing would have been adopted in the House of Commons because, for the reasons I have given, there is this negative majority. More was impossible and nothing more could be delivered if the interests of the European Union were not to be violated. And it must also be clear what comes with open borders now. Britain cannot sneak into the single market without meeting the conditions of the single market without entering the single market. This morning's statements are populist and malicious and cannot be accepted in this way. That would be a sneak-in into the internal market, which would not be acceptable.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Madam President, Vice-President, Mr Barnier, Madam Minister, ladies and gentlemen, a few days before this European Council, many questions arise and, among them, at least two are of crucial importance for the future of the European Union. Brexit, first, with the defeat of Theresa May yesterday and the probably inevitable extension of Article 50. I don't think we should prolong a torment that has lasted since 2016. We must therefore give voice to the British citizens. I appeal to the fellow members of the House of Commons to face the fundamental question of giving voice to the British people, of hearing their voices, of knowing where they want to go. It is clear that the Commons is blocked, they cannot define what they want. The only way out is to give the citizens a voice and hear their opinion, even though many of our pro-Brexit colleagues here are afraid to give people a voice. The second issue that is very important, and certainly more important than Brexit, for the future of the Union is that of climate change. We are going to take essential measures, but I think we also need to learn how to change our rules of operation. We must intervene on the European Semester, in order to focus it on the ecological objectives of sustainable development of the European Union and the United Nations, without turning it into a semester on austerity.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, the British company New Financial announced yesterday that more than 250 financial sector companies have already left or are leaving the United Kingdom. A change of 5 000 jobs. As a result, around £1 trillion will leave the UK. This is only about numbers that we know. We don't even know what's happening outside our field of vision. This is a major problem for the UK. On this side of the Channel, too, there will be a blow to Brexit. Think, for example, of the fishing industry or the transport world. At the same time, we see that there is no majority in the London parliament for any approach to Brexit. That means it's time for a new approach, for rethinking. The United Kingdom must remain in the European Union. We need a new deal, not a no deal. Make the UK an offer, it can't refuse. Thanks.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Madam President, I hear the word solidarity used over and over again. Solidarity can come in many forms, political, but also financial. Commissioner Timmermans, you talked about continuing preparation for a new deal, continuing the solid work already done. So, what are the plans in place to financially help the Irish economy in the case of a no deal? I really would like an answer.  Solidarity up until now has not cost the European Union a single cent. Also, while people talk about solidarity, we have a situation in which Ireland borrowed and burnt EUR 3.5 billion last year on the orders of the ECB. As part of the financial help needed in the case of a no deal this obscenity must end. Mr Barnier, you said that we remain respectful and calm. You do indeed. People in Ireland cannot control the diplomatic disaster that is the Conservative Party. However, when it comes to respect and calmness, I am glad that Tusk and Juncker are not here today: they have not remained calm and have at times put their own personal prejudice before diplomacy. You must think of this with every word that is used. Remember that.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: Madam President, Vice-President Timmermans, the European Council on 21 March will give the European Commission the mandate it is asking for in order to negotiate a free trade agreement with the United States at full speed. At a rapid pace, because Germany fears that the US government will impose a 25% tariff on its precious automotive exports as early as next May. What is it about? The adoption of zero tariffs on industrial products allowing Germany to maintain its trade surpluses vis-à-vis the United States, which will nevertheless further dampen the economic growth of others, especially that of France. It is also a matter of agreeing on common standards for new technologies. So the United States is going to impose its conditions on us again. Finally, it will be a question of lowering agricultural customs barriers. The United States is very keen on this and Germany will give instructions to the Commission, which will give in, because French farmers and herders do not weigh much against the mercedes, BMW and Audi industrialists. And as always, the negotiations on this new treaty will be conducted behind the backs of the Europeans, who will find out too late.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Anyone who watched the debate in the House of Commons yesterday and saw in a frightening way the rift in British politics can only be shocked. Shocked because there is a clear mandate from a majority of the British population, a majority in favour of leaving the European Union accordingly. And it doesn't matter if you think it's good or bad, it doesn't matter if I think it's good or bad. It is a question of respect for democracy and of majority decisions of a population that has set a clear direction. And please, I can only appeal to you: stop tricking, via the detour and through the back door to launch a second referendum. Decisions must be respected. And even if we had a second referendum, if we assume that it would now be for Britain to remain, what will the game go on? Will the opinion change again in a few months' time? Do we then have a third referendum? No. If we want to take ourselves seriously and also to reform this European Union, we must respect the rules of the game and take a clear, clean and fair path.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Madam President, the withdrawal of the United Kingdom is not just a procedural event. It essentially means rejecting any planned federalisation and the beginning of a new European Union, which will also be reflected in the forthcoming elections. A development based on the rise of healthy patriotic forces with a view to the proper functioning of the Union as it should exist, repatriating powers under the sovereignty of the Member States. The intimidation of the remaining members, by the supposedly exemplary way of dealing with the United Kingdom, will collapse. Those in power now, refusing to accept voluntary and two-way cooperation between independent sovereign states, will sooner or later be forced either to remove or respect national sovereignty and the concept of nation-state. It is time for serious people to take on the role of serving citizens as real representatives, a result of a broad rally and cooperation of patriotic forces in every European country. For a Europe adapted to nation states and not subject to economic interests and the service of the few and chosen.

name: Pilar del CASTILLO VERA
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen of the Council and the Commission, Mr Barnier , you have certainly done an impeccable job , the agreement reached on Monday night by Prime Minister Theresa May and the European Union was an opportunity. In fact, it was an opportunity to facilitate an orderly withdrawal: it gave sufficient assurances about the UK's concern to get caught indefinitely in the Customs Union. But it was nevertheered by the British Parliament.  It has been a new disappointment at its lack of realism and lack of responsibility, the lack of responsibility of that majority of British Members who are permanently blocking a solution.  It is likely that in the British Parliament today there will be a vote against no agreement and that tomorrow it will be voted in favour of extending Article 50 and deferring its entry into force, but what will not change the European Union is the terms of the exit agreement. So sooner or later, the UK will have to make the decision: agreement or not agreement, deal or no deal... That's the point.  And, in this scenario of uncertainty, there are a number of lessons that Brexit is leaving and which we must take note of. The first is that belonging to the European Union represents a profound transformation in the economy and functioning of a country and, therefore, leaving the group is such an arduous and titanic task. Decisions like this can't be made cheerfully.  The second is that abandoning means affecting daily, directly to the daily life of people, the small things that are very important in everyday life: the way to be able to buy the cheapest and most varied products, the health card to be able to travel all over Europe, the costs of roaming...  And the third lesson is the depth of the fracture it generates in countries where this can occur, as is happening in the UK.  Today, the European Union is more necessary than ever to be able to meet the global challenges we have. The one who does not act together risks staying in irrelevance.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I am now going to break some bad news to people who will be very angry with me, but I have no choice. We will have to drop catch-the-eye procedure because we are exceeding our time. So apologies, but that is the case.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Mr President, you have these Weeks of Strasbourg in which hope and despair coincide. This is one of those weeks. The desperation, almost all the other Members have already talked about very much, about yesterday's vote, and what that brings us now and where that should take us. I agree with many members, especially from my group, who believe that it is now time to let the people speak again, because the British Parliament is not coming out. I think we need to get back to the people to get out of this impasse. There was also a lot of hope this week. I'll tell you why. There were 60 young people in this House who tried to put an entire parliament in place to finally put climate policy at the top of the political agenda. Not only to implement the far too low ambitions of 2030, but above all to raise those ambitions. If we want to do Paris, if we want to honour Paris, then we will have to do 55% by 2030 and be completely carbon neutral by 2050. In order to achieve this, it is also important that we come to a climate law at European level which incorporates our commitments made in Paris and which entails important obligations for all Member States, so that there can be no freeriders. The young people are right to ask us to take this kind of action. That was definitely a sign of hope this week.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: – Madam President, after yesterday's chaos in the British House of Commons, we know that the Withdrawal Agreement is dead. The British cannot and will not vote on it indefinitely and clean wine must be poured: we are back to the beginning, we have just lost time. Ignoring this decision would be reprehensible;  And that's why the only logical solution is to prepare for a hard Brexit, the No deal.  It does not have to be the end of the world, either for Britain or for the European Union if we approach a cold-headed situation. World Trade Organisation rules and others will apply. If, tomorrow, our British colleagues ask for a postponement of the withdrawal from the European Union, we can extend it without major problems, and during this time it is possible to take some basic steps and measures to ensure that a so-called hard Brexit is achieved.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: Madam President, climate change will once again be on the agenda of the next European Council on 21 and 22 March. This is a corneal dilemma for the European Union: on the one hand, it is claimed to save the planet by reducing greenhouse gas emissions, on the other, we are encouraging unbridled free trade with the whole world, which mechanically leads to an increase in the same greenhouse gas emissions.   Free trade treaties combined with unsustainable standards imposed by the European Union on our businesses have resulted in the breakdown of our industries. We are reduced to importing products made in countries that do not meet the same environmental, health and social standards. In addition, everything is routed by supercargos, which are also superpolluts: sulphur oxide, nitrogen oxide, fine particles, etc. In short, we are losers on all counts.   It is time to rethink our entire business model. The future is for protection, relocation and short circuits. Producing, consuming, recycling within a reasonable geographical area: this is the only way to reconcile our ecological requirements with our economic interests.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: – Madam President, the rejection of the withdrawal agreement means several crucial things. First, an orderly withdrawal in two weeks is not going to happen and, secondly, the Union’s – and indeed the UK’s – priorities of protecting citizens and businesses most affected by the withdrawal and of avoiding a hard border between Ireland and Northern Ireland and safeguarding the Good Friday Agreement have not been delivered, a mere two weeks before 29 March. They are indeed under serious risk, and that is very bad.  If the result of the possible vote tomorrow is to request an extension, then what for and for how long? A short technical extension would only make sense with a positive meaningful vote, which is not the case anymore. A longer extension would not only bring the legal and political problem into the context of the European elections, but it will also provide for a period when a future partnership cannot been negotiated. The withdrawal agreement will not be re—opened. A longer extension means a longer period of uncertainty. The Union has said many times how important an orderly withdrawal is on the basis of an agreement concluded under Article 50 of the Treaty. This is indeed a precondition for creating the trust necessary for the negotiations of a deep and ambitious new relationship. We must repeat that today.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Madam President, European leaders will shake up the economy. But that's not enough. It is high time to link the economy to environmental protection and to protect workers where jobs are disappearing. That's what young people tell us. After the vote in the British Parliament, we can also just hope that there will be no hard Brexit. This will be, colleagues, the last summit before the European elections, and the responsibility is therefore even greater. Our citizens expect action, but I fear that the opportunity will be missed again. Let's just look at the failed migration policy. We have passed all the legislation in Parliament to ensure effective management of migration and secure borders, the culprits are in European governments and nationalist policies. And we have to point the finger at you. We know the heads of state, which are the biggest inhibitors of European migration solutions. Their reasons are populist, taking the rest of the Union hostage - all on the basis of intimidation. And what is the conscience of these leaders who ignore people's concerns? Migration has been europeans' biggest concern for five years in a row. What kind of face do they stand in front of the electorate?  I would like this time for the electorate to choose courage and, with their vote for a sensible, different, progressive, socially just Europe, to prove that dangerous populism, nationalism and cowardice are not the values of Europe and that we really deserve a different future.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Dear Chairman, Brexit has turned into complete chaos as neither side has acted in good faith or really wanted to honour what people voted for. Brussels saw this as an opportunity to send a message to the rest of us that there was no stability or prosperity outside the European Union, and London's wishes were largely articulated by politicians who personally did not want an exit, so through these negotiations they tried to achieve the impossible – to take Britain out, but to practically stay inside. The complicated political situation in both Britain and the rest of Europe has made matters even more difficult and this very complex process, which both sides have been complicating further since day one, could not be completed properly. Now we're probably going to watch the finger-pointing contest and looking for the culprit, but the blame is on both sides. There's no point in regreting spilt milk now, it needs to be prepared for the future. A future in which, I believe, we will work together on key issues and trade without barriers to mutual benefit.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: –  Madam President, just one short remark on Brexit. A so-called bad deal was negotiated not just by Mr Barnier on behalf of the Commission, but also by the Prime Minister of the UK and the UK Government. The problem, in my opinion, is not the deal, but the political crisis that is taking place in London, which has actually been supported by the activity of many people who have already spoken here today and disappeared, as usual. But let me talk about some other business at the summit. I guess it’s very important to focus on economy. After the good times, the times to come may not be so good. This could be triggered by the trade war, by Brexit or by other events. It’s up to Member States to consider how robust our economies are and how ready are they for an adverse economic environment, a slow-down in economic growth and possibly other implications.  The second important thing for me is China. Our representatives should be more assertive. They should more clearly articulate our legitimate interest and negotiate accordingly. Just yesterday we talked about cybersecurity and we should know what Chinese law on national security means. Obviously, there are huge topics such as fair trade, climate change and Chinaʼs involvement in in resolving this issue, and also human rights, and we should pay attention to those issues.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It is tragic what is happening in the United Kingdom at the moment. A nation that can look back on its history with justifiable pride and which owes so much to Europe is in the process of destroying itself and giving it to ridicule. Disoriented and without political control, Britannia threatens to run aground. This is an emotional moment for many of us that makes us stunned, sad, even angry. An entire generation will suffer the consequences of these events. At this historic moment, we must not make any more mistakes. Rather, our actions should be based on a characteristic that is rightly attributed to the British: pragmatism. So we must give our British friends one last chance, anything else would be ignorant right-handedness. This signal must come from London. The UK's whereabouts remain the most sensible option. In my opinion, however, this needs to be legitimised by means of a referendum, which this time, unlike the previous one, must be binding. Above all, we must do everything we can to finally provide clarity for the three million EU citizens in the United Kingdom and the 1.5 million Britons on the continent. Much is still unclear. Far too little is happening here. These people deserve a lot more respect. They have made their life choices on a different basis and must not become a game ball.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the dramatic developments in the wake of Brexit are shocking the Old Continent. Everyone in the European Union must understand that Brexit has sent a strong message, that european peoples are looking for another path to Europe, a Europe of nations and homelands, a Europe that respects national traditions and peoples, a Europe that is democratic and decentralised, a Europe of solidarity and not of the hard core, a social Europe and not a Europe of banks. The European peoples cannot stand the austerity and violent fiscal adjustment imposed by the Eurogroup and the European Central Bank and will soon send a strong signal to the forthcoming European elections. For Europe there is another way, the road to regaining the national sovereignty of its Member States, the road against the Chineseisation of wages, the road against German Europe.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Madam President, last night we saw another manifestation of the inability of the British Parliament to reach a consensus. A reduced majority, but still the fourth most devastating defeat in history for a UK government. Last night Theresa May set out three options. The first was to revoke Article 50 – possibly the first time those words have passed her lips in public. Secondly, she talked about holding a second referendum. Ditto. And don’t underestimate the significance of her saying those words. The third option was to negotiate a new deal. I think, though, that the message has finally got through in Westminster that the third option is not possible in any sensible timeframe. So now it’s down to no deal or no Brexit. It seems very likely that tonight the UK parliament will reject no deal. They will not reject no Brexit. Of course, we have a limited direct role here, we have to choose our language carefully, we’re giving signals. So let me assure colleagues here that there is a strong will in the UK for a second vote. The People’s Vote campaign is the biggest grassroots pro-EU European movement. Polls show a majority in favour of a second referendum. Like all things Brexit, it won’t be easy, but don’t believe the voices you’ve heard from the Brits here today. Seven out of nine speakers today represent only 1.5% of the seats in the House of Commons. They are spouting their usual rot and nonsense. They are not the patriots. They are the ones advocating a no-deal Brexit, and that’s an act of unparalleled harm to the British people and the European Union. They are not the patriots. Nobody calling themselves a patriot would advocate that kind of harm. No one laying claim to the title unionist would advocate a no-deal Brexit. No one who wants to support the Good Friday Agreement would advocate a no-deal Brexit. They are not in the majority – actually they are all in the bar coalescing around a beer now. They don’t even bother to stay and listen. So I say to them: you are not today’s people. You are yesterday’s voices. We are the voices of today, and young people support my position completely. (Applause)

name: Richard CORBETT
text: – Madam President, after the first rejection of the deal by the House of Commons back in January, Theresa May tried to renegotiate just one point, the Irish backstop, in order to appease the right wing of her party. But for a majority in the House of Commons that was not the main problem with her deal. There were other problems and she made no attempts to address those issues. She only tried to appease the right wing of her party and she failed. So where does that leave us? A majority in the House of Commons does not want to leave without a deal, but the only deal on the table has been rejected. Where do you go from there? Logically, there are only two possibilities: either you negotiate an alternative deal or you reconsider Brexit. The chances of an alternative deal look vanishingly small at the moment. Reconsidering Brexit needs a referendum and, as we just heard from Ms Girling, there is a majority in public opinion that wants another referendum and opinion polls show that, if there were another referendum, the British people would vote to remain in the European Union. It’s absolute folly to proceed with Brexit on the ground that it is the will of the people when it may very well no longer be the will of the people. It’s at least worth checking. (Applause)

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is clear to all of us that if there is no change of attitude in the United Kingdom, there will be a chaotic Brexit on 29 March, a hard Brexit. And we must also make it clear that those who are not prepared to talk to each other across party lines cannot solve a problem of the present and the future. The economic, environmental, social, technological and democratic challenges can only be tackled jointly in Europe across party lines and through a united Europe in the world. That is what the election to the European Parliament is all about. That is what the composition of the next Commission is all about. And this reality is in stark contrast to the political failure of political leaders in the United Kingdom, but also in other political parties and countries within the European Union.  Let us look at the murders of journalists in Malta and Slovakia, the blocked constitutional procedure against Hungary and Poland, the EU bashing of populists and nationalists in Hungary, Italy, the Czech Republic and Romania. The European idea is being jeopardised from within. We must reject the threat from within in the european parliament elections. With recriminations, lies, anti-Semitism, nationalism and isolation, we are not solving a problem in Europe, not even Brexit, but only with a new form of basic consensus with each other.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, following the rejection of the withdrawal agreement in the House of Commons last night, there is a grave sense of trepidation in Ireland, especially among the farming community and the agri—food sector – because they know that a crash—out, a hard border, reverting to WTO rules, will send them to the wall. They will go out of business. Also, we all know that if there’s a crash—out then the hard—won peace which we’ve enjoyed for the last 20 years is also in mortal danger. Therefore, I hope that today in the House of Commons they will vote to avoid a ‘no deal’, a crash—out. If they do, I think that we should immediately offer an extension – and not be putting conditions on it. We should offer it. Because we can do so for three months without interfering in any way with our elections. As my colleague, Jim Nicholson, said, this will help them to find another way – and maybe that way will be to stay. Now wouldn’t that be a countenance devoutly to be wished? Wouldn’t any extension be worth that?  So I am appealing to the European Commission to act in good faith by saying ‘yes, we’re going to help you’. We’re going to give you the time and the space to get your own house in order to avoid a hard Brexit, to avoid a crash—out; if you are serious about it, then we will give you the time and the space.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Madam Chairman, it is evident that the debate on preparations for the European Council has turned into a debate on Brexit. We are not talking about the Paris Agreement today, we are not talking about green technologies, we are not talking about European industry, the European economy, unemployment, or the disinformation that is pressing us from all sides in the dawn of the European elections.  Unfortunately, today's debate has turned into a Debate on Brexit. It is clear that Brexit is one of the most important topics. I would be pleased if those at Westminster today would pay attention to us here in the European Parliament and hear what we are saying. They are expected to make a prudent decision, british politicians are expected to be accountable. My personal opinion goes with those who spoke today about a second referendum, I think there is still room for a second referendum, I think there is still room for the UK to remain in the European Union, because I think the UK belongs in the European Union and I am sorry that there was such a populist term in the referendum. I believe that this can still change and that British politicians will be responsible enough and understand at what point they are and will not work against the young generation, against young people who in particular, as we have heard from Mrs Girling, are in favour of remaining in the European Union and I join all those who are advocating a second referendum.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, having listened very carefully to the speakers, I come to the conclusion that there is very broad support in this Parliament for the way the Commission is negotiating on behalf of the European Union, its Member States and this Parliament to try and reach an agreement with the United Kingdom on a withdrawal that would do as little harm as possible to both sides. This has been the intention of the Commission from the start, this has been the way Michel Barnier has been negotiating from the start, and we feel strengthened in our approach by the debates here today. Having listened to Mr Farage and his colleagues, and seeing the hubris with which he stands here and the self-gratification of his position, I sometimes wonder whether he has gone to Sunderland and talked to the workers at the Nissan plant and said to them, ‘It might cost you your job, sorry, but I’ll get my pipe dream of so—called sovereignty’. Has he done that? Has he gone to Oxford to the Mini plant and said, ‘I know what BMW are thinking if there’s a no—deal Brexit, but I want it so badly, this no—deal Brexit, that I really don’t care about your job’. Has he done that? That would have been the honest thing to do, I suppose. (Applause) Has Dr Liam Fox ever said, ‘Well, I said it would be the easiest trade deal in human history but, on second thoughts, it’s much more complicated than I promised before the referendum’? Has Boris Johnson gone to the doctors and nurses of the NHS and said, ‘I did promise you an extra GBP 350 million a week but, sorry, I can’t deliver on that promise’? Have they done that? I think, frankly, if we want to come out of this situation, we would need a bit more modesty and honesty on all sides. (Applause) I just referred to a report by the UK Government, published in November last year, where it said that a no—deal Brexit would cost approximately 9.3% of economic growth. Are you willing to pay that price? I ask the Brexiteers: are you willing to pay that price? Are you willing to sacrifice all those jobs for your pipe dream of so—called sovereignty? What is that sovereignty going to bring to you if you live that pipe dream? (Interjection from Mr Coburn: ‘Freedom is irreplaceable, sir, freedom is essential’) (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Mr Coburn, you and I have a special relationship. I am special, and I do not know what you are, so please, don’t interrupt. And I know Ms Atkinson takes issue with me on occasion, but please listen with respect. You may disagree but I would urge you to listen and maybe learn.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, well I did! I did listen to Mr Coburn and he says ‘liberty is more important’. Then have the courage and go to Sunderland and talk to the workers in the Nissan plant. Talk to the workers in Oxford in the Mini plant and tell them, ‘My so—called liberty is more important than your jobs’. Have the courage to do that, sir. Then also go to Ireland and go to a place where, since 1998, peace reigns and violence has disappeared and tell the people there ‘My pipe dream is more important than your peace and quiet. My pipe dream is more important and I will accept a hard border if that gives me my no—deal Brexit’. Have that courage. Do you know the number 16.1 million? I never hear it mentioned. I always hear 17.4 million. Yes. But 16.1 million are also British citizens who voted to stay. They haven’t disappeared. Isn’t the essence of European democracy that we also respect the position of minorities in our countries? Isn’t the essence of democracy that we try to build bridges and to find solutions that can be carried by most people in our society? Should those not be the next steps we take in this?  To be very clear: why does the Commission stand so firm for the integrity of the internal market? Why don’t we simply say ‘let’s have open borders’? I give you one example. If for some reason the United Kingdom would decide to have a trade deal with the United States on their terms and chlorinated chicken would be coming into the United Kingdom and we would not be able to check that at the European border, then we would not be able to say to European citizens that we could protect them against something they didn’t want. We could never do that. That’s why we have always to protect the integrity of the internal market. We’ve been bending over backwards and we spared no effort – and I do pay tribute to Michel Barnier – to try and reconcile Mrs May’s red lines and her demands with our firm duty to protect the European Union and the integrity of the internal market. The withdrawal agreement is the best and only possible solution to that dilemma and I hope that this is something that will be well understood. This is a position the Commission defends on your behalf. The vast majority of this Parliament supports this and we will continue to do that: to protect the interests of European citizens, whether they live on the continent or in the United Kingdom. (Applause)

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for their remarks and comments. I will inform the President of the European Council accordingly. It is clear that Brexit will be a pressing issue for leaders next week. Beyond dealing with these immediate concerns, it will be important also to address those strategic challenges that will define our common future in the years ahead. In that spirit, the different topics on the leaders’ table will help to inform reflection on our next strategic agenda. The next rendezvous will be the informal summit in Seville, which will be a key moment to discuss and start shaping that long-term agenda.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – European Council leaders must be courageous and turn the spring summit into the sustainability summit. It is not acceptable for us to continue to postpone the fight against climate change. We need to steer the Stability and Growth Pact, the European Semester and the other technical instruments of the Union towards a sustainability model. If we want to avoid the repetition of sad episodes such as Brexit, we must offer our societies a breath of new air that brings with it a policy of social cohesion and economic modernization, both accompanied by an environmental policy. The summit must not forget two other urgent challenges. On 26 May we have an obligation to ensure fair and free European elections. And to do so, the leaders of the Union need to make a greater effort. The obligations assumed by internet platforms are insufficient. In addition, the reform of asylum policy must be on the agenda. It is a scandal that more lives are being lost in the Mediterranean and that the leaders of the Union ignore the decisions this Parliament has taken to put an end to this human tragedy.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. – A maxim of Einstein who has always amused me said: "there are two infinite things: the universe and human stupidity. And I'm not so sure about the first one." And defending positions of principle is the stupidest thing that can be done. Toyota, BMW and Nissan are just the latest companies to have threatened to leave the UK in the event of Brexit in recent days, and May and the British Parliament continue to defend their seats as the Titanic sinks. No more politics in the House of Commons! And British politicians look after the real interests of the UNITED Kingdom. Let us facilitate an agreement between the two majority groups to ensure that something acceptable to the European Union is submitted for an extension. Let us facilitate an honourable departure from the scene. This uncertainty cannot continue for us, for you and for our citizens.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I still hope, even as time is running out, that the UK will leave the EU in a regulated manner. We must not rule out postponing the withdrawal date in general. Without a scheme, the UK falls back to third country status. This would entail customs controls at the EU's external border for all trade in goods. And it would lead to a border between Northern Ireland and Ireland. But we must also keep our own interests in mind: the elections are due in May, and by then the process of leaving must have ended. The UK must then accept the negotiated result or withdraw the withdrawal request.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. – I had the topic of debate 'Preparing for the European Council meeting of 21-22 March 2019 and the UK's withdrawal from the EU'. However, more than 80 per cent have been discussed about Brexit. For two years we have been consuming thousands of hours for this subject that has created a crisis in the EU. Prolonging the crisis brings negative effects for both sides. European leaders and European institutions must learn from Brexit. EU leaders need to understand that different management is needed in the future in which subsidiarity is taken into account. And as the Council representative said, "No one should be left behind". We need cohesion, industrial and social policy, respect for democratic and constitutional decisions in the Member States. We need a fair market for all European citizens. Only then can we secure a future for the EU. The Council must discuss important topics such as economic ones, the new Multiannual Financial Framework, the future of cohesion policy, the Schengen area - its enlargement with the States meeting the conditions of the Regulation, Romania and Bulgaria. Greater transparency and avoidance of the double measure applied by the Commission and the Council can strengthen the future of the EU.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. – This week, all of us in the European Parliament followed with particular interest the series of votes in the UK. While we do not yet know what the latest results will be in the House of Commons, we can say that we have seen a dangerous approach to Brexit without a deal.  I have always argued that this is the worst-case scenario for Bulgaria and our citizens. We are currently on the verge of finally avoiding it and moving to the extension option. Once the decision has been made not to allow an exit without an agreement, we need to see what mandate the government will give for next week's summit. The British government may, of course, ask for a deferral, but the question is under what conditions and how long it should be.  All I can say is that Britain is on the verge of taking part in the European elections again, which is sure to create problems for the European Union. We look forward to answering all these questions in the coming week.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – It is likely that a request for extension of the Brexit negotiations will soon materialise. But to fulfil the objective of the extension and end this impasse, the UK Government has to bring to the EU Heads of State and Government a clear vision of the form of the future relationship that is sought. This is currently lacking. The length of any extension should depend on this vision, and also on the extent to which the European block would want to negotiate. The European side still needs to make its position more transparent. For instance, regarding the backstop for Northern Ireland, is it true that an approach modelled on the situation between West and East Germany in the past has been ignored? If so, why? However, if the withdrawal agreement is indeed not negotiable, it would not make sense to allow the continuation of the negotiations for a much longer period going, say, beyond EU election day. The ongoing controversies within the British political system will not help. Using the possible extension to push for a second referendum could push the country towards more chaos. On the other hand it would be disastrous if the extension serves merely to postpone a no-deal Brexit.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: Written. "The PROCESS of the UK's withdrawal from the EU is becoming more confusing every day. There is no desire to find a majority for any constructive proposal. Yesterday's vote in the British Parliament came as no surprise. The withdrawal agreement negotiated by Prime Minister May collapsed for the second time with clear figures. There is still a law in force in the UK under which the withdrawal will take effect in two weeks' time on Friday 29 March. at 11:00 p.m. The negotiation period has now been wasted, and a contractual withdrawal is no longer possible by the deadline. The risk of an uncontrolled no-deal brexit has already become so great that the game should be whistled off at the latest.  I hope that the British Parliament will then end up seeking a short extension of the negotiations. The European Union should grant that additional period of a few months, provided that the British have some kind of plan for the future. A sensible plan would be to hold another referendum, because now British citizens have a better idea of what leaving the EU really means to them. The mere preparation of the withdrawal has brought a great deal of uncertainty to the everyday lives of many EU citizens. It has become clear in the withdrawal negotiations that the UK would like to continue to be involved in almost all EU activities. Therefore, staying in the EU would still be the best option.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – The withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union is a legally protected right. In view of the results of the referendum held in that Member State and the decision taken by its government to trigger exit procedures, the EU participated together in a negotiating process based on safeguarding its values and protecting its citizens and businesses without antagonising UK citizens, institutions or civil society. Throughout the process, the Peoples of Europe have made clear their respect for the will of the British people, and at the same time they have noted the desire to achieve a good agreement or to maintain the integrity of the territory of the Union. The impact assessment of an eventual exit without agreement has shown that this scenario, to be occurring, will be highly pernicious for both parties. It was with this assumption that European negotiators tried until the last moment to respond with openness and common sense to the requests of the British negotiators. The British parliament has chosen to clearly reject the proposed agreement. The European Union in general and Parliament in particular must maintain a firm attitude towards values and openness in solutions in order to defend the interests of all its citizens.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, over a year ago we adopted a position on the Dual-Use Regulation that would restrict the export of spyware to dictatorships and ease the export of encryption software: 92% of us did this because democracy, freedom and human rights are being violently attacked all over the world. New dictatorships in Africa and the Middle East are developing, and old ones like China are getting more and more oppressive. Horrific cases involving journalists – like Jamal Khashoggi being dismembered and burned in a furnace by Saudi Arabia for defending freedom and democracy – are in the news. These and other crimes have been made possible with European spyware in the wrong hands. We have decided, for moral and security reasons, that we, the European Union, cannot be part of this process. We strive to protect people all over the planet who wish to improve their society, who speak truth to power and who want to live in freedom and safety. We strive to protect our values. The European Council disagrees with us and has refused to adopt a common position in order to start discussions on this. It was, especially, a last-minute change of heart by Mr Macron himself that stopped us: France, Sweden, Finland and other Member States believe that European companies should be accomplices to these crimes and make a little profit as well. (Muted heckling) I call on the Council to listen to all the NGOs, the Commission and the European Parliament, and to put values before profit. And now let us vote on this and other safeguards against a hard Brexit. (Applause)

name: Alain CADEC
text: Chairman of the PECH Committee. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we will vote on two emergency measures in the area of fisheries, to be ready in case there is no agreement between the European Union and the United Kingdom before 29 March 2019. The House of Commons again rejected Theresa May's proposal last night.  I would remind you that these emergency measures are only applicable in the event of a no deal. However, if, as we all wish, at least a large part of us, an agreement is reached, this free trade or customs union agreement will have to be conditional on a reciprocal agreement on access to water and resources as it is set today. This is not negotiable! I am speaking on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, which wishes to reiterate this position on the future relationship between the European Union and the United Kingdom.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, it was obviously a technical mistake. The description in the text refers to the other EU institution, namely the Commission, and therefore I propose that the words ‘next’ and then ‘and her successor’ be eradicated because we refer to the Council now.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: That concludes voting time.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I supported this agreement between the European Union and Afghanistan. I believe that we must support the Government of Afghanistan, which is trying to stabilise the situation in this country and calm the civil war. I also say this as a Czech who is proud that hundreds of Czech soldiers contribute and are part of the peacekeeping missions that nato operates today in Afghanistan, and they are putting their lives on the line for peace in this country. I am therefore glad that the European Parliament has adopted this agreement today, and I hope that it will contribute to finally finding peace and some compromise with the Taliban in this country, although I am personally sceptical and believe that finding an agreement and a compromise with this organisation will be very difficult.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of concluding this agreement. I want to say that it is really important to help the development of this country, because the destruction of this country will come back to us, right in the near future, and it will come back to us at home. So it is very important for me to support the institutions in Afghanistan that are fighting terrorism there today, with the drug industry, with criminal gangs, of course, to support not only the soldiers who maintain at least some order there today, but also, of course, to assist the civilian administration of this country and the security forces. I consider this to be absolutely important, and at the same time I believe that it is precisely these proper Afghan institutions that need to be supported in order to modernise the country, to bring concrete real benefits to citizens, because these are precisely the tangible results of the work that we can bring to these people in Afghanistan.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, Afghanistan is, according to almost all of the UN league tables, one of the worst governed, poorest and most corrupt places on the planet.  The interesting thing is to ask why. Why has it developed that way? I don’t want to over—simplify as there’s more than one factor in play, but at least part of the answer is that Afghanistan was never a nation state. No single ethnic group constituted a majority. The demography is a mixture of Tajiks, Hazara, Uzbeks and so on. It was created, if you like, artificially, as a buffer state and therefore its history has been a series of coups, dictatorships, invasions and revolutions.  One of the most warm and profound and important developments of the last half century has been the multiplicity of new states in the world. The world has gone from having around 80 sovereign countries when the European Union was formed to 200 today, and this move towards smaller states has coincided with a move towards more democracy and more prosperity. How sad to see this continent alone going in the opposite direction.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by You started by explaining the votes with the Fotyga report, with Mrs Fotyga's resolution. Earlier, there is mr Zdrojewski's report on erasmus and hard Brexit. Does this mean that we will not explain this topic? I have been put on this subject and I do not understand why it is not on the agenda.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: As far as the Zdrojewski report is concerned, there can be no explanations of vote because there has not been a debate. So it's not planned.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: Mr President! In my view, when I speak on this resolution on Afghanistan, it is not an attempt to get the European Union to conduct a foreign policy or engage with the world, as I know many people around this House want it to. This is in order to crack down on a very central area in relation to the wishes I know there are in the Commission to develop an EU army.
