That is, of course, the dream of Parliament, the Commission and indeed a few individual Member States that the European Union will one day be the one that draws the whole security policy, foreign policy and defence policy. However, in this report, which was written by Mr Fotyga, there is a slightly higher degree of understanding of reality. There is talk here of the important alliance with NATO. NATO, the defence alliance that binds Europe with the United States, is the alliance that has brought peace and prosperity throughout the Western world since the second world war. That's the way forward! Not to build new defence models under Juncker as some kind of political leader, but to stick to what has worked: NATO, which has been the road to freedom for the whole of Europe.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, despite no one disagreeing on the urgent need for better EU—level laws for the benefit of disabled people, this proposed legislation is a disappointment. The UK Government worked hard behind the scenes to water down its ambition and should be ashamed of its role. In particular, mandatory access requirements for buildings and physical infrastructure were excluded, including for transport and vehicles. The implementation periods concerned are also far too long. On the other hand, I welcome the positive elements to improve access for all to electronic services such as online banking and self—service terminals, as well as the technical annex and the strong penalties requirements and working group involvement of disabled people’s representatives. For this reason I voted for the report.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I supported this report. Of course, it could be more ambitious in some aspects, but for me the direction it is going is important, that is, the European Union is dealing with disabled people, disabled fellow citizens, and it wants the products and services that are being placed on the European market to be applicable and usable to those people. I think that's an extremely important idea, an important signal. That is why I supported this report, although – as I said – I could imagine, in some respects, that it would be more ambitious and more accommodating to the people affected. This is a good direction, and perhaps the next European Commission, the next European Parliament, will refine this report and create even more conditions for people suffering from certain disabilities to be able to access products that are placed on the European market better and to be able to use them better.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I also supported this report because, in my opinion, Europe, if it is unhindered, should not suffer from obstacles for people with disabilities. We must remove the legal obstacles in the legislation that this report defines, there are a number of them, and also not create new ones. It is, of course, about the fundamental European freedom. On the other hand, I think that we must also respect the requirement of proportionality, especially with regard to the sustainability of certain rules for SMEs, which the report also reflects. I am not entirely sure of setting exactly the same obligation for all, for example, the websites of small and medium-sized entrepreneurs are being lists. This can indeed have a very fundamental impact on business. So we need to find the appropriate weight and proportionality of those measures. That is why I supported this report.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, the visa information system, which we call the VIS, helps to issue visas and helps the competent authorities on asylum, visas, borders, migration, to quickly and effectively verify third-country citizens coming to the European Union. The new VIS Regulation adapts the rules on the interoperability of databases, union information systems, precisely to work directly, efficiently and intelligently, so to talk to each other very quickly, in seconds. Protecting the Union's external borders, managing migration and improving internal security are essential for all of us, we know well. The new regulation introduces the obligation to fingerprint children from the age of 6, thus verifying the identity of a child applying for a visa. This will also be the case for stolen children, for example, and trafficked.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: Mr President! The migration to Europe is, absolutely, the greatest challenge of our generation. And we have already seen in recent years the disaster it has caused our countries that the European Union – the European Union where it has been promised to the electorate/ citizens to solve this problem – has not been able to do the job.  We have seen how the open external borders have led to Syrian fighters, terrorists coming into our countries. We have seen how the open internal borders enable them to move freely between countries and carry out their outs around, wherever it may now be the easiest for them. All because it has been said in this system that a task will be solved but has not succeeded. The fact that we are now trying to get a grip on the visa rules is, of course, a step in the right direction, but it is a step that is incredibly late. And where you would say: where would Europe be today if countries like Denmark and others had not implemented national border controls? Then it would be an even greater morass than what the Commission has created.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: Mr President! It should have gradually dawned on most Europeans that Europeans do not want the house here, for the Commission or the EU agencies to decide what the population composition should be in their countries. Immigration policy is undoubtedly the biggest, the warmest and the most important issue, because it will determine what our countries will look like in a generation and in two generations - whether we want to stick to that heritage, the culture, the tradition that the generations before us have given us as a christening gift, or whether we want to transform our homelands into a kind of laboratory for migration. I do not think that Europeans want the latter. That is why this is a bad proposal. The only good proposal, the only good way to deal with the migration of people, is to let the individual Member States decide for themselves how they want to adapt. If there is some crazy left-wing majority coming into government, then let them conduct their policies. But it should not be dragged down over the heads of Europeans who do not want it!

name: Silvia COSTA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the new Asylum and Migration Fund for the period 2021-2027, with its budget of ten and a half billion, has introduced important innovations, for example by including the principle of solidarity in the legal basis. More specific attention is paid to integration policies in addition to the first reception, with minimal resources devoted to the European asylum system, integration, solidarity and also development towards third countries, but with respect for fundamental rights.  I believe, however, that the Commission must at this point ensure that these indications are respected by the various governments, in particular our government, by the Italian Government, which is currently cutting funding for integration, for second reception, for solidarity and for municipalities and non-governmental organisations.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Mr President, honourable Members, I voted against the proposed text, although migration is part of the Biggest Problems of the European Union today. The proposal made is completely unacceptable, because instead of striving to achieve real results, we are again talking about a tool that focuses on the so-called " integration of immigrants entering the territory of the Member States, both legal residents and those who have entered illegally. This for me is unacceptable and unacceptable, entering into foreign culture, traditions, customs. Solidarity should be one of the principles on which the European Union is founded. But the mere assumption of spending money on entering people who have entered illegally or illegally, or those who have been denied the right to reside on the territory of the European Union, is completely unacceptable to me. Moreover, it cannot be noted that various NGOs, which are usually involved in trafficking in human beings, are mainly involved in the consultations on the establishment of the Fund.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Mr President, there is no doubt that in order to manage the ongoing migration crisis on its borders the EU needs to reform profoundly its migration policy and for Member States to share responsibility and show political will. This is the only way through which we can save thousands of human lives and stop human trafficking in Europe. The establishing of the Asylum and Migration Fund is just such a positive step towards the efficient management of migration by the EU. I welcome the fact that, under the proposal, the Member States will fulfil their obligations to centralise and develop all aspects of the common European asylum system, develop legal migration channels, promote the integration of third country nationals, ensure effective and sustainable returns and give meaning to the notion of solidarity and fair sharing of responsibility.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Mr President, the migration crisis has caused a political earthquake on European soil. It reveals a different understanding of the foreign and internal security policies of individual Member States, and this approved asylum migration fund shows that the European Union has embarked on a path of political pushing of the agenda without trying to bring different approaches into line.  Slovakia, like other Member States, has declared its willingness to deal with the migrant crisis where it arises. The funds from this fund will act precisely in the opposite effect, i.e. as a magnet for other asylum seekers.  From my business trips, and I have been to several refugee camps or ports where migrants come, I can say that, with the exception of direct war conflicts, people want to stay in their countries and build them, develop them.  In his letter to Europeans, President Macron outlines the pact with Africa, support for development, investment, university partnerships. Similarly, the European Christian Political Movement, of which I am President, proposes a sustainable economic model in which relations are most valued. Our political efforts should be directed right there. The Union's interference in the national competences of the Member States is a dead end.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I will therefore give an explanation on the Asylum and Migration Fund. I think there's been some kind of flaw in the system. Thank you for your kindness. There is a clear lesson from the migration crisis that we must seek a systemic solution both within the European Union and outside the European Union, and we need to work with third countries to eliminate the causes of irregular migration directly in the source countries. For this reason, capping the part of the budget that can be spent in third countries at five percent is completely illogical. That is why I voted in favour of the amendments, which unfortunately have not been adopted, and the ceiling of 5% has been agreed. That is why, in the end, I could not support the European Parliament's position on this Asylum and Migration Fund in the final vote.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – I voted against this report because the European Commission proposes the creation of a new integrated border management fund within the next multiannual financial period, which is so far good. But there is undoubtedly a need for support from member states, including my homeland – Bulgaria, which is an external border of the European Union with a country that we can hardly now call our partner – the Republic of Turkey. There are quite controversial proposals that once again show a bureaucratic manner and a work-based approach to pushing extreme liberal policies and practices, obsessed with a kind of seemingly useful tool. Throughout the document, the illegal crossing of a state border is governed by the term "unsettled". The two terms are completely and radically different, and the fact that someone has entered the territory of a Member State of the European Union illegally would not suggest any failures or any infunctionality of border authorities to the border states of the European Union. The report provides a number of requirements and references to human rights guarantee instruments for migrants who, in a situation of threat to national security, could not be placed above the rights of citizens of the Border Member States of the Union.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Mr President, as we all know the main goal of the European Union’s policy in the field of external border management is to develop and implement European integrated border management. However, this has to be done within defined limits and subject to the appropriate safeguards, hand—in—hand with the free movement of persons within the Union – a fundamental component of an area of freedom, security and justice. In this context, I warmly welcome the proposed regulation for the establishment of the instrument for financial support for border management and visas. I’m in favour of a financial framework with which to help address the evolving challenges more effectively. It is the right step towards real management and security of EU external borders.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I supported this report because I clearly consider the Schengen area and its existence to be one of the European Union's greatest achievements. Therefore, financial support for border management is, of course, a step in the right direction. Joint border management and sufficient funding are also strategic for security risks such as, for example, or still the migration crisis. Good border management is also a cornerstone of the security of the Schengen area and of the European Union as a whole. I must therefore regret somewhat that the proposal that the funds of this fund can also be used for the migration crisis on its own has not been approved. In the future, we should also focus on a system of coordinated sharing of police and customs forces within the European Union. I consider this proposal to be a step in a very right direction, which is why I supported it.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, the Union Internal Security Fund was established in 2014 to facilitate cross-border cooperation and exchanges of information between Member States. This Union Internal Security Fund will continue to exist and will be fuelled by European money and from 2021 to 2027, precisely because internal security and the fight against organised crime are very important for all citizens of Europe. I must point out that cross-border crime has increased lately. That is why this money must be spent to strengthen the external borders and, in particular, to buy that equipment that can scan travel documents, passports, others, for every EU or non-EU citizen entering and leaving the European Union. We are talking about scanning in databases, which is done very quickly, in a minute and scanning the visual image of the face. All of this means protection, and for all this there is money in this security fund, which the Member States have to spend. Unfortunately, not all Member States have spent it.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Mr President, I supported this resolution because I believe that the environment cares about each of us. The attitude towards her is a matter of upbringing in the family, of a social example, but also of politics. To my great regret, according to the latest statistics, the capital of my home country Bulgaria – Sofia is in the fifteenth place for pollution of the environment and air worldwide. Problems range from the combustion of non-environmental raw materials for heating, which in many cases is dictated by both social poverty and low education, to the use of old cars and the availability of expensive public transport. In addition to global aspects such as tackling harmful industry emissions coming from factories and factories and those in the transport sector, we also need to tackle the social factor of misinformation, poverty and misunderstanding of the problem. I think we need to invest in environmental awareness so that we don't have to invest much more in health care.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I abstained from voting on the Clean Air for All resolution despite the important problems that need to be resolved. It is unacceptable for us to abandon the use of coal for energy production by 2030, because energy in Poland is based on coal due to the availability of raw materials in the country and justified on economic and social grounds. Modern low-carbon energy is also needed in Europe as a guarantee of security in relation to nuclear energy and from the parties to electricity supply in the face of the development of unstable and difficult-to-forecast renewable sources. Scientific research is underway and we are currently conducting research to reduce pollution and innovative technologies to change the working regime of energy blocks with capacity of more than two hundred megawatts to new requirements related to improving working flexibility and reducing emissions such as oxides, halide, boron and mercury.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Mr President, I voted in favour of the clean air strategy despite the objections of the European People's Party for two serious reasons. First of all, the national ceilings for the six main pollutants that are destroying our health, the health of citizens and causing many diseases are being reduced. Secondly, because pollution, as you know, knows no borders, knows no borders, and that is why we must insist that international rules on transnational pollution have an even greater demand on the part of the European Union. Above all, however, we must mobilise citizens and local authorities to adopt environmentally friendly transport, and to replace old vehicles with the contribution of the European Union. The example to avoid in this case is the OASTH model in Thessaloniki. Buses that pollute our air do not serve citizens and, instead of investing in new vehicles, only pre-election recruitment.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – I abstained on this report because, on the one hand, improving air quality should undoubtedly be a priority for each of us. Problems with air quality requirements are important and their discussion should be placed at the top of our agenda. Although air quality in Europe is improving over time, air quality standards, in particular particulate matter and nitrogen dioxide, are still exceeding in many places. The Union tackles air quality through a number of specific legal measures: an application for low-emission mobility, an Energy Union, a reform of the common agricultural policy, new national emission ceilings, new air pollution limits for large combustion plants. The Union devotes significant resources to projects to reduce air pollution. Europe's air will not improve without a joint, concerted effort. And the solution is not to lay down new rules, given that two-thirds of the Member States of the Union have problems with the application of the current rules and norms laid down in 2008, but also repeat those of the 1990s. The balance between action and social spending must be found. Bulgaria's main priority is to reduce air pollution from low-quality bit heating, especially in gypsy neighborhoods.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, one person dies in the world every five seconds as a result of exposure to air pollution: more than 700 people die every hour. The consequences of these climatic conditions are without appeal, given that 90 % of the world's population is exposed to air pollution. Air pollution causes 7 million premature deaths every year in the world, including 600 000 children aged five or under: more victims than wars, killings, tuberculosis, AIDS and malaria combined.  I recall the words of US President Trump in the aftermath of his inauguration: when he withdrew the US from the Paris Agreement, he said: 'I care about the interests of the people of Pittsburgh'. Absurd! I, on the other hand, care about the interests of all those billions of people who do not pollute, but suffer the effects of air pollution and climate change.  I have a son the age of little Greta and an even younger one. I'm afraid one day they're going to say to me, "Dad, your generation is even dumber than the previous generation," the atomic bomb generation, to put it mildly.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, good air quality is essential for the well-being of all of us, which made it easy to vote in favour of this important issue. I am very pleased that the resolution also takes into account indoor air pollutants. People spend most of their time indoors, where air quality can be much more polluted than outdoors. We have a lot of people who will have to suffer for the rest of their lives after being exposed to bad indoor air. According to one estimate, for example, there are up to eight hundred thousand people in Finland who are exposed to indoor air problems every day in both homes and workplaces. Many of those exposed have even lost their ability to work. Mould and moisture damage affects numerous public and private buildings, such as kindergartens, schools, office properties, hospitals and apartments. Clean air is an important part of the health and well-being of all of us, which is why I am in favour of measures to improve air quality.

name: Jiří PAYNE
text: – Mr President, even on the European continent, we are faced with disinformation, propaganda, false information. We are also trying to do something about it in the European Union, but the question is how are we supposed to do it? The European Union decided some time ago to deal with the situation by regulating, imposing additional obligations on those who provide space on servers, those who operate social networks, and actually want to regulate public debate on the Internet. The fundamental problem is how to determine what propaganda really is. Who's supposed to determine that? It is an ancient temptation of all authoritarian and totalitarian regimes to determine, if I say so biblically, good and evil. And it can even be said that, as a rule, it is precisely those regimes that run their own propaganda that fight propaganda by some kind of regulation. There is only one option to solve this problem, we have known it since ancient Greece. It's a free and fair discussion. That's the only way to get to the truth, that's the only way we can get rid of some propaganda. And that is why I could not agree with regulation that goes against fair debate, which seeks to promote regulation.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this vote confirms Europe. We have taken the opportunity offered by the association negotiations with the Republic of San Marino and demonstrated the value of strengthening relations and integration with the European Union. Our friends in San Marino have always been at the heart of European history and the partnership with the Union has always been based on a complex of common political and cultural values. Negotiations must continue. We will conclude a joint political declaration before the end of this mandate by recommending that the Commission and the European External Action Service conclude the negotiations as soon as possible and in any case within the next two years.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on the recommendations for the opening of negotiations between the EU and the US (2019/2537(RSP)).

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the joint agreement between President Juncker and President Trump of last July outlined a focused and positive trade agenda with the USA, our first and most important trade and investment partner, and it has helped to de-escalate tensions in this very critical relationship. Since last July, I have met my counterpart, US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer, five times to review the implementation of the work programme identified in the joint statement. At our meeting last week, we evaluated progress in the work streams of the executive working group and I debriefed him on the process for adoption of the EU’s negotiating authorisations. I conveyed to him that there is momentum in the Council to conclude, in the weeks ahead, the discussions on authorisation for both negotiations – one on elimination of tariffs on industrial products and the other one on conformity assessment. I expressed our commitment fully to respect the implementation of the joint statement as it stands, and reiterated that future negotiations would not touch upon agriculture. I am sure that this House is fully aware of the importance of the transatlantic trade relationship, which has been and will remain a central artery of the world economy. The carefully defined, narrow and meaningful agenda of the working group can be to our mutual advantage. Given the size of the EU-US trade relationship, elimination of tariffs, even though they are today already moderately low, will lead to important cost reductions for economic operators. Many industrial sectors on both sides of the Atlantic operate with small profit margins due to the size and efficiency of our respective markets. A limited yet very meaningful agreement on industrial goods and tariffs would give transatlantic companies of all sizes a comparative advantage and would support their global capacity to compete. We estimate an increase in bilateral EU-US export of 8%, and respectively 9%, and that is around EUR 26 billion, so quite a lot of money.  In a different strand, our work on conformity assessment, standards and regulatory issues could leverage the resulting economic benefits for a free-trade agreement for industrial products. We launched consultations with stakeholders last week, inviting them to come forward with proposals, and we’re looking forward to receiving their support for our discussions with the USA in this field. I am fully aware that some of you here fear we will be negotiating under threat. In that regard, I would like to assure you that I have conveyed a very clear message to our counterparts – as late as last week and also before that – that unilateral trade actions from the USA on EU imports would risk damaging our efforts to strengthen transatlantic relations at a critical time. I’ve also made it clear that, while it would not be of our choosing, if the USA did take unilateral trade measures against us we would immediately respond. Indeed, the negotiations would stop – that is clearly provided for in the draft negotiating directive – and we would also promptly adopt rebalancing measures. I hope, of course, that wisdom will prevail, and that this will not happen, so we can continue to work towards a mutually beneficial outcome to build this relationship. The timely adoption of these mandates would be an important signal of the EU’s good faith in relation to honouring the joint presidential statements last July: no more, no less. Delay in the adoption risks initiating an unconstructive cycle of exchanges and allegations on the EU’s commitment to the joint statement. So I sincerely hope that you will support our negotiations with the USA. Your support is, of course, very important. It would show unity among the EU institutions, and unity is our strength. In contrast, and this is important, a vote by this House against these limited negotiations would be a vote against the well-balanced and proportionate approach of the July statement, which we deployed to reduce trade tensions. It would therefore be a vote in favour of maintaining current trade tensions with the USA at a time when ideas to bring down these tensions are on the table. Especially regarding cars, as we have included that in our proposal, it is much better for the transatlantic relationship to bring car tariffs down to zero percent. It’s better for the producers, for the workers and consumers: much better than slapping additional tariffs on cars and car parts. Let me assure you that I will listen very carefully to this debate, to your ideas and recommendations, and I would reiterate that, once we have started negotiations, we will actively be informing this House on a regular basis on all aspects of our discussions, as we always do.

name: Godelieve QUISTHOUDT-ROWOHL
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to express my respect for you. Their efforts to restore transatlantic relations are important and they can only lead to lasting results through constructive negotiations. I therefore recommend that this House behave responsibly in tomorrow's vote and speak out in favour of such a mandate.  It is in all our interests to explore possible similarities with the United States and to use them to defuse trade tensions. But anyone who suddenly demands that the Commission show a hard edge, only this language can understand Trump, does not care about all those who have to bear the damage every day through possible sanctions, be it on cars or other products. Instead, it is precisely because of the disagreements between the EU and the United States that we should return to the negotiating table. What do we have to lose?  If these negotiations were unsuccessful, it was at least a constructive attempt to re-establish relations. If they produce results, we have not only defused a trade conflict, but we have also been able to reduce tariffs and barriers to trade. Finally, I would like to add a single sentence: the world is moving, it is moving forward, whether we are negotiating or not, and I believe that it is the duty of the great democracies to work together.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done "We won't negotiate with a gun to our head" – that was the principle of the European Union in many recent press statements: we do not negotiate under blackmail pressure. Now I wonder: what has changed? US tariffs on steel and aluminium are in force, and there are additional tariffs on Spanish olives. We have the threat under Mr. Trump for additional tariffs on cars and parts of cars, he has just completed an investigation. Nothing has changed in terms of US pressure. On our side, we have made many concessions. Imports of liquefied natural gas from the US have increased by 180%, and imports of soybeans have increased by 112%. The Commission has confirmed the sustainability of American soya beans in an urgent procedure, two months only, and they can now also be mixed into biodiesel, in other words an increase in imports of American soya beans. So we, as the European Union, have already made a number of concessions. I ask: where are the concessions made by the United States? Where is the pressure of the United States being reduced? I don't see anything there. And as long as that is the case, we must formulate our position very confidently. Secondly, in July last year, we decided not to conclude an agreement that does not have a reference and implementation of the Paris agreement on climate change. Today, a few hours before this debate, we discussed climate protection. None of this is reflected in the mandate proposals, not even an impact assessment on the climate impact of this agreement. No, let us formulate our requirements with confidence! For i am still: we want to enforce the law and reject the law of the strongest.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, transatlantic trade is a cornerstone of the global trading system. Our political group supports the Commission’s two draft mandates, one on tariffs on industrial products and another on conformity assessments. They will not only help to de—escalate rising tensions but also, and more importantly, would bring substantial benefits to EU businesses and consumers. For instance, the elimination of high tariffs on manufactured goods, such as clothing and footwear, would open up opportunities for EU exporters and increase the international competitiveness of our industries. In addition, our SMEs would benefit from the elimination of duplicate testing, inspection and certification requirements that would be possible with a conformity assessment agreement. I would add, however, one crucial condition for these negotiations: they cannot be successfully concluded without the tariffs on steel and aluminium being removed. More clarity is also needed on the inclusion of the automotive sector, as it is key to ensuring World Trade Organisation compatibility, and on how the rules of origin will work. I believe too that the EU and the USA must both build on and learn from the four years of negotiations on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, especially in relation to possible ‘quick wins’ on tariffs, customs facilitation, standards and regulatory cooperation. The ECR Group hopes that this agreement can be the foundation to build on in years to come.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, rules-based trade is important for our open economies, especially because the majority of growth in the next decades will take place outside of the EU.  But when we look at China, we see a country not respecting trade rules and sadly now, when we look at the United States, we also see an administration that has unjustly labelled the EU as a national security threat in order to justify steel and aluminium tariffs, while, of course, reminding us of our obligations under the NATO alliance. It doesn’t quite add up, and the escalations in our trade relations with the US have serious consequences. It is therefore crucial to keep talking and to try to come to agreements. Somebody has to be the adult in the room. For those in the House who do not want to support the European Commission here, I hope you understand that it will be gladly explained by Ambassador Sondland and other officials of the Trump administration as proof of the EU’s inability to make decisions, and that is not in our interest. Instead, by supporting the Commission opening negotiations on the basis of a limited scope (this is not the defrosting of TTIP, it is the consequence of the agreement between Juncker and Trump) but spelling out very clear conditions on our part before closing them, we engage in the most meaningful way.  I would also like to remind colleagues that they should not use the agreements we make with third countries as the weapons to beat those countries with, while we in fact lack the foundations of a bilateral agreement or negotiations with countries that we do trade with – think about China.  Let us be clear about what is to gain here, but also be very very mindful of what we could lose. My group will support the European Commission, and I believe we have to be strong and united as Europe, especially when dealing with the confrontations of the Trump administration.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Donald Trump is the one who, a few years ago, said 'global warming is a total hoax. It is a concept invented by and for the Chinese, in order to make the American manufacturing sector uncompetitive." Just a few weeks ago, when the U.S. Congress drafted a climate report, with 300 scientists pointing out the dramatic effects of climate change, including on the United States, President Trump said "I don't believe it." President Trump, over the past few months, has been blowing the embers of Brexit, backing the hardest Brexit, even criticising Theresa May for her desire to strike a deal with the European Union. And it is with this president that you want to negotiate today, it is to this president that you give a part of our sovereignty, part of our values, as has been said. I even hear our Social Democrat friends find, in this election period, reason, common sense. We don't negotiate with a president who puts a gun to our head! We don't negotiate with a president who taxes us in the morning, who threatens us in the afternoon on the steel industry, on cars and tomorrow on I don't know what!  So if we have courage, if, in this period, we want to show that the European Union is an economic power, a political power, if we want to show that the European Union defends its values on climate and on all social, environmental issues, we cannot start negotiations with the United States. It's tartufferie to say, ''Let's start, and we'll see what happens over time.'' No, we cannot negotiate today with the United States, because President Trump does not represent our values, does not embody our values, is a danger to our economic sovereignty and therefore to our democratic sovereignty.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Commissioner Malmström, President Trump recently threatened us as the European Union: 'I will tariff the hell out ouf you' if we do not agree to a trade agreement on its terms. That sounds like a saying from a bad Western. You yourself said in the Mirror a year ago, "We don't negotiate until Trump takes the gun off our chests," and now they want to capitulate?  I am disappointed that you have proposed to the Council that you be given a negotiating mandate for an agreement, despite the increased threat of punitive tariffs on cars. They are even throwing their own principles overboard: although the substantial agreement is supposed to cover more than 90% of all goods traded between the EU and the US, you are refusing to study the economic, social and environmental consequences. There is not even a standard chapter with rules for the protection of workers and the environment in the production of these goods. There is no consultation with the public. You are also closing your eyes to Trump's decision to leave the Paris climate agreement – my colleagues have already spoken about it. According to our principles, the Trump administration has thus disqualified itself as a negotiating partner. You know what Trump is up to. He wants to force the opening up of our market to American agricultural goods. But that would be the end for thousands of our farmers, and for our sustainable agriculture as well. Have you forgotten the TTIP protests of millions of Europeans? In return, he does not want to give anything, but only renounces the imposition of punitive duties on cars at that time. Commissioner, I am campaigning for a majority in favour of our motions in tomorrow's vote to recommend to the Council not to give a mandate for these negotiations.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, our position on this second version of TTIP has not changed, but that of the Commission has obviously changed, since from American sources agriculture will be included in the agreement. Of course! We know, it's too much of a throat for the Americans. But you see, we don't have to reach out to the United States. We have already done our part by importing 77 % more than their soya and 181 % more than their natural gas. Now it's time for them to come to meet us. Before we even start negotiating, we want the US administration to suspend tariffs on steel and aluminium and stop any hostile action on our cars.  Do we want to make a new deal? Fine! Let us, however, cancel the negotiating mandate of the old one, start from scratch and erase forever that infamous TTIP that has terrorised European citizens for years. And, for heaven's sake, we don't sell off our agriculture.

name: France JAMET
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this resolution is a real mystification. The spirit of the original text was completely perverted in committee by an alliance of ultra-liberals composed of the EPP, the ALDE and the ECR, since some of our colleagues chose to sacrifice political necessity to shopkeeper interests. Where we had to demand strong guarantees against the United States before we think about negotiating, we now want to negotiate before we get strong guarantees on the auto sector, on the exclusion of agriculture before the negotiations and finally on an impact study on the fisheries sector. Who can believe that an agreement that we will take 10 years, 15 years, 20 years to negotiate will not be signed, if only one of these conditions was not fulfilled at the end of the negotiations? No one. It is imperative that we set our conditions in the United States before we get to the negotiating table, and certainly not the other way around!

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the Juncker Commission has had to rectify the pull of its trade policy after the United States' decision to withdraw from the trade and investment agreement. The truth is that sanctions or tariffs on Spanish aluminium, steel and black olives that have to be eradicated are not the best start. In this context, last year's July declaration and these negotiating directives for tariff reduction agreements on industrial products and non-tariff barriers are an interesting turn. But, Commissioner, it is important to maintain the principles — by the way, there are colleagues here who invoke the principles of our trade policy when they have not believed, do not believe and use them as an excuse to reject free trade agreements. It is important, Commissioner, to fight for rules-based trade on the reform of the World Trade Organization, to preserve the principles of Paris and, above all, Madam President, not to renounce the ongoing agreements: Mercosur, Australia and New Zealand.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Madam President, I would like to say to Madam Commissioner that we all agree here that the transatlantic relationship is facing an important number of challenges and disruptions in the short term. Nevertheless, I remain convinced that the long-term fundamentals remain, and have to remain strong. It is important today for the EU to take all necessary safeguard measures to protect the EU internal market, our workers and our industries. That means being firm and rapid in counteracting any new tariffs and measures taken by the US administration, but at the same time to do our utmost to appease the tensions and avoid a trade war, which could escalate and heavily impact on both sides.  We know well that there is no better way to avoid new tariffs than through dialogue and negotiations. This is why I trust the Commission to do the right thing and I welcome the efforts of President Juncker and Commissioner Malmström and support starting talks for limited sectorial negotiations with the United States. I will conclude with one question, Madam Commissioner. If we say no to the talks with the United States, with whom will we say yes in the future?

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Madam President, the US and European have always been natural partners. We champion common values and face common threats together. As in any relationship, there have been highs and lows. Despite the occasional obstacle, the fundamental common interests of our relationship remain strong.  Last year was clearly a low for our trade. While responding firmly to the tariffs on steel and aluminium, the EU at the same time showed it is willing to cooperate to find solutions. The message was clear: we need to work together; we need this for our businesses and the jobs they create in Europe. Our markets, resources, security and citizens are highly interdependent, and this will only increase. Therefore I hope this Parliament will clearly support the launch of the negotiations. We can always win through negotiations, but we will only lose if we close the door to the US.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. President Juncker's visit to the White House in July was a stroke of genius. If the Commission had quickly presented a mandate on the basis of the results of this visit, we would be better off today. But with a false tactic, they have sploffed political capital and time, out of great fear of public debate and unrealistic assessment of the us administration's hard work. You are just saying, Commissioner: ... 'unilateral trade actions would risk damaging our efforts of strengthening transatlantic trade relations'. This is how fearful souls speak. Mr Lighthizer, on the other hand, speaks to us in the tone of the command. And all I can say is that if you behave like a kicked dog, you will experience many kicks. I am in favour of negotiation, but not on the basis of such a weak mandate. That is why we must reject this and come back and force you to present a better mandate.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: – Madam President, this morning we discussed climate change and the right has filled our mouths with empty compromises. Even Commissioner Cañete seemed concerned about the future of the planet.  I say how worried you won't be when you veted Greta Thunberg, only 16. It's scary for you to hear the truth.  Most European policies delve into the suicidal dynamics of accelerating climate change, and here we have the perfect example: resurrecting TTIP. They change his name, chop him, and think that's how it's going to go unnoticed.  Commissioner Malmstrom, you undertook to make the implementation of the Paris Agreement a sine qua non condition for signing trade treaties. We all know here what Trump thinks of climate change and that he denies the agreement, but business is business and it seems that it weighs on you more than the future of the planet.  As we have already beaten TTIP once, we already know how to do it: with information and with mobilization. But today, moreover, there is a young person standing along with a feminist movement that will not allow them to move forward with policies that compromise our future.  We need another business model, let's do it while we're on time.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: – Madam President, German car manufacturers exported cars to the USA to the value of more than USD 20 billion in 2017. In 2015, the figure was over USD 26 billion, and this notwithstanding the fact that German car manufacturers have little or no input in the formulation of US regulations. Nonetheless, they export very successfully. But let me come to the key point, that US tariffs on imported cars are 2.5%. EU tariffs on cars exported from the USA, by comparison, are 10%. It is asymmetric. The US administration has a point, whatever colleagues may say. And, in consequence, US exports of cars to the EU are a tiny fraction: only USD 48 million, as against USD 20 billion. Now to the resolution. The resolution criticises the USA for withdrawing from the Paris Agreement but, Mr Jadot, you cannot have the government that you want in someone else’s country. Indeed, you can’t always have the government that you want in your own country. I certainly know that now and I have known it for some years. What we’re looking at here is the politicisation of trade. The politicised paraphernalia in this resolution shows how difficult and tricky it is for the EU to finalise trade agreements, and that is the penalty that the people of the EU Member States pay for the politicisation of trade, which is aided and abetted by so many colleagues and is something I deplore. (The speaker agreed to take a blue—card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Yannick JADOT
text: 'blue card' question. "Dear Colleague, I did not quite understand if you were convinced of climate change or if you were not convinced of climate change. I did not quite understand whether Britain, which has been a very large country in the international community, still believed in the universal values of this international community. And then I did not quite understand whether the government in Britain was today, in these voting moments, your government!

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: blue-card answer. – I think that’s two questions. If you don’t mind, I’ll just answer one. In this debate we’re discussing trade, not climate change, and this is a serious point that I’m making. It is simply that you should not, with your considerable political expertise, tack irrelevant things about climate change – or, for that matter, other irrelevant things – onto what should be basic ‘plain vanilla’ trade agreements. If you do so, it will be costly to the peoples of Europe whom you claim to represent.

name: Christophe HANSEN
text: – Madam President, trade conflicts begin when one country decides to violate international trade rules to undercut another country’s industries. This is exactly where we stand in our relations with the United States. Our aim here should be to stand up strongly for our export jobs. Those who seek to torpedo negotiations with the US are playing poker with the jobs of our people. Let’s not forget that 88% of the EU companies exporting to the United States are SMEs. The European Commission should pursue a win-win agreement, strictly within the scope of the negotiation mandate, and respect the July conditions for concluding an agreement; and we should resist any American effort to include agriculture. As JFK once said, we should never negotiate out of fear, but never fear to negotiate, and that’s what we should do if we have the political courage, Mr Jadot.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Madam President, Madam Commissioner, I think this question as to whether we should restart negotiations is very important for us. I think it’s clear to everybody that the Trump White House is undermining all that we stand for, not only in Europe but also in much of America. I am vice-chairing the delegation to the US and I have many colleagues in Congress who have the total opposite opinion of Mr Trump, Robert Lighthizer, Wilbur Ross and all these people who are occupying the administration in what they think.  Should we then start discussions with people that we don’t agree with? People who are undermining the rule of law on trade, people who are undermining the World Trade Organisation. I think we should do it because Europe is a strong superpower when it comes to trade. We are the ones who are in the driving seat and we would never accept, in trade negotiations with the US, any deal before they lift their unilateral tariffs on us.  If you can restore some sensitivity and the rule of law, then we should take it, but we should not do it under pressure.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – I just want to clarify from your speech, Mr Kofod, whether I am right in characterising what you said as being that the European or EU superpower, as you put it, should not talk trade with an administration that it disagrees with, even if that administration happens to be in the one real superpower in the world – the USA – and that you would rather talk to the people in opposition than to those currently in a position to do a trade deal? Surely – and, believe me, I understand what it’s like to see a government in place that I disagree with – if we’re talking about trade that affects all of our constituents, all of our countries, there should be discussion about trade for jobs and employment and careers?

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: blue-card answer. – Well, I think you misunderstood me. I think we can talk to the US administration, despite all of the differences we have, because the US is much more than the current administration, the Trump Administration; the US is Congress, where a lot of people fiercely disagree on the trade policy that this White House under Trump is doing. What I said is that Europe is a trade superpower: we uphold the rule of law when it comes to trade. We want to ensure that the World Trade Organisation continues. We want to ensure a level playing field in trade. We want to integrate sustainability. We want to integrate and fight against climate change in our trade agreements. We should talk from a position of strength, not be too weak to talk to the people we disagree with.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the European Union has decided to reopen negotiations to reach a trade agreement with the United States. Yet people strongly reject free trade treaties that impoverish them. The comprehensive agreement with the United States has been in a state of stalemate since the election of Donald Trump. Instead of taking note of this failure, technocrats are trying to find alternative tricks. This agreement, which we are discussing today, is one of them. However, there is nothing positive to expect from this negotiation. How can we believe that agriculture will really be excluded, when Mr Juncker has already agreed to increase imports of American soybeans in order to sell German cars. It is time to opt for another model, more sustainable, more social, more respectful of people and the environment. Every day, the European Union shows that there is only one thing to do, to get out of it and get by.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: I have a great request for the following procedure of spontaneous speeches: I have ten applications and I would like to take them all. The basic requirement for this, however, is that you please keep to your speaking times. Otherwise, I will not allow all ten to speak. Spontaneous speeches

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We have an agreement with Canada, with Japan, we have also recently adopted an agreement that will be implemented with Afghanistan, and we do not want an agreement with the United States.  The far left and the far right believe that negotiations should start from scratch or not be conducted at all. Why? Because they don't like Donald Trump. But the Americans liked it. Maybe they made a wrong. And were there no electoral mistakes in Europe? The British people have made no wrong with Brexit? Watching the British Parliament, I have the impression that Members are playing football on the basketball court, but they do not yet know about it.  Mistakes happen. However, such a serious partner, with whom we have very important security and defence links, must also be our strategic partner in trade agreements. I would like to draw attention to this by stressing the importance and importance of trade relations with the United States.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I am defending transatlantic relations and dialogue as a mechanism for resolving the problems we face, but I honestly do not believe that the conditions for negotiating a trade agreement with the United States in the terms raised by the Commission are met.  I think in politics the most important thing is the coherence between what is said and what is done. And I want to address all the young people who are here, who are firmly committed to the fight against climate change and who are asking politicians to take action to solve that future. And if we say and approve in this Parliament — and the European institutions have expressed a strong commitment to combating climate change - we cannot make an exception to a trade agreement with the United States because it is based on industry – which has the most polluting effects – to exclude it from this situation.  And we cannot negotiate with those who have not considered us a reliable partner, with whom it has attacked us by imposing tariffs based on laws that are not justified because they threaten security — the European Union is supposed to threaten its security; these are not the conditions for establishing a dialogue as it should be in the future.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Madam Chairman, the United States of America is our main global partner and in this sense it is logical to expect a long-term mutual commitment to facilitating and increasing trade. I am pleased that a new chapter in trade relations is opening relatively soon after the collapse of the TTIP negotiations. I hope that this time we will not repeat the old mistakes and that the new agreement will cover all industries and that we will not slave to futile attempts to harmonize production standards, but open the space for mutual recognition of existing standards with a special label on products.  I also hope that our negotiators will not bring European prejudices about President Trump and his administration to the negotiating table. If we send political messages about Trump's rule through these negotiations instead of focusing on business, we certainly won't make it. The question then is whether, and when, there will be a third attempt.  So let's be wise.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to express my agreement with this negotiating mandate for three reasons. Our economy will grow more in the coming years thanks to what we are billing abroad.  The three reasons: one, preparing for this situation is mandatory for the European economy and essential for SMEs to operate in that country; two, these agreements are the only way to defend and extend our environmental and social standards; and three, this is not an isolated performance.  Europe has responded to the threat of neo-protectionism and trade wars by signing very important agreements, such as the recently closed one with Japan and those negotiating with other actors forcing everyone to move.  I would like to stress that if all this is possible it is because it is being managed in women. Grievance lists, thick words, testosterone love Trump—it's true, he loves them—but he hides in that noise the failure of the recipes he advocates.  And Commissioner Malmstrom cheres, in addition to the résumé, an ability to negotiate, but she conducts this with emotional intelligence. That's why the show politics, that of the short-term and tuiter headline that is being worn today, is not going to get you up from the table and I...  (The president withdrew the floor to the speaker).)

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Madam President, entering trade negotiations with the US at this time would mean colluding in their attempt to smash up the institutions of multilateral trade cooperation and joining Trump in the new global game of ‘bully thy neighbour’. It would make a mockery of the idea of trade for all, and would put the final nail in the coffin of the vision of an EU trade policy based on environmental and social justice. With the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) stating that we have only 12 years to solve the climate crisis, it is simply impossible to open trade negotiations with a country that is the world’s second biggest emitter of carbon dioxide and yet is reneging on its climate commitments at every opportunity.  How can we be considering offering the US improved trade terms a year after they introduced punitive tariffs on our steel industry, while failing to make their own steel industry compliant with the Paris Agreement? Rather than feeding Trump’s ego, we should develop a strong industrial policy that defends European workers and supports the move towards a low-carbon economy.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, let us be very careful, because we will not allow you to circumvent the opinion of this House and of the peoples it represents, and therefore to open trade negotiations with the United States of America that are in fact a kind of 'decoy treaty' that endangers health and the environment, that allows the unconditional entry of agricultural products and fisheries from the USA. For example,. This decision would be truly illogical, which would further drown our fishermen and the entire fisheries sector, flooding the European market with cheap fish. A threat against which we will oppose with all our might.  How many times have we said that trade agreements must be made, yes, but in the interests, first and not only of European citizens, and provided that they create attractive, useful and market markets for our producers? No matter how many times you ask us, our answer will always be the same: no to a new TTIP.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The opening of negotiations is aimed at halting the further escalation of trade and political tensions between the US and the European Union. As long as talks are ongoing, the US has pledged not to impose tariffs on imports of cars from the European Union. Automotive accounts for 12% of total Polish exports and 85% of Polish automotive exports are aimed at the European – mainly German – market. Germany, on the other hand, is a major exporter to the US market, so it is in the Polish economic interest to avoid tariffs on cars, and negotiations with the US can contribute to this objective. I must also mention the safeguarding of vulnerability in the energy-intensive sector. These are differences in gas prices, energy and regulatory costs in the US and the European Union – especially in Poland. No less important is the elimination of LNG export licences in the US, which would bring greater stability to trading conditions.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, of course, we have many reasons to be angry with the Trump administration. Personally, I have fought very hard to introduce a lot of amendments into TTIP. That TTIP fell, but the European Union's relationship with the United States cannot be ignored. We have to think about the whole what we lose and what we win. I trust the Commissioner and I believe that, for a limited term, we must open negotiations. Only those battles that you never start are lost, said a great writer from my country, Mircea Eliade. Commissioner, you have to take into account what has been said here. We need conformity assessment, we need product standards that are recognised, we need not to be unilaterally charged to certain product groups, and I very much believe that you can carry this task and report to us what is happening with this market. Because we can't with Russia not to have, with Turkey we don't have, with China we don't have, with the United States of America we don't have! How to develop the single market? I wish you success and hope to pass this negotiating mandate.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Madam President, Commissioner Malmstrom, I still dream of a Europe where we put coherence between our social, agricultural, development, trade and environmental policies. Commissioner, explain to us the value of increasing imports of American soybeans, under the Blair House agreements of 1992, on the European continent, rather than increasing the production of agricultural and vegetable proteins at European level. Tell us about the value of continuing to sacrifice agriculture, which is the adjustment variable for all other policies, in the free trade agreements you enact. The massive importation of soybeans was already in contravening the Kyoto Protocol, and it contravened the Paris Agreements. Commissioner, you who come from the beautiful country of Greta Thunberg, are you going to stop pretending to listen? Will you finally bring trade policy into line with the necessary fight against global warming, which is becoming an emergency?

name: Maria ARENA
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I really have the impression that everything is in the mill of the European Commission when it comes to liberalising trade. Your arguments, in general, are arguments that can be heard, for example: we make agreements with countries that are friendly countries, with countries that share our values and share our rules. But, tell me, how do Mr. Trump and his administration share our values? Our climate values? He decided to leave the negotiations and the negotiating table of COP21. International trade values? Mr. Trump has decided not to abide by WTO rules. You who are the defender of WTO rules, why do you want to sit around the table with the Trump administration when that same government is not following the rules that you think should be respected? I therefore ask you to quote a single argument that would suggest that you would be able to change the current policy of the Trump administration, a policy that does not respect Europe. I do not believe that, and I do not think it would be appropriate today for the Council to authorize the mandate you are proposing.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the agreement that President Juncker made in July with President Trump was to try, despite our disagreement in several areas, to find ways in which we could cooperate. We talked about liquefied natural gas (LNG). There is a desire for many European countries to buy American LNG instead of LNG from other important partners and the Americans agreed to facilitate that. That is a decision to be taken by every Member State and their companies. Of course, it is not the Commission buying gas. The increase of soya beans is also a result of markets. The Commission is not buying soya beans and stocking them in the Berlaymont building. This is market policy because it has changed quite considerably. We agreed to accept the American sustainability scheme in full compliance with the directive. We also agreed that we would cooperate to reform the World Trade Organisation (WTO). We have disagreements there as well, but we also have a process where we work with the Americans and the Japanese to try to write new WTO rules in order to counter some of the state capitalism from China, for instance. That work is ongoing. We also agreed that we would cooperate on some regulatory matters in full transparency, voluntarily, with full respect for our respective protective systems. We agreed that we would seek negotiations on two limited – but still important – agreements. One on the conformity assessment – and I haven’t heard anybody question that here today – and the other one would be on a limited agreement, a tariff on industrial goods. This is what we are asking you to give your opinion on here. In the proposed mandates, there are clear conditions. We could not conclude anything if the tariffs on steel and aluminium were not lifted before we try to conclude. There would be no additional tariffs under 232, for instance, on cars. In the course of these negotiations, we will also do an external study on an impact assessment on sustainability. We will – and we have already started to – consult with civil society. It is crystal clear in this mandate – and by accepting it, you would make it even clearer in writing – that agriculture is not included in the negotiations. It is a limited agreement that we are asking for on industrial goods, including fisheries and cars. That would make it WTO compatible and the sums are not negligible for the European Union either, so we are not giving anything away. It is not, however, a full free trade agreement. It is not taking TTIP out of the freezer. TTIP is really far down in the freezer. For different reasons, it was not possible to advance under the Obama administration and it is not possible in any foreseeable future to advance now either and, of course (you too have mentioned it), also because the US have withdrawn from the Paris Agreement. As I said, there are several disagreements with the Trump administration, but the US – the US people, the US elected assemblies, the US nation – is a friend of the European Union and we have every interest to try to find areas where we can cooperate, where we can talk, and where we can have a dialogue. This is the unanimous will of the European Council as well. That’s why we are asking you to agree on these two negotiating mandates. The Council is ready and I hope that you too can vote in favour tomorrow.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Thank you very much, Commissioner. Mr Etheridge, I must tell you that I was not able to give you the floor again, because you already had a blue card and the reasons for the time have meant that I could not accept your speech again. A motion for a resolution has been tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday, 14 March 2019.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the joint debate on the report by Tom Vandenkendelaere on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the subject "European Semester for economic policy coordination: Annual Growth Survey 2019" (2018/2119(INI)) (A8-0159/201) 9) and – the report by Marian Harkin on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs on "European Semester for economic policy coordination: employment and social aspects in the 2019 Annual Growth Survey" (2018/2120(INI)) (A8-0162/2019).

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, discussions on the European Semester are always very politically charged. As the elections approach, they may become even more political. Indeed, the questions we have to ask ourselves in the context of the Semester are precisely those questions that make us confess political colour: "What is the state of our economy?", "What are the big challenges?", "What priorities do we put first?" and above all "How do we ensure that we can pass on the welfare states we have to our children?". Ladies and gentlemen, some of you will want to push for more investment. Others of you will ask for more budgetary discipline. Still others will propose to make the reins more celebrated. As a true Christian Democrat, I am already starting the debate. I think the best course is a sensible combination of all these options. There is no message about half-truths and easy solutions today. It is important that we tell the full story to them and to our children. As it happens, my two-year-old son is here to visit today and tomorrow. It's also for him that I'm standing here today. I want to make sure that in the future it is that welfare state that can protect him and his loved ones, even when things get tough, and if he gets sick, heal, and guarantee a fair pension, when he can re-end his life that he has built. It is that future, this great story, that legacy of decades of building the prosperity and well-being of our citizens, that is at stake. After all, ageing is one of the most important demographic developments of the 21st century. In itself, there has been tremendous progress, but it is accompanied by enormous challenges. Firstly, the cost of pensions, health care and care for the elderly will increase enormously in the coming decades and this is going to put enormous pressure on our coffers. Secondly, the ageing population is also causing proportionally fewer people to work and therefore fewer people being able to help finance all these costs. That puts our coffers under pressure a second time. So it is time to intervene, and I believe that on three fronts at once. We need to invest, and structurally reform, and get our budgets in order. Firstly, – I think it really starts there – a healthy treasury. We need to build fiscal buffers to protect ourselves from the rising costs of ageing. More older people automatically means more pensions, more health care costs and more costs for elderly care. We really need to prepare for this. If not, we'll turn the whole bill on to the next generation. Secondly, it is important to implement structural reforms that will reduce the costs of an ageing society, and thereby putting the proportionally smaller group to work as much as possible at working age. Employers need to be able to hire and fire employees more quickly. Employees should be able to switch between different forms of work more easily. My parents are still from the generation in which they worked for the same employer all their lives. That model is already under pressure. We're seeing that today. And our children, I think, will simply not know that model anymore. Politics must therefore create a framework to make that transition easier. To make employees more flexible and resilient, constant training, retraining and lifelong learning will have to become the new standard, whether we like it or not. Finally, if we really want to tackle the ageing population on this European continent, then investment in the future is crucial, not only in human capital, as I have correctly indicated, but also in future productivity, to ensure our economic growth. We need investment in research and development, in innovation and digitisation, in infrastructure projects. Wise investing today means harvesting tomorrow. That is the path we need to chart with the European Semester. A socio-economic compass that ensures that we do not get off the path and that offers a real guarantee of a sustainable future.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, first of all, can I thank the shadow rapporteurs for their good cooperation, which I believe has led to a balanced report. There are a few amendments submitted and I think that, with the exception of one, I can support all of them. They don’t significantly change the content or the tone of the report, but they do improve it. So, first of all, can I say how important it is for the Employment Committee to have its own separate report on the Annual Growth Survey, because we have a different perspective to that of the Economic Committee. They are complementary, but they have a different emphasis, and this report, as well as the previous two reports from the Employment Committee, I believe contribute to rebalancing the importance of the social and economic issues. The economy must work for society. It must contribute to social cohesion, social inclusion and decent jobs. It must be the springboard from which individuals and families can plan their future with confidence. Many of the headline figures for the EU are positive, and I want to list some of them because they are important: the EU economy continues to expand, providing a record number of jobs for people; we are making progress on the social scoreboard; household incomes continue to rise in most Member States; the share of people at risk of poverty and social exclusion decreased up to 2017; and there are more women in the workforce. All of this is positive, yet there are very significant challenges that persist. For me, one of the major challenges is that household incomes have grown more slowly than GDP, from something like 10.9% to 15.5% over a period of 12 years. This clearly indicates to me that much of our growth is not fully inclusive. This is a key issue for citizens and for the EU as a whole and I believe it will play a role in ensuring the cohesion, and therefore the future, of the EU. Youth unemployment averages at 18.6% across the EU, which is unacceptably high. While the youth guarantee has certainly helped, the issue as regards resources is that it is woefully underfunded. Precarious work is a huge challenge, given that workers are unable to enforce their rights, with no social security and work in security as a major issue. That’s one of the reasons why I will be supporting the amendment calling for the banning of zero hour contracts. We have challenges around increasing life expectancy, with 80% of the care in the EU being provided by informal family carers, 75% of whom are women. Yes, we have our Directive on Work-Life Balance, but unfortunately on the aspect of carers’ leave, that part of the Directive is weak and allows Member States to choose not to make a real choice for carers. We have stated clearly in the resolution that the EU’s social goals and commitments are just as important as its economic goals and are not just a means of guaranteeing economic growth, but must be a specific target in themselves. This perspective underpins our approach to all the proposals in this report on the Annual Growth Survey. This report sends a strong message to citizens that we in the Parliament recognise the essential need to ensure that our citizens can look to the future with confidence. And once again, thank you to all who have contributed to this report.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, thank you for the opportunity to discuss the European semester today, a topic of particular relevance in these times. The Council attaches great importance to the semester and I’m pleased to exchange views with Parliament on the subject. If we are all to make Europe relevant to people’s daily lives, we need to deliver on growth and jobs, high-quality education, social protection and inclusion, as well as environmental sustainability. We should stress here that it is a question of ownership for the Member States. By streamlining reforms, the European semester aims to improve the situation in each Member State and in the EU as a whole. An agreement on common objectives is therefore important. Your report shows that we recognise these common objectives. I’m glad we have this opportunity to discuss them with you today, and that you have also discussed them recently with national parliaments. To start on a positive note, evidence suggests that Europe’s economy is strengthening. Employment is growing. Investment is recovering and public finances are improving. Yet, clearly, many challenges remain. You have identified a number of them in your report. Long-term challenges remain, such as population ageing, digitalisation and its impact on work, climate change and unsustainable use of natural resources. Boosting investment remains a priority in order to promote a more robust recovery and to secure a healthy growth rate in the long run. The extension of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, in terms of financial capacity, is an important step towards achieving this goal. Let us continue to work together to spur social investment and human capital, to lift the remaining barriers and to foster a truly favourable investment climate. Furthermore, we need to support growth with smart fiscal policies, while paying close attention to the long-term sustainability of our budgets and debts. We also need to implement the necessary structural reforms in our product and labour markets in order to prepare our economies for the challenges ahead. We must provide our young citizens with high quality education and invest in their skills today. Madam President, honourable Members, as we are now leaving crisis times behind us, the legacy of the crisis remains a serious concern. Some citizens are trapped in a cycle of poverty and social exclusion, which they cannot easily escape from. This is an important issue for the Romanian Presidency. Our policy efforts need to be oriented towards the most vulnerable categories of our citizens. They also need to be oriented towards those regions and sectors that are undergoing the greatest difficulties.
