We need to think of new solutions to new problems whilst seizing the opportunities ahead of us. The collaborative economy represents a huge potential, but it cannot be a reason to backtrack on employment and social rights. Employment and social policies need to adapt to the changes in the labour market, whilst workers rights should remain protected. Environment policy, together with greening the economy and greening the European semester, can contribute in a very significant manner to the broad policy objective of stimulating sustainable growth and creating jobs. What is key is to focus on the full implementation of the reforms and carefully to monitor the progress in each Member State. We should share our experiences and use best practice examples to learn from each other. Only by working together closely, to push consistently for reforms and to keep supporting inclusive growth and job creation, will we be successful in creating tangible benefits for every citizen and in rebuilding trust in a strong and prosperous European Union. Thank you very much for your attention and for the contribution of the European Parliament, in particular the rapporteurs, on this important topic. (Applause)

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, Europe is set to grow for a seventh year in a row. Employment figures stay at record highs and unemployment at record lows. The average levels of both budget deficit and public debt continue to go down. Our strategy based on three priorities, investment, structural reforms and fiscal responsibility, is working. Yet growth is moderating and risks are mounting. We face trade tensions and a slowdown in emerging economies. Concerns about banks, sovereign loans and debt sustainability are resurfacing in some countries. Amongst homemade reasons for the slowdown, we also see stalling reform momentum in some Member States. Some countries still have high unemployment, while others face skills shortages. Unresolved structural issues continue to hamper productivity and investment. There are still high levels of inequality within and among EU Member States. Long-term challenges, such as population ageing, remain pressing. Rapid technological change and digitalisation are changing our daily lives and the world of work. That is why decisive action is needed. At national level, we need well-targeted investments and reforms to increase productivity and to foster inclusive growth. Good times must be used to reduce high debt and rebuild fiscal buffers. This, unfortunately, is not happening in some Member States. At EU level we have made progress on the banking union and the European Stability Mechanism (ESM) reform, but some proposals, on the capital markets union, for example, still await adaptations. At the Eurogroup meeting earlier this week we continued discussions on how to support reforms and investments for the sake of competitiveness and convergence. The Commission is open to amending our proposal on the reform support programme to serve this purpose.  We have just issued our assessment of the economic and social challenges in all Member States and, where relevant, of macroeconomic imbalances. We also identified priority areas for investment, providing a basis for a new programming of cohesion funds. Regarding macroeconomic imbalances our conclusion is that Bulgaria, Germany, Spain, France, Croatia, Ireland, the Netherlands, Portugal, Romania and Sweden experienced imbalances and Cyprus, Greece and Italy experienced excessive imbalances. For Croatia, this is an improvement. We found this year that Croatia still has imbalances, but they are no longer excessive. So this is good news, including with regard to preparations for participation in the Exchange Rate Mechanism (ERM) II and eventually for euro area membership.  We also found imbalances in the case of Romania. This was not the case last year. The reasons are competitiveness losses, widening current account deficits and pro-cyclical expansionary fiscal policy. We remain concerned about Italy’s public debt ratio, which is not set to decline, and reform momentum has stalled. In spring we will once again assess Italy’s policy steps and the commitments to address imbalances, as well as the level of ambition of the national reform programme. Overall, since 2011, Member States have made at least some progress on two-thirds of the recommendations but, as I said before, momentum has been slowing. To regain this momentum, Member States can count on our structural reform support service that has been providing support for 500 reform projects in 25 countries, with a further 260 projects to be financed this year. To conclude, our focused approach has helped us to steer the recovery and it must serve to keep us on the path of sustainable and inclusive growth. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Vandenkendelaere, and the shadow rapporteurs, for the report and I am looking forward to a constructive debate.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank both rapporteurs, Ms Harkin and Mr Vandenkendelaere, for the two reports on the Annual Growth Survey. The positive economic developments continue to translate into sustained job creation. Two hundred and forty million people have a job in the European Union and this is the highest number ever. Unemployment is at 6.5% and this is now the lowest it has ever been in this century. The number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion is dropping and now, for the first time, it is below the level of what we recorded in 2008. However (there is also a ‘however’), we must not forget that growth in Europe is not benefiting all citizens in the same way, as the rapporteur of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs told us. Real household income is still below the 2008 level in some countries. There is still very high youth unemployment in some areas or a high level of poverty, including high in-work poverty in some Member States. This is why your report, Ms Harkin, strongly resonates with our analysis. We take note of your calls to do more on skills, in-work poverty, regulation of new forms of work, labour market inclusion of people with disabilities, work-life balance and housing.  Since the publication of the Annual Growth Survey last autumn, we have published the country reports on 27 February and those provide a more detailed analysis of the economic and social situation in the Member States. For the second year now, we look at the implementation of the European Pillar of Social Rights. The country reports provide an idea of where we stand and of the challenges ahead and they assess policy response by Member State.  We also look at the social scoreboard. This year, we see progress on all 14 indicators of the social scoreboard. Moreover, for the first time, the country reports reflect on the investment needs in each Member State and also, more specifically, as regards European funds. Our aim is to achieve greater synergies and complementarity between the economic policies, reforms and the cohesion policy funds, and I am confident that the combined efforts of European legislation, coordination of economic policies and European funds will help to make the European Pillar of Social Rights a reality for all citizens.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. – Madam President, the Economy of the European Union is entering its sixth year of growth as a result of structural reforms, investment and responsible fiscal policies. These good economic conditions are an opportunity to turn our attention to creating prerequisites for lasting economic growth that is socially just and environmentally sustainable. We have a responsibility to future generations not only not to burden them with debt, but also not to jeopardize their ability to meet their needs. The big challenges ahead remain. An ageing population or unsustainable use of natural resources are risk factors for our long-term economic development potential. The Environment Committee believes that an environmentally friendly economy and investment in more efficient health systems are key to the well-being of European citizens. The Recommendations under the European Semester are a good tool to promote the necessary structural reforms in this direction. A longer-term perspective needs to be taken when monitoring and evaluating reforms, because results are often given in a few years. We support the allocation of funds in the next programming period to support Member States in implementing structural reform recommendations.

name: Iskra MIHAYLOVA
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. – Madam President, Commissioner, Commissioner, Honourable Colleagues, the Committee on Regional Development in its opinion welcomes the positive dynamics of economic growth and investment, but is concerned that their impact on productivity and jobs is not sufficient. And therefore a better focus on cohesion policy investments and complementing them with other Union programmes, as well as public and private investment, is needed. The Commission and the Member States need to step up their cooperation and take further measures to attract private and public investment, build partnerships and cohesion in order to complement the European Union funds and instruments. We welcome the proposals for the next Multiannual Financial Framework and the close link between the European Semester and future Structural Investment Funds. In conclusion, I would like to highlight the role of the Structural Reform Support Programme providing tailored assistance to help Member States carry out their structural reforms.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: draftser of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. – Madam President, if we are to address the challenges and challenges of the European Union, we must understand that the European Semester needs to cease to be an instrument that tells countries where they have to spend more or less, where they have to save or cut and truly become an element of European policy to ensure economic sustainability , social and environmental.  And for that we also need to be able to hear outside these four walls and understand that we need to understand that people are tired of austerity policy. Let us listen to the millions of women and men who took to the streets of Europe last Friday 8 March to call for a fairer, more social and more egalitarian Europe; let's listen to the young people coming out next Friday calling for a Europe that is capable of committing to the fight against climate change. If we really want to regain the trust of the public in the European project, we must move from austerity policy to fair and equal growth policy for all.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: draftser of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. – Madam President, it is 13 March, five days after 8 March, when millions of European women took to the streets again to claim their rights. We are discussing the European Union's growth and economic prospects in the context of the European Semester debate and the issue is totally absent.  I have not heard practically from the Commissioners' mouths to refer at all to this, nor to the Council either, and in the report on the Annual Growth Perspective Study the words 'gender equality' appear once, simply to mention in the past the pension gap.  Look, I only have one plea in today's debate: this cannot go on like this in the next term. Frankly, that we have every six months an analysis of economic policy, country recommendations, and that we do not analyze the gender impact of any of the structural reforms we make, nor look at how we can reduce the pay gap and the pension gap or move towards an equal society becomes unbearable.  So, for the next term, frankly, I hope this changes from top to bottom.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. First of all, As shadow rapporteur for the report, Marian Harkin, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the excellent, balanced and socially sensitive report and for the excellent style in which she negotiated this document.  The report cites data and figures which confirm that the labour market situation is stabilising and improving. 2018 is the seventh consecutive year of economic growth in the European Union. Unemployment is falling, new jobs are rising, key economic indicators are positive, satisfactory. However, as we point out, this prosperity does not apply to all Citizens of the Union. The group of people who are poor and at risk of poverty still number more than one hundred million. We also have a group of NEETs who are not working, not learning, not educating. It is still more than 6 million people. There is also a pension gap between men and women of almost 40% and a work-home imbalance. These issues continue to pose challenges.  Finally, the European Union is in the process of digital transformation, which is the basis for our future and competitiveness in the world. Meanwhile, the labour shortage in key sectors for the future is in the hundreds of thousands, and 40% of european citizens do not have basic digital skills. We need an immediate response from the education system to the challenges of industry 4.0 and a multicultural, green and mobile Europe to ensure the sustainable and sustainable development of our economy.

name: Maria ARENA
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D - Madam President, the annual growth review is part of the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordinations of the Union. You know that in our eyes, socialists and democrats, this semester is too focused on purely economic and budgetary issues and not enough on social issues. Indeed, what is the point of creating jobs if they are poorly paid and poorly protected, such as zero-hours contracts? What is the point of having a balanced budget, which forbids investing in the future, in education, in training, but also in the ecological transition? What is the point of growing if it generates inequalities that are increasingly present in Europe today? Is it not true that social and cultural inequalities are the main danger of democracy? We are living it today in many European countries. In the proposal before us today, these social concerns have been heard and supported in the context of the Committee on Employment. I will mention a few: better access to education and training; The importance of decent wages and collective bargaining; reforms that do not undermine solidarity and redistribution of wealth, and finally investments in the ecological transition. I come to an amendment that the EPP wants to table at the time of the vote, which concerns pensions. According to the EPP, the only way to have decent pensions is to have private pensions. I would like to say to the EPP that private pensions are the main obstacle to equality between men and women. Women today do not benefit from the pillars of private pensions. To claim, therefore, that the problem of pensions will be solved by private pensions is to reinforce inequality towards women within Europe. We will oppose this amendment because there are other solutions to deal with pensions.

name: Ralph PACKET
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Thank you, Chairman. Thank you, Tom Vandenkendelaere, rapporteur, for your interesting report. We remember each other from when we were youth president, Tom from his party and I from mine. Even then, we were working on whether people of our generation will ever get a pension again. Many young people no longer believe in the social contract as we know it and as we need it. Today's pensions are paid by the active, working people. However, due to an ageing population, we have less and less income for more and more expenditure. In Belgium, these costs will amount to more than 15 billion. This report is about that. What measures we need to take to ensure that the younger, working generations are not squeezed out now and then left without a pension later. Reforms are urgently needed, because the current situation cannot be sustained. If we go on like this, then everyone will eventually have to make sure of their own thirst, if they want to face their old age with peace of mind.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: au nom du groupe ALDE. – Madam President, Madame Thyssen, merci coming nous écouter. Je vais'tre tr's bref et vous exposer une vision politique. In spagnol, aprs vous avoir salué. Firstly, we must recognise that this mandate has finally focused on society, on the social exit from the crisis and, in particular, on the European Social and Employment Semester. That has to be used much more in the following command. Secondly, employment is said to be better than ever, and it is true, but, keep an eye on the idea that, when there is a major unemployment pool in a nation, it is a European problem. The distribution of unemployment is also a European problem. Another thing, inequalities. There's a lot or all to do. Even if a crisis now comes, upcoming economic and social policies cannot fail to take priority to combat the growth of inequalities. And finally, two essential things for the future, to achieve a social Europe. Firstly, we will have to have a concerted fiscal economic policy, and that will allow for redistribution at European level. Secondly, it must be admitted that European financial solidarity will be needed, for example in unemployment and anti-unemployment aid at European level.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would also like to thank our rapporteur from the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs for the very good work that she did on this report, and I welcome the growing attention that we’re now seeing being given in the semester process to climate change. The report recalls the need to modernise and decarbonise our industry, our transport, our energy sectors and, as we just heard from the Council, environmental sustainability matters. If we fail to respond properly, we’re going to see our economy and our societies pay an ever-increasing cost, as we struggle to deal with the development and effects of extreme climate events. If we think of the costs over the last year of forest fires, floods, storms, et cetera, and what that has taken out of the public budget and our public services, the need to invest in resilient infrastructure and good strong public services and utilities is absolutely crucial. For that, we need the fiscal space to be able to carry out real investment.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, we have missed one opportunity, one more. European citizens do not want to continue to hear that the same policies that have led us to the critical situation in which we find ourselves must remain the benchmark for the coming years.  Austerity has been a mistake and a failure. Policies to manage the economic crisis have led us to the greatest increase in inequality in Europe since the end of World War II.  The euro has become a machine of creating economic and social divergence between our countries and, as a result of this perfect storm, the anger of a part of the public and a deaf unrest that threatens not only the European institutions but democracy itself has increased significantly and critically.  And, in the face of evidence of this situation, our reports continue to tell millions of impoverished, excluded and frightened people that everything is going well. This is not possible, unreasonable, and it seems that the lack of interest in continuing to believe in this story is evident.  News like the so-called "Google Rate" confirms what millions of people have found: not everyone is treated in the same way. Some countries of the Union show an unmisericoal harshness with workers and deplorable servitude to multinationals and economic elites. This, of course, is not the way.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Mr President, with every policy problem – and we have no shortage of them – the EU has only one roadmap. The powers must go to Brussels and the regulations must be more detailed and compelling. This picture is confirmed by this report on the European Semester for Coordination and Economic Policy, at a time when the whole socio-economic area seems to be heading to Brussels. The problems described in the report also show that the introduction of the single currency, the euro, has led to lower economic growth and higher unemployment than outside the euro area. The eurozone is doing worse than the other Member States, including the United Kingdom. The solution to this problem is therefore very simple. Simply say goodbye to the euro and, with it, the system of a centrally driven economy. However, such a simple solution eludes Brussels and also seems a little counterrevolutionary. It is felt that, now that the central control is failing, more central guidance is needed from Brussels. For example, by setting up a European investment programme for jobs and growth, but on condition of all kinds of social goals, such as sustainability and inclusiveness and climate-shuddling behaviour. All this to prevent actual growth.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support For the average European citizen, the term European Semester says nothing. I will try to define: the EU's definition of the main figures in the Member States' budgets. Member States shall submit their own stability and convergence programmes in April each year. Subsequently, in its opinion, the Council invites governments to adapt their programmes, to incorporate country-specific recommendations, to monitor them and then to monitor the implementation of the programmes. In practice, therefore, in the framework of the European Semester, the main figures of the country's budget are determined, so that national parliaments can only make detailed decisions within this framework, and this is already a question of self-determination. The substance of the budget is taken away from sovereign parliaments. The introduction of this was a step towards creating a supranational superstate.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, the winter package for the European semester has been sobering in many places. The key message was that growth will slow significantly in the coming months. The economy is weakening, the extent of the expected slowdown and its impact on the European economy will depend on our actions: on the one hand, our political action in recent years, in which we have benefited from a very pleasing economic development, but also on our political action in the coming months.  If I look more closely at the country reports, I get the impression that many Member States are not sufficiently prepared for a weakening economy. The fat years were not used. France has been on the border of the EDP for years, and the country report on Italy is a document of failure. This very worrying finding once again raises the question of why the Commission is not more vehemently enforcing the implementation of the country-specific recommendations and compliance with the fiscal rules. We see the same pattern over and over again: the country reports are disastrous, the recommendations are not implemented and the fiscal rules of the game are ignored. If we start in this way into an economically more difficult time, and also, as has been suggested since yesterday, with an unregulated Brexit, which will cost us economic performance again, then we do indeed have a problem. If the Commission is not prepared to ensure implementation here, consideration should also be given to entrusting other institutions.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the discussion in this Parliament on the economic and budgetary policy guidelines is always an important moment in the so-called European Semester, but it is even more so in the current context of the enormous risks and uncertainties and the slowdown in economic growth.  The final version of the report that we are voting on this afternoon is fortunately quite different from the initial version. Many of the proposals put forward by my group have been welcomed, and i am therefore pleased to say that the final version of this report will have a favourable vote from the Socialist group. I therefore thank the rapporteur, our colleague Tom Vandenkendelaere, for the excellent cooperation we have had and which has made this good result possible.  The main message of this Parliament is that European economic and budgetary policy needs to take a step forward to respond to the slowdown in the economy. We need concerted action for more sustainable and more inclusive growth, we need to overcome the public and private investment gap and we need to ensure that Member States with budget surpluses do more for the growth of the European economy by increasing wages and investment. Responsibility in the management of public accounts is of course still necessary, but it must be compatible with investment for job creation, with combating inequalities, with promoting convergence, with social inclusion, with energy transition, with combating climate change, with sustainable development goals.  This is another view on investment policies and the idea of structural reforms that we need to make the European pillar of social rights effective. These are the key parts of the economic and budgetary strategy that Europe needs and so we will vote in favour of this report.

name: Czesław HOC
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Europe is currently experiencing a period of good economic prosperity, but threats and new challenges are emerging from everywhere. The good times will not last forever. Many challenges already need to be met, namely constant globalisation, 4.0 technology, including digitalisation, changes in the labour market model and demographic trends. We need to invest heavily now to sustain this economic recovery and provide benefits for everyone, including future generations. It is therefore necessary to effectively combat youth unemployment in the Union, to improve the fate of NEETs, to invest in skills, to eliminate social and social inequalities, to invest in dual education combining science and training, perhaps also in job sharing, i.e. shared work, etc.  It is worth pointing out that the European Commission's report, as part of the alert and detection mechanism for macroeconomic imbalances, identifies 11 Member States that will be subject to a detailed assessment in 2019. Polish are not among them, because the Polish economy is strong. Kaczynski's current, new so-called five strengthens the economic development Polish and promotes its further development in the proverbial fifth heat.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, if you have a foot in a freezer, in absolute cold, at minus 273oC, and if you have the other foot in an oven at 300oC, the temperature is good, you are at 27 degrees, but you are dying, you will soon die of a heart attack. This is what is happening for Europe and the disparities between the North and the South. It took Spain eight years to return to growth and its previous level of domestic production. Italy has yet to find him. France regained it in 2013 thanks to a deficit of which it lost control. We are in a situation where the comparative advantage means that the European Monetary Union will only function if an investment agency is set up, in order to invest heavily in the countries of the South. Otherwise, the future with the euro is in jeopardy.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Madam President, in Greece the disproves of the SYRIZA fairy tales are in return. He was celebrating raising crumbs on the minimum wage by abolishing collective bargaining agreements. Extortion of workers to accept full-time part-time work and redundancies have increased. Supermarkets are calling on employees to bless the boss because they get 300 euros rather than zero. He was celebrating not cutting pensions for the 23rd time. As a member of Parliament's economic committee, I asked the President of the Eurogroup, Mr Centeno: Will the surpluses be cut again if the surpluses are not caught? Answer clear: silence. The European Semester reveals why: the committee is here and full of unpopular measures. The Union's main objective is the dismantling of public social security, citing an ageing population, removing state funds from insurance funds, leading them to large enterprises. Competitiveness, that is, with handout pensions, work to the death with active ageing for anyone with private insurance. Her reserves? Free of business through stock exchanges. The European Union with neoliberal far-right or pseudo-progressing fronts like SYRIZA only gets worse and becomes more dangerous for the people.

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, representative of the Council, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work and for the work she has done on this For the time being, I would like to thank my esteemed colleague Marian Harkin from the Social Committee and also in the Working Group on Carers for their important report, but also the Commission, because the Commission is doing an annual job here, providing an excellent tool for the reform needs of the EU Member States. The fact is, however, that many Member States are not fulfilling their responsibilities and are making little or far too little effort to overcome the clearly identified problem areas and, most often, urgent challenges with concrete reform measures, especially when it comes to ensuring the sustainable financial viability of social systems. I think that, in future, the Commission should have a tougher instrument to warn, to remind and also to take much tougher sanctions, especially where voter gifts are causing the budgets to be thrown into disarray by non-reform of structures and even mismanagement, the stability of the countries is being affected and not only smaller, financially weaker countries belong, but also large states in the south and west of Europe. Now there is a need for reform!

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab It is difficult to disagree with the many diagnoses and recommendations made in the text of the report. I find it particularly valuable to point out that future investment programmes should serve SMEs more and that the distribution of EU funds must take better account of geographical balance and the specificities of the region. On the other hand, there are concerns about the non-reflective emphasis on the role of the Stability and Growth Pact. I would remind you that the ECA only six months ago pointed out the systemic flaws of this document, which the European Commission has applied selectively to many EU countries. There are more such inconsistencies in the text of this document and I will recommend that my delegation abstain.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – Madam President, we, as a community, have, of course, made progress, yet the situation is very different from country to country. The recipe for success is to maintain good fitness on the side of the economy, which, of course, can only be achieved through a very thoughtful investment and tax policy. It is important that these guidelines are followed by the Member States and that they also provide for urgently needed social reforms. At European Union level, we should also pay more attention to demographic change and to ensuring a family-friendly environment. In doing so, I regret that housing policy is not one of the European Commission's priorities. Housing affordability, especially for young families, is very poor in some countries. European families are the foundation of development and our society. However, the number of births in the European Union is declining and quite a few Member States have not yet taken the necessary measures in this area, despite the fact that our future depends on the next generations. I therefore propose that we pay more attention to this.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Madam President, I very much share the opinions of other colleagues that have been expressed here during this debate, that the Union faces new challenges. We have an economic slowdown on the horizon. We have an unpredictable Brexit ahead of us, we have trade wars and their implications. We have to be prepared to face these challenges. Now, most of the postulates here have been addressed to the Commission, but I think that the main responsibility is on the Member States. I mean, issues such as the reform of the labour market, attempts to encourage people to work longer, increase capacity in research and development, in education, and also to work in favour of improving the situation of our banks, especially in some states. These are all responsibilities of Member States, so I would encourage the Commission, and personally Commissioner Dombrovskis, simply to address this issue in the country specific recommendations. We have to indeed be very ambitious in this regard.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: In the spontaneous speeches that follow, I will only be able to give the floor to one person per registered group because of the lateness of the time.  Spontaneous speeches

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: – Madam Chairman, triangle: investments, structural reforms and smart management of public finances, is in theory completely clear. Of course, implementation needs further work, which is why we are trying to strengthen the reform support programme in the new budget, triple the European Fund for Strategic Investments, increase investment in digitalisation and strengthen the single market, remove barriers and create an Equal Opportunities Union. Of course, I support all this, but I oppose the Commission's proposals that the main criterion for the allocation of these increased funds is the population. By this distribution, we lose sight of the basic objective - to reduce differences in the development of Member States. In addition to the ageing population, we need to further help less developed Member States, which are most often and most affected by demographic challenges, which, along with an ageing population, also benefit from large-level emigration, not reduce the ESI Funds or allocations from structural reform support programmes.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, promoting investment, responsible budgetary policies and well-thought-out reforms are the priorities pointed out by the Commission, which a few weeks ago published its annual assessment of the economic and social situation in the Member States as part of the European Semester winter package. The Commission paints a not rosy picture for Italy and criticises the effects of the measures contained in the Conte Government's manoeuvre, considered a step backwards compared to the previous ones: excessive imbalances in the economic framework, high public debt, not intended to decrease, weak productivity, growing gap between North and South, employment rate among the lowest at European level, very high youth unemployment and the risk of contagion to other Member States.  From an economic point of view, the situation in Italy has clearly deteriorated. It is clear that Italy (but also other countries) needs a change of course and that public accounts must be improved and reforms made. I believe, however, that the European Commission must have a greater impact on those countries that are showing that they are not up to their responsibilities.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the European Semester is a system through which the European Union, especially the Council and the Commission, interfere in the exclusive competences of the Member States, because economic policy has nothing to do with the competences of the European Union. It is the responsibility of the Member States. And through the European Semester system, what is being done is that Brussels, in essence, dictates its own economic policy to the Member States. In this way they continue the policy of austerity and violent fiscal adjustment. Does the European Union have any competence over pension systems? No. And yet, with the directions it gives, it forms a climate. And if there are governments that may be reacting, then they're on the black list of markets. It is therefore a way in which Brussels intervenes at the expense of the sovereign rights of the Member States. It is a good thing that Brussels should exercise its own exclusive powers and let the other issues be exercised by the Member States, both on wage policy and on pension policy.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Madam President, we hear about high youth unemployment and wages not rising quickly enough, yet would that not potentially be one effect of there being a large supply of labour – supply and demand? A lot of people have entered the EU, many of them looking for work. Obviously, that makes it harder for the people already there. We hear about slow economic growth, but you say that your social aims and social policies are just as important as the growth policies. Well, if you take that approach then of course you’re going to slow down economic growth. Of course you are.  May I suggest that the best way to raise living standards, to get more tax dollars coming in so you can spend them on really nice things, good things, nice projects, is to grow the economy with serious economic policies. Nobody would have heard of the Good Samaritan if he’d been poor.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you very much for this debate. We are now continuing as a dialogue with Member States and seek a common understanding of the challenges and policy actions to address them. We expect national reform programmes and stability or convergence programmes by mid-April and, as always, the Commission strongly encourages the close involvement of national parliaments, local authorities and social partners in the preparation of national reform programmes. Based on this, we will present our country’s specific recommendations in a Spring European Semester cycle, so I’m looking forward to continued, constructive dialogue with you in the coming months.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members and the Commissioners for their remarks. They addressed important points and their remarks will provide valuable input for the discussions in the Council that touch upon many aspects of the European Semester, such as the environment, competitiveness and social policies. The country reports published by the Commission in February represent an important step in the current process. They form the basis for the work which will eventually lead to the adoption of the Semester’s country-specific recommendations during the Semester. When working on the European Semester and debating the country-specific recommendations, we should always remember the importance of reaching as many citizens as possible to increase national ownership. I commend the initiatives taken in this regard, including the increased dialogue in the capitals and the consultation with social partners. Today’s debate showed that, while there are some differences, there is a lot of common ground to build on. This gives me confidence in our continued cooperation in looking at the challenges ahead of us and identifying appropriate solutions to tackle them. Thank you very much once again for your attention.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: Rapporteur. Thank you, Madam President. Thank you also, all colleagues, for the comments. The Semester always opens the door to very political debates, but also very interesting debates. We always come to a consensus on exactly what our economy is like, about what the challenges are. These have all been reviewed here tonight. Rightly so! Gender equality, climate, poverty, health care, growing inequality, and I myself have talked about ageing. Whatever priority you have to tackle the first, with only investment or purely budgetary discipline, it will really not succeed. No way. We will have to work on both investments and reforms and budgetary discipline. They are certainly not always easy to reconcile. We also heard that during the debate this evening. It is, however, about time to dare to say what the European Semester programme really is, which is an opportunity. An opportunity, not an annoying straitjacket, not a test that we have to do, but an opportunity for the Member States to prepare ourselves for the major challenges that lie ahead. In that sense, dear Council, I am really counting on you to take the implementation of these proposals to heart, to see them as a recommendation, not as a punishment that the European Commission isting. An opportunity to tackle ageing. A chance also to pass on to our children the amazing achievements of the 20th century.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, as we know, the AGS is published each year. Therefore it is really important that the country specific recommendations are sustained from one year to the next. So we ask the Commission for follow—up on that.  I was also encouraged by the words of Commissioner Thyssen, who replied directly to some of the suggestions in my report, especially on the issue of in—work poverty and the regulation of new forms of work. A few colleagues spoke on the issue of pensions. While we fully support universal access to adequate retirement and old age pensions, we also believe that other avenues need to be explored. One of those is to complement statutory pensions with supplementary pensions. Three final points. In light of today’s debate on climate change, and indeed the huge challenge we face on the issue, we have called for budgets to be made available to modernise and decarbonise industry, transport and energy. In the context of social inclusion, we call on the Commission and Member States to step up efforts for greater inclusion of people with disabilities in the workplace.  Finally, we deplore the failure to include housing and homelessness among the top priorities for 2019, and call on the Commission to use this semester to monitor and support progress on housing affordability and homelessness as fundamental areas of concern.  (Applause)

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today, Wednesday, 13 March 2019. (The session is suspended for a few minutes.)

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls Voting Time. (For voting results and other details about them: see minutes)

name: Julia REDA
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I rise in accordance with Rule 59 and would like to ask the Chamber to refer the matter back to committee in order to start interinstitutional negotiations.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very I just wanted to say briefly what this is all about. We are now voting on the fact that the disposal of marine waste in European ports will be improved from now on. It is the case that, until now, we are still allowed to throw some waste into the sea.  This will be banned from now on. There is a 100% waste collection fee that you pay with the port fees, so there is really no incentive to throw anything overboard. This is a decisive improvement for our seas and, at the same time, it is also the case that the fishing boats, which, not because they want it, but because it swims around in the sea, can, for example, fish .B plastic that can be delivered to ports without having to pay for it, and perhaps even receive compensation for it. In other words, this is good for the ports, and that is why I would like to thank all – I am looking at Bas Eickhout – who have worked here, and I look forward to broad support.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I take note of this resolution adopted by the European Parliament. Allow me to affirm that the draft Commission regulation is in line with the procedural steps set out in Council Decision 1999/468/EC on comitology and Regulation No 396/2005 and that it is therefore within the implementing powers conferred on the Commission in this latter regulation. I would also like to remind you that the Standing Committee has given a favourable opinion on the draft act and the Council has already decided not to oppose it. I find it regrettable that Parliament has rejected this measure, which is based on the scientific assessment of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). Such decisions undermine the EU’s well-established, science—based approach to food safety. That is what I wanted to declare in the name of the Commission.

name: Kati PIRI
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank my colleagues for sending a straight signal to the Council calling for the suspension of the accession talks with Turkey, while at the same time also showing solidarity with Turkey’s democrats. This was our final report of the past five years and I would like to thank, too, all the shadow rapporteurs for bringing Parliament together every time on a clear stance. (Applause)

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: This concludes Voting Time.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the report by Esther de Lange and Roberto Gualtier, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 as regards minimum requirements for non-performing liabilities (COM (2018) 0134 - C8-0117 / 2018 - 2018/0060 (COC)) (A8-0440 / 2018).

name: Esther de LANGE
text: Reporter. - (NL) Mr President, I will do my best in the busyness that is still there in this room. I think it is important, ladies and gentlemen, that we have been able to reach an agreement on this difficult and politically very sensitive file. It is an important file because it concerns the stability of our financial markets and the banking sector. Markets and a sector that are still vulnerable. In the EU, do not be alarmed by the amount, banks still have some 820 billion in loans on their balance sheets that are difficult or impossible to collect. These loans are substantial, invisible risks that can cause instability in the financial markets in times of crisis. Moreover, banks that have a lot of these kinds of bad loans on their balance sheet naturally have much less room to actually finance the real economy. That may be just as big a problem. It is also a sensitive file, because this 820 billion is partly made up of mortgages. From loans to citizens, to farmers, and loans to small and medium-sized businesses. Loans that years ago were perhaps provided too easily and regularly with too little information, often through no fault of that citizen or entrepreneur. And it is not about abstract matters or abstract amounts, but it is about someone's home, about your business, and about your existence. And so it was beyond dispute for both co-rapporteurs that this problem had to be tackled urgently, with ambition, but in a responsible manner. And I am convinced that we have succeeded. What do we do? Whereas in the past the ECB had to address banks individually on what to do and tell them to deal with those bad loans, now all banks are legally obliged to build a buffer for bad loans to fully cover these risks. Depending on the type of exposure, this 100% obligation arises after three years for unsecured loans, after seven years for secured loans, or after nine years for loans secured with real estate. And see how we take into account the fact that it concerns houses and mortgages and someone's existence. In addition, the ECB will of course continue to have the option of imposing an additional obligation per bank and accelerating the path where necessary. And I am well aware that this will hurt some banks. But the EPP and the CDA would rather take difficult but important measures now than pass that pain on to the next generation. What I personally think is a shame is that this legislation only applies to new loans, so for the future, while banks, especially in some countries, are still carrying a huge burden from the past. I think those corpses should also come out. So we are not there yet. This Regulation should be complemented by a Directive that addresses these old non-performing loans from the past by simplifying and facilitating their sale. We are currently working on this guideline with the same team of co-rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs, hoping to be able to complete that process before the elections. All in all, we will then go from a legislative proposal to entry into force within a year. That is quite unique for such a difficult and sensitive file and I think we can all be proud of it. Europe has delivered here. So I would especially like to thank Co-rapporteur Gualtieri and the other shadow rapporteurs for their cooperation, as well as the Commission and the Council, under both the Austrian and Romanian Presidencies. And thank you for your attention to this tricky, technical, but oh so important topic today.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: speaker. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the problem of non-performing loans has been widely discussed and identified as one of the problems needed to reduce risk in the European banking system. It is good to say and remember that the main cause of the high stock of non-performing loans was the deep economic recession that hit several member countries in the aftermath of the financial crisis, to which the negative effects of austerity policies were added. In some Member States, it is also true that this main cause has been accompanied by opaque credit practices, bad management or insufficient prudence. As regards these aspects, several measures have already been adopted, both at national and European level, and this is producing a significant drop in the level of non-performing loans. The text that we have agreed - and I would like to thank my colleague Esther de Lange for her cooperation, which led us to conclude such a delicate legislative procedure in record time - has two main objectives: on the one hand, to strengthen the measures aimed at preventing the excessive accumulation of non-performing loans, and on the other hand avoiding negative incentives from the point of view of the ability to support the economy or also from the point of view of the debtors, which naturally compared to an excessive push to sell down non-performing loans would be negatively affected. What are the main points of the agreement reached with the Council? First of all, we decided to apply this prudential backstop only to new credits resulting from new loans, in line with the Council's action plan, which called for precisely this. And this is logical, because it takes a sufficient period of time to adapt to the new rules, from an accounting and prudential point of view. The second element is that in the text we outline a correct and fair balancing of the provisioning levels for banks. In particular, unlike the Commission proposal, provisioning for secured or unsecured loans only starts after two or three years respectively, thus avoiding the risk that prudential provisions are added to the contraction of capital caused by the recession, creating a pro-cyclical effect, with negative effects on the granting of credit and on the real economy. We have also eliminated the potentially negative (or we could say perverse) incentives present in the Commission's proposal that would have accelerated the liquidation of companies only temporarily unable to repay the loan, but actually solvent, with negative consequences not only on the companies themselves, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, but also on economic growth and the level of employment. Last but not least, I would also like to mention an element that we have introduced, that is a more favorable prudential treatment for those non-performing loans that are purchased on the secondary market by other credit institutions, in order to avoid an unjust penalty for specialized operators and, at the same time, provide higher protection for consumers, SMEs and all other debtors, as these institutions are subject to strict controls and regulations. In conclusion, this is a balanced text that helps us take another important step in reducing the risks of the banking sector, while avoiding negative consequences on the real economy and on consumers. For this reason we invite you to support the text.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate you for taking this file from the onset, in July last year, with a strong will and dedication, which helped us reach political agreement on the text you will vote on tomorrow. We have been working intensively over the past years to reduce risks and to strengthen the resilience of the European banking sector. With a prudential backstop regulation, we are addressing one of the major risks to which European banks are still exposed: non-performing loans. Non-performing loans had piled up in the banks’ balance sheets in the aftermath of the financial crisis and ensuing economic downturn. As we saw, elevated levels of NPLs, if not dealt with sufficiently quickly, weighed on banks’ liability and capacity to lend to the real economy. We have certainly made substantial progress in reducing the high levels of NPLs. However, the ratio remains elevated when compared historically and to other regions, and accelerated GDP growth – a key driver behind the reduction in NPLs – cannot be taken for granted. Preventing the future accumulation of NPLs is hence essential for preserving financial stability and supporting lending to create jobs and growth. To this end, the prudential backstop will put EU-wide brakes on any excessive future build-up of NPLs on banks’ balance sheets, without sufficient loss coverage. It will do so by setting a common minimum coverage level for future loans if they become non-performing across Member States and banks. It will serve as a necessary complement to existing supervisory tools that can only be applied on a case-by-case basis, depending on the individual circumstances of the bank. The prudential backstop is therefore an important part of the Union’s effort to further reduce risks in the banking system, with a view to completing the banking union. However, our work to address NPLs is not complete yet. As you know, the backstop is part of the package of measures which also aim to improve the conditions for banks to deal with NPLs through more efficient enforcement mechanisms, as well as efficient competitive and transparent secondary markets. I therefore encourage you to swiftly agree on the outstanding proposal on the NPL Directive, in particular to further develop secondary markets for non-performing loans.

name: Stefan GEHROLD
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, I have been asked to speak in this debate on the so-called austerity policy and its effects on relations between Member States. I am certainly not the only one who feels that the financial crisis and its consequences have inflicted considerable wounds on the unity of Europe, and that these wounds are not yet fully healed. In this context, the financial system has suffered considerably, which has had major consequences on the lives of citizens. This is how the central place of financial institutions for the good economic development of all of society has been confirmed. Financial intermediation plays a vital role. After all, this is the goal of the proper functioning of our financial system: to enable all Europeans to fully benefit from the economic potential of our businesses. It should therefore be emphasized that patients are not only banks, of course, but also individuals. Therefore, it is by viewing the reduction of non-performing exposures as a crucial part of treatment that one can realistically speak of a real cure for all stakeholders. I would therefore like to congratulate the rapporteurs for providing a balanced response to the multiple challenges that have arisen. Let us not forget, however, that in order to ensure the success of this part of the treatment, one must also swallow the bitter pill of reasonable management of public finances. However, such a policy does not cause, as it is wrongly criticized, stagnation, but rather sustainable economic growth. Ultimately, the so-called austerity policy is not the consequence of a harsh regime imposed on the states concerned, but the consequence of an irresponsible spending policy carried out by weak and unwilling governments for many years.

name: Neena GILL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, my congratulations to the rapporteurs Roberto Gualtieri and Esther de Lange. Non-performing loans (NPLs), as we heard, are a legacy from the last financial crisis and a decade later, the EU has not sufficiently reduced the levels, and therefore action is still needed to prevent a worsening situation in the future. Since 2015, NPLs have declined by only 400 billion, down from one trillion. Clearly, there is a long way to go and they remain a big challenge facing banks in the euro area. The only way is to clean up their balance sheet whilst we have a positive economic climate. Therefore, I really welcome the improved text from the trilogue because it ensures adequate provisioning of NPLs in the banks’ balance sheets, and a more gradual provisioning in the earlier years will reduce the potential negative impact on the real economy.  Whilst this agreement and the recently adopted banking package reduce the risk in the banking sector considerably and bring the EU a little closer to banking union, there are three major reforms that are still needed to ensure that the EU banking sector becomes more resilient. Firstly, we need a decisive step towards a pan-European depository scheme to get adequate risk-sharing and equal protection of all EU savers. This is critical. It is a pity that the right side of this House keeps blocking this for ideological reasons, and I hope the next Parliament will address this.  Secondly, sustainable finance should become the norm, not the exception, and as banks are still the main financing source of the EU economy, they have a big responsibility. We have taken steps recently in terms of the sustainable finance package, but my question to the Vice-President is: how will the Commission ensure that banks exercise this responsibility? Finally, given the massive impact on the economy and taxpayers of the last financial crisis, we can no longer have too-big-to-fail banks. What is the Commission’s view on the upcoming merger between Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank and, in particular, the impact of this merger on financial stability?

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! We have a big problem in the eurozone with the huge stock of bad loans. 600 billion euros or more, if a lot is not hidden in some deferral measures. We have a big problem and now we are debating in this House a solution that does not solve the problem. A measure, a highly competitive legislative measure, that does not address the whole problem we have in the euro area because all the bad loans that built up in the financial crisis, that built up in the euro crisis, that built up in the The sovereign debt crisis that has built up will not be covered by this law at all. The law only applies to non-performing loans from the time this law comes into force. And not even the loans that will go non-performing now in 2019, after the law will come into force, will be immediately affected in any way, but will still have a period of three years before the first write-off measures apply. Only in 2022 will we begin to deal with non-performing loans, which at the moment do not even exist. And with this legislation we are not addressing the huge mountain of non-performing loans that is endangering bank stability and financial stability in the euro zone. This is a clear example of how often politicians pat each other on the back and congratulate themselves on solving a problem without explaining why the measure solves the problem in the first place. That is a complete failure of this Parliament.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would like to welcome Commissioner Dombrovskis again to this Parliament.  It was not easy to include our proposals and ideas for this regulation as the two co—rapporteurs held onto this file very tightly. Nevertheless, we have been active through the whole procedure because we are committed to those people who suffered the most due to non-performing loans. We have always said that non—performing loans (NPLs) have an inherent human dimension. They were built up because European law was implemented incorrectly. At the very beginning of this regulation, the Union acknowledges that there were important laws that were not implemented properly in some Member States: the Late Payment Directive, the Consumer Rights Directive and the Mortgage Credit Directive. Let me warn you that if we do not improve the implementation of EU law in some Member States, we may risk suffering a new wave of NPLs in some Member States in the next few years, even in the event of a new huge financial crisis or another economic crisis. Proper implementation is key. Proper implementation means prevention and commitment to our values, our rules and our Union. Parliament cannot fail in approving only one law and not the other. Without the directive, the regulation would lose all its meaning and major institutions could not have the legal incentive they need to put their non-performing loans on the market. We consider that this Parliament needs to send a strong message. It is therefore important that the whole NPL legislative package is approved. This is our responsibility.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, our Group shares the need to reduce the package of non-performing loans on balance sheets —it is very large—, not so much because they are a brake on credit ―Credit works when there is economic activity and when there is demand. but because they can be and are a source of significant financial instability. Therefore, it is a goal that we share. But, nevertheless, we believe that there are two criteria that must prevail. The first is that more responsibility should be demanded from financial institutions when it comes to giving credit, and that means a very high demand in the provision of non-performing loans. And, the second, a very great protection of the consumer and, particularly, of consumers who cannot afford their credits, because the reduction of delinquent credits cannot be carried out at the very high social cost that was carried out in some countries, as was the case. the Spanish case. Therefore, that was our will and these are our objectives, with which we face this debate. I have to say that we are not satisfied with the regulation that is presented to us. Therefore, we are not going to vote on it for some particular reasons that I will detail below. The first, because the provisions established for future non-performing loans are excessively long. The Commission proposed that a loan should be one hundred percent provisional after eight years. You propose up to nine. We proposed seven, following the advice of the European Central Bank, as it seemed to us a reasonable timetable but, of course, a little more demanding. And, finally, because you say that this rule will take effect three years after its approval. And, finally, we also proposed that this Regulation touch on some previous credits by making all credits that become delinquent after March 1 to be included. You only propose that all those credits issued as of April 1 be covered. Therefore, we are not happy at all. And we are also concerned that, having separated the two files, with the Directive all the part of consumer protection to see how it will be. Because if the negotiation dynamics is the same as what we have had in this file, which is basically a grand coalition agreement, then that really does not bode well. I therefore hope at the very least that small groups will be taken more into account when negotiating the Directive.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, none of the arguments in favour of the Commission’s package on non-performing loans stand up to scrutiny. Its supporters say that it will contribute to financial stability, but how does moving billions of euros of bad debt into the unregulated shadow banking sector achieve this? Its supporters argue that it will free up banks to lend to small businesses, but all of the evidence shows that it’s the lack of demand in the economy and not credit supply that is limiting lending. Its supporters say that we can achieve strengthened consumer protection in the directive, but in reality the package will encourage the banks to throw their customers to the wolves through the mass sell-offs of mortgages on family homes to vulture funds. This is exactly what’s happening in Ireland right now, and it has fuelled a housing and homelessness crisis on an unprecedented scale. Supporters of this proposal actually cite the Irish example with bad debt as a model to be replicated across the EU when, in reality, it is an example of exactly what not to do.  The truth is that this package is about returning banks to the situation where they can make massive profits again without any regard to the rights of borrowers who, let’s not forget, are European citizens. We cannot support this package as it won’t solve the problem of bad debt in the EU’s financial system. It will just move it into the shadows while throwing families who find themselves in distress to the vultures.

name: Marco VALLI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I personally, and also my group, are very concerned about the measures that will be applied with this NPL package, first of all because the impact study has not been done, and therefore the impacts that will be there. on the real estate market and the impact that there will be on consumers, businesses and European citizens have to be verified, because encouraging the sale of non-performing loans, in a short time, compared to a sound management that banks could do internally, involves precisely also a speculative mechanism. We know that there are several Funds that have also advised the European Central Bank and SSM during the stress tests, who are very interested in getting their hands on these NPL packages. I would not like that the houses, buildings, assets to guarantee citizens go, in fact, in the hands of these speculators. And since we are talking about risk reduction, I now wonder where is the reduction of risks on derivatives, for example, that the large European investment banks have in their stomachs and when will this blessed sharing of risks arrive. We look forward to a risk sharing on the joint deposit guarantee.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group.- (NL) Mr President, this report on loss cover for banks is in line with the formation of the capital markets union in which risks are spread among Member States.However, the Netherlands Scientific Council for Government Policy (WRR) concludes in its recent report "Money and Debt" that this spreading of risks actually promotes instability.The WRR concludes that the stability of the financial system is not only undermined by excessive credit build-up, but also by the uniformity, scale and interdependence of financial institutions.That is precisely what the capital markets union is aiming for.The WRR is certainly a well-known institute for the Dutch.So I assume the rapporteurs are also aware of this.So, Mr President, the only question that remains is why the rapporteurs want this after all.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: - Madam President, unfortunately the Commission is approaching this serious issue mainly from the point of view of banks and not with a view to consumer protection. Banks are an important pillar of the Member States' economies. Their possible collapse at the given time would mean frightening difficulties for the daily life of the citizens, but also for the states themselves. Strategic defaulters must be identified and forced to pay. Banks, however, are responsible for uncontrolled lending without collateral. Millions of citizens in the Member States of the Union, mainly due to the economic crisis, are unable to repay their debts and even risk losing their homes. Banks, through recapitalizations from citizens' money, continue to operate. For citizens who are struggling to survive due to their debts, measures should be taken, such as protecting their main residence and facilitating the repayment of their loans, especially for the unemployed, the low paid and the most vulnerable social groups.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: - Madam President, non-performing loans are a European problem, for which this text is an additional step forward. The aim is to reduce, in an effective way, non-performing loans and, at the same time, without creating a negative impact on the real economy and on borrowers. So far, so good. Three points: first, the protection of borrowers, given that the bank is de facto the strongest and the borrower is de facto the weakest, as set out in this European directive on unfair terms, means that we must intervene and in particular the European Commission to investigate complaints of ineffective implementation of this Directive. Let me tell you, then, that in the case of Cyprus in particular, this European directive is not being implemented effectively and in other Member States it is not being applied uniformly. The second point: risk sharing. Here I will repeat what my colleague said: ideological reasons - but I will also add: the special interests of some Member States - are hindering the completion of the European Banking Union with the third pillar that was and remains the demand: a pan-European deposit guarantee. Without this, we can not talk about real competition, which is fair, between the banks of the Member States. And the third point: recently in Cyprus we had a conclusion from the research committee appointed in connection with the collapse of the cooperative bank. The problem was, from the outset, the non-performing loans. But I confess to you that the conclusion comes to something that concerns the European institutions. They were deceived by the specific authorities of the government in Cyprus.

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: - Madam President!Financial institutions in the Union made progress in terms of the quality of their loan portfolios as well as the overall volume of non-performing loans.Additional measures are necessary to prevent the accumulation of non-performing loans in the future, which is why the Polish delegation welcomes and supports the presented legislative proposal.However, I would like to highlight two points.First, the current one-size-fits-all approach fails to take into account the existing differences in national civil law and the length of proceedings in civil courts.Secondly, a specific impact assessment needs to be carried out to assess the possible impact of the regulation on banks, on loan portability, on households, on small and medium-sized enterprises and on the growth of Member States' gross domestic product.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: - Madam President, of course we have to reduce non-performing loans because they are too high, EUR 600 billion. But we must do so by ensuring adequate consumer protection against speculative practices, and neither the Commission proposal is adequate nor the joint compromise proposal between the European People's Party and the Socialist Group. And also, if we want a sound banking system, we must also ensure that the non-regulated banking sector is subject to and obeys the same rules of transparency and accountability, and again this is not guaranteed by this proposal, which is why we cannot support it. . In addition, we are opposed to the salamiization of the problem and the constant postponements. Mrs Esther de Lange, you have the EDIS file in your hands for 4 years and you are late and nothing has been done and the term is ending. The risk has been reduced, but "risk sharing" has not gone one step further, as proposed by the Commission, and supported by the European Central Bank and a large part of the European Parliament. So, with salami, we will not achieve anything and the regulation has no meaning without the parallel directive. Too little, too late, what you have proposed and therefore we can not support.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Madam President, the SYRIZA government, after giving 20 million the day before yesterday to the pharmaceutical manufacturers, agreed to voluntary non-compulsory taxation with shipowners' crumbs, exempted banks and funds for eight years, and now puts the broken ones on the backs of the people. Completely abolishes any judicial protection of the first home of thousands of popular families from auctions. In 2019, 20,000 auctions are planned with a single decision of the banks and funds, where thousands of loans and bank employees are waiting for the dismissal. Lonely loan arrangements for a single year that are impossible to comply with for the few who will enter them due to very strict criteria. Free auctions for red loans from now on. The SYRIZA Eurogroup discussions do not change their co-decision for 100,000 auctions in three years. Another recapitalization of banks to finance capital. Memorandum and duration supervision. No pseudo-progressive front hides this deeply reactionary policy. After all, here in the Golden Dawn, first of all, he advocated the rescue of the banks and not the borrowers. The slogan "no house in the hands of a banker" to mobilize the working class families, to become a criterion in their attitude in the elections.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, the establishment of a comprehensive strategy to address the issue of non-performing exposures is an essential goal for the Union in its attempt to make the financial system more resilient. While addressing the non-performing loans (NPLs) is primarily the responsibility of banks and the Member States, there is also a clear Union dimension to reducing the current high stock of non-performing exposures, as well as to preventing any expressive build-up of NPLs in the future, and to preventing the margins of system-wide risks in the non-banking sector. I consider that an integrated financial system will enhance the resilience of the European monetary union to adverse shocks, while at the same time reducing the need for public risk sharing. Nevertheless, this proposal is crucial as it aims to ensure sufficient loss coverage by banks for future NPLs by amending the existing Capital Requirement Regulation.

name: Ralph PACKET
text: - (NL) Madam President, EUR 714 billion!Ten years after the financial crisis, that enormous amount of junk credits and loans facing repayment problems is still on the balance sheets of European banks.That has its consequences.In Italy, where junk loans are a huge problem, the Italian government had yet to come to the aid of the Carige bank in January.That is why these new rules come as called.They may even be a bit stricter for my part.In the meantime, the Macrons of this world always want new European funds, transfers, a Eurozone budget, a European Deposit Guarantee Fund, and so on.But if everyone had to sweep their own door and clean up their own debts, the European Union would look a lot better today.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! Indeed, we are considering a problem that can be very painful for both banks and borrowers. The argument that there is a delay and that we should therefore not endorse it does not convince me personally. We have been working for a long time, but the matter is not so simple. I understand that we mean the division of responsibilities between the bank and its assessment of the so-called the level of risk and the borrower, which is, remember, varied (this is not one unified type of borrower) and who also has the right to risk, both in part of the investment loan and, possibly, in part of the consumer loan related to the life plan. We need to reduce the level of non-performing loans, prevent their renewal or an increase in the degree. The question is, of course, fundamental from our point of view: how large should the funds be to cover the risk and what effect will this have on the banking system as well? However, we should remember - banks must be protected and investors should be given a chance to invest.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, we are talking about red loans in the Union, at a time when in Greece the Greeks impoverished by the memoranda are in danger of losing their homes to the crows. Despite the fact that the Greek people, by their over-indebtedness due to memoranda, saved the foreign creditors, but also the banks, although Greece was charged with 288 billion euros, finally the troika led by the ECB and Draghi demand from the banks the sale of of red loans to crows instead of lentil board. The Tsipras government, as well as the previous memorandum governments, let the problem of red loans grow. Now the Tsipras government is abolishing first-home protection and throwing borrowers north on usurers. The only solution is the creation of a rescue fund for borrowers with state intervention that will buy the red loans at the first offer price made by the crows, a proposal that we submitted two years ago. Stop here and now at first home auctions. "No house in the hands of a banker." This should be the central slogan in the upcoming European elections as well. Because there is another way for Greece.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Madam President! I would like to draw attention to the fact that these 600 or even 700 billion euros of outstanding or unpaid loans are a serious problem, but not so painful as we are in a period of development, rather than as if we were dealing with a period of stagnation or "failure". I draw your attention to this because the whole debate has not had very important definitions of the problem, related mainly to the sources of the problems. Are legal loopholes or system errors the source of the trouble? Are these mistakes made by the bankers themselves? To what extent are bad loans the result of the deliberate activity of various legal entities or natural persons? I am talking about this in the context of my work in the Committee on Terrorism. We talked there about bitcoins, about VAT loopholes, about creating criminal groups also using various banking activities. From my point of view, we should be on time before the end of the term of office.
