It's good that we make it, but it is very important that we have a full diagnosis of the sources of the problem and its scale.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Madam President, banks are part of a state's economy. It is, therefore, logical to show interest in order for them to survive, not to collapse, in order to be able to grant loans, which will contribute to the development and finding of work and employment. Primarily, however, the objective is not the survival of the banks, but the help of the borrowers, who are unable to repay the loans they have received. Due to the economic crisis, the number of these people is very large in all the countries of the European Union. This phenomenon is taking on tragic proportions in Greece, where millions of Greeks, due to the economic disaster of the country due to the memoranda, are unable to repay their loans, which turn red and every day thousands of them lose their homes. Recently, two days ago, a 54-year-old man committed suicide when government officials came to seize his house. This must be the effort we have to make. Protect these people, protect their first home, and enable them to repay the loans they have taken out.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to congratulate the co-rapporteurs on their work and dedication and the shadow rapporteurs for their support in the negotiations on this file.  Let me close by stressing that this legislative initiative proves that the Union is indeed united on the need to take decisive action to make its banking sector stronger and more stable, with the capacity to withstand future shocks, wherever they may come from and with the capacity to lend to the real economy. This is an important ingredient in future economic prosperity and also a resilient Economic and Monetary Union.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: Reporter. - (NL) Mr President, I would like to briefly comment on two points. A number of colleagues have commented on the European Deposit Guarantee Scheme. I must then take a step back and remind you that at the time of the crisis, we asked a lot from the European taxpayer when it comes to rescuing banks, guaranteeing that rescue, and guaranteeing a number of Member States . And during that crisis we said "never again". So the next time a bank needs to be bailed out, it's not the taxpayer, but the shareholder who gets the bill in the first instance. Now we have seen in practice that when it comes to a bank rescue or a resolution in certain countries, the state again guarantees, yet again the taxpayer has to cough up. And then I can imagine that when there are such big differences between Member States in whether or not to use public money to save banks, not every Member State is eager to guarantee one European fund right now, overnight. of bank balances across Europe. That doesn't mean we can't do anything. There is a good proposal to start with mandatory liquidity support in the case of deposit guarantee. That is something we can, as far as I am concerned, start tomorrow. The only problem is that a number of political groups already want a guarantee that we will immediately switch to that European pot. A number of recent bank rescues in Italy, the fact that a number of political groups will now also vote against this legislation for non-performing loans, shows that unfortunately the political support for this is not yet present, simply because in a number of Member States this risk reduction and the attitude required for this is not yet present. That is one. Secondly, I would like to answer my colleague Auke Zijlstra, who "did" a "Nigel Farage". He intervened in this debate, issued a two-minute statement and then left. He thinks the legislation is too weak. He comes from the Netherlands and belongs to the PVV. However, he was represented in these negotiations by a colleague from the ENF group from Italy, who sent me as a signal on behalf of his group: this legislation should work with much longer deadlines and above all be less ambitious. I added it up for a moment. I think we negotiated physically for about 20 hours, technically and with colleagues. The presence of the PVV and Mr. Zijlstra in these negotiations is exactly zero minutes. I have had dozens if not hundreds of emails as input for this legislation. The input of the PVV and Mr. Zijlstra: zero e-mails. So if I may say one more sentence, namely my response to the PVV: either do your work, write to me and join the debate, or shut up.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: speaker. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I think this debate has shown that we have actually approved a balanced text. We have listened to some propaganda on both sides. There are those who say that it is too harsh, and frankly I would like to say to my colleague Valli that I am serious, because everyone knows that this is a text that has softened the Commission proposal and is more balanced than the ECB addendum and therefore now accuse us of having made a text that is too harsh I find it propaganda. At the same time, I must say, I agree with my colleague de Lange: we have not seen all these colleagues who spoke to tell us that instead we had to do something tougher at the moment of the negotiations, only to say now of course that we were too soft, too loose. So the truth is that we took the responsibility of tackling a very difficult, very delicate issue and we managed to do it well and quickly. And this is a positive case of the capacity of this Parliament to produce legislation and also of being, in some way, a subject that when something does not work well, some authority, some tendency, some position, solutions that may be suitable for some conference. but then produce problems and negative impact on the real economy, this Parliament knows how to correct and reconcile the necessary reduction of risk and impaired loans, on the one hand, with the safeguarding of financial stability, the interests of citizens, debtors, small and medium-sized enterprises and produce a regulation which I think will have a significant impact, on the one hand, in greater prudence and therefore in discouraging practices that can then lead to an excessive accumulation of non-performing loans, but at the same time it does so to a sustainable manageable, without negative impacts on the real economy. So I would like once again to thank my colleague de Lange, the Commission and all colleagues who supported this work, and also the Council for allowing us to do a trilogue at record speed (possibly the fastest trilogue in history), with whom we were able to quickly insert this rule in the Official Gazette, as it will happen shortly.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: - The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday, 14 March 2019.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: - The next item is the interim report by Pedro Silva Pereira and Vladimír Maňka, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a Council regulation establishing the European Monetary Fund (2017 / 0333R (APP)) (A8-0087 / 2019).

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: Reporter. - Madam President, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, the reform of the European Stability Mechanism is one of the most important pillars of the reform process of Economic and Monetary Union, a process necessary to tackle the enormous weaknesses in the architecture of the euro that the financial crisis is so dramatically revealed. With this report, Parliament makes a very timely contribution to this process and I therefore want to thank the correlator, our colleague Vladimír Maňka, for the excellent collaboration we have had in the last few months of work. I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs of the different groups for the excellent spirit of cooperation that allowed us to achieve, I believe, a good result. With this report, Parliament defends a two-step strategy: as regards the medium and long term, the European Parliament reaffirms its vision with full clarity in defense of the full integration of the European Stability Mechanism in European law so that it can become a genuine institution of the European Union, with governance subject to the Community method and under the democratic control of the European Parliament. This not being immediately possible, in the short term, we advocate moving forward with the reform of the European Stability Mechanism through a revision of the Intergovernmental Treaty that created it. We did not think it appropriate, unlike the Commission, to change the name of this institution to the European Monetary Fund because this could create confusion as to the competence to conduct monetary policy, which should remain with the European Central Bank, but there are more important things that we can do. and we must do: first, strengthen the democratic control of the mechanism by the European Parliament. We therefore propose a cooperation protocol between the two institutions to reinforce the dialogue, strengthen parliamentary scrutiny and we propose more, we propose that the director of the European Stability Mechanism be elected here in the European Parliament. Secondly, we recommend strengthening the role of the mechanism in promoting financial stability, in responding to economic and financial shocks and, therefore, also with the revision of its missions and competences, without prejudice to the macroeconomic surveillance tasks that must continue to be carried out. the European Commission. Finally, greater autonomy vis-à-vis the International Monetary Fund must be achieved and the mechanism should be empowered to make the single resolution fund operational and therefore contribute to the completion of the banking union. We all know that the euro reform agenda goes beyond this, it requires budgetary capacity, it requires many other things, but the reform of the European Stability Mechanism is also an important step and we now hope that the Council will listen to the proposals and suggestions of the European Parliament so that we can move in the right direction.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, Vice-President of the European Commission, people remember the financial assistance to Greece as the country most affected by the financial crisis. At that time, the eurozone countries created the European Financial Stability Facility. This temporary mechanism has become a permanent European Stability Mechanism known as the Euroval. The aim was to provide financial assistance to countries affected by the financial crisis and the sovereign debt crisis, which had lost access to financial markets, namely Ireland, Spain, Portugal, Greece and Cyprus. However, these countries had to commit themselves to doing their homework in the form of structural reforms. The measures have led to the recovery of their economy, but have also prevented the enormous damage that would occur not only in the euro area but throughout the European Union. Let's look at these countries today. Thanks to European cooperation, Ireland achieves the highest economic growth in the European Union, Spain broke its historical records in exports, Portugal achieved a primary surplus. The Greeks, who had to undergo the most painful reforms, also no longer need a rescue program today. Once again, they can finance themselves on international markets. Greece has created hundreds of thousands of new jobs in recent years and is achieving solid economic growth. A few days ago, the rating agency Moody’s raised Greece's rating by 2 notches to B1. The Agency thinks that the reforms are already more firmly entrenched, with a high probability of further progress and a low risk of reverting the situation. At the same time, due to assistance to Greece in 2011-2012, the government fell in Slovakia in my country. But it has turned out that it is thanks to our joint European cooperation that the euro is more resilient to the crisis today than ever before. Support for the euro is also historically the highest in the euro area since its introduction. Since the beginning of the creation of the European Stability Mechanism, we have seen that its intergovernmental nature reduces its ability to respond quickly to economic and financial shocks. Therefore, the future integration of the European Stability Mechanism into the legal framework of the European Union will strengthen its ability to act and be effective. We should see this integration as part of the project to complete economic and monetary union. It is important that future integration into the EU legal framework takes into account the role of national parliaments. In the case of the European Union's budgetary resources in the future, the European Parliament should have the political power to exercise all rights of control over the budget in the context of the discharge procedure. In such a case, the European Court of Auditors should have a role in the discharge procedure. Financial resources, instruments of the reformed European Stability Mechanism, should be able to provide preventive financial assistance to Member States before they face significant difficulties in obtaining capital market funding. Financial assistance to Member States may be complemented by budgetary instruments to support economic and financial stabilization, investment and upward socio-economic convergence in the euro area. The European Stability Mechanism should not remain closed to euro area countries alone. It should be open to the participation of all Member States of the European Union. Ladies and gentlemen, I believe that our joint efforts will result in greater security and stability, not only for the euro area, but for the European Union as a whole.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, the European Parliament has always played a pioneering role in the debate on deepening the Economic and Monetary Union. It has also showed strong support for the Commission’s initiatives to strengthen its architecture. Today’s debate about the interim report on the Commission’s legislative proposal for the establishment of the European Monetary Fund is another step. On behalf of the Commission, I would first like to thank the committees and, in particular, the rapporteurs, Mr Silva Pereira and Mr Maňka, and the shadow rapporteurs for their work on this issue. I would also use this occasion to thank those of you with whom the Commission has worked very closely over the past years to complete the Economic and Monetary Union. The Commission welcomes this interim report and broadly agrees with its most important messages. In particular, we support Parliament in its call for the integration of the European Stability Mechanism (ESM) into the Union framework. As you know, this was an objective of our proposal. Since its creation in autumn 2012, at the height of the crisis, the ESM has proved decisive in helping to ensure financial stability in the euro area. Its integration into the EU legal order will not only strengthen its institutional anchoring, but will also enable its accountability to the European and the national parliaments to be increased, as well as making its functioning more transparent, a point Parliament also addressed strongly in your interim report. Another important point you stress, with which we fully concur, is on the need for Member States to respect the common rules of the economic governance framework in order to ensure that the competences of the ESM do not overlap with or affect those of other EU institutions, and to ensure that any set-up is fully compatible with EU law. I would also like to welcome your call for an anticipated introduction of the common backstop to the single resolution fund by 2020. Finally a remark on the name. We proposed ‘European Monetary Fund’, as this was the terminology used in the policy discussion, but we have taken note of the objections of the European Central Bank and of this House and we are open to reconsidering it. Maybe we can just stick with the current name, European Stability Mechanism. Since the Commission tabled this proposal, we have seen further developments on the various EMU work strands. In particular, Member States have decided to proceed with a revision of the ESM treaty in an intergovernmental framework. Work on the revision of the ESM treaty is ongoing and I trust this will make an important contribution to building a stronger Economic and Monetary Union, not least by adding the backstop for the single resolution fund and increasing the effectiveness of the precautionary instruments, while avoiding duplication of roles. In the latter respect, I would like to highlight the agreement on cooperation between the Commission and the ESM reached in November last year, which was endorsed by the euro summit. Our ambition is that the new treaty will include a commitment to integrate the ESM into the Community framework at the next possible opportunity.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. – Madam President, I would like to raise issues which are important from the perspective of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO). There are two points I would like to raise. The first is that of the inclusion of the successor of the European Stability Mechanism (ESM) in the European legal framework. It is not a detail, I believe,  but a crucial point of the proposal. We in the Parliament had been calling repeatedly for the end of those intergovernmental arrangements established during the financial crisis and their integration into the Union framework and this proposal is an opportunity to do so. Member States are currently working on the basis of an amendment to the ESM Treaty, but we should be very clear here that the integration of the ESM Framework into EU law will have to be addressed soon. Secondly, the accountability of the successor of the European Monetary Fund (EMF) to the European Parliament and national parliaments will be crucial. We have to establish mechanisms which ensure a high level of accountability of the decisions of the successor of ESM to elected bodies. Access to information is a precondition for the exercise of accountability so there will also be a need to provide for a high level of transparency regarding the decisions of the successor of the ESM.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - (NL) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the financial crisis has left us all face to face. Our Monetary Union is far from over. On the contrary. Member States that had to rescue a banking sector have suddenly found themselves in trouble. National regulators, each checking their banks on their own island, actually had no idea whatsoever of the whole systemic disaster that was to come. Some member states were suddenly unable to obtain financing on financial markets and have become dependent on European emergency loans. We hastily created the European Stability Mechanism, the ESM. That clearly did what it was supposed to do. But it is important to stress that a European emergency mechanism must at all times remain a story of rights and obligations. Member States at risk of losing funding in the financial market should be able to turn to that mechanism. There should be no doubt about that. But it is, of course, just as important that this support remains conditional, so that enough money is left in the jar for when Member States really need it. Ex ante with fiscal rules and ex post with economic adjustment programs. We must absolutely avoid an emergency mechanism to weaken the pressure to comply with fiscal rules because, so to speak, Europe will come to solve it anyway if it really becomes necessary. We know Commissioner Dombrovskis that you are personally available day and night, weekend or weekdays, to save the Eurozone. But you would also not like us to just call you without any kind of conditions. Finally this. Deepening our Monetary Union must be at the top of the agenda. Along with the completion of the banking union, the creation of the capital markets union, inserting the European Stability Mechanism into the European construction is, I think, another important and necessary step to make the eurozone "crisis-proof".

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Madam President, we welcome the opportunity for the European Parliament to say how it sees the evolution of the European Stability Mechanism with this interim report, when clearly this discussion is totally blocked in the Council. The creation of the European Stability Mechanism was successful when some Member States needed to be bailed out and no longer had market access. Today, it is a question of using this success to take a new step, and we are well aware that this step is also linked to a new environment, where the question of sharing risks and their reduction has taken steps. absolutely considerable, whether with the adoption of the PNP package (non-performing loans) and the banking package. That is why my group believes that the development of this European stability mechanism should not lead to the creation of a European Monetary Fund. We would have preferred the creation of a European Stability Fund. I understand that the agreement will be made around maintaining the existing name, but the main thing is the role that this mechanism will play in the future, because we would have liked it to be able to be used fully to ensure the stability function which the European Union, and above all the euro zone, undoubtedly still need and which it can provide the guarantee we need for the “safety net” of the banking sector. We understand that some things are changing in the Council, but from this point of view, I fear that an inherent flaw in the European Stability Mechanism persists. When the European Parliament, in the midst of the crisis, agreed to the creation of this mechanism in an intergovernmental framework, it was under pressure, in the idea that we would succeed in remedying this situation. However, today, the Council refuses any discussion on the useful proposal that the Commission had put on the table and which made it possible to progress towards the integration of this mechanism into the framework of the Treaties, which this Parliament continues to advocate. to ask and to claim as being the right way forward for the future of the mechanism.

name: Ralph PACKET
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - (NL) Mr President, with this report the aim is to anchor the European Stability Mechanism or ESM, and thus the financial support to member states, forever in EU legislation, with financial support as the main task. We do not agree with that. I don't believe in that focus, in bailouts. Simply giving extra loans does not solve anything, because the debts in Europe will always linger like a sword of Damocles above the eurozone. Such a bailout fund costs far too much to the taxpayer and removes the incentive for Member States to take responsibility. It is also simply much more logical to leave the organization of the ESM with the Member States, because it is they who provide the money in that fund. It is the national parliaments that must be able to exercise control over this. We should not focus on new bailouts, but on the prevention of new crises. We do this by enforcing the budget rules much better. We must also focus on settling the debts. However, if a country cannot pay off its debts, then we need to see how they can be cleared. The Flemish taxpayers should not just pay for the problems of elsewhere. And in time, the original "no bailout" clause in Europe must be reinstated, so that wild rescue plans like this no longer have to be invented.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to salute the excellent work of our two co-rapporteurs and welcome the entry of this European financial stability mechanism into the Community framework. It is true that when the single currency was created, no one imagined the crisis in which the euro zone found itself during the sovereign debt crisis and the difficulties of Greece. It is in this context that we had to imagine an instrument to pool, in a way, the over-indebtedness of certain countries. Today, it is opportune to bring this mechanism into the institutional framework, and I thank the rapporteurs for insisting on the need to maintain a close link with national parliaments. When it comes to endowing the social capital of the European Financial Stability Mechanism and granting financial guarantees, it is indeed the national parliaments that make the funds available and make the commitments. I will express regret because, fundamentally, this is about the governance of the euro zone, and I regret that we did not believe it necessary to recommend the appointment of a Minister of Finance, who could have been a vice-president of the Commission in charge of the euro. I would also like to express a wish: that the European Union uses its currency as the United States of America does, in order to ensure respect for Europe's vital interests extraterritorially. I hope that one day we can use this currency, the euro, as an instrument in economic and trade war to safeguard our vital interests. But once again, I thank our co-rapporteurs, because their interim report allows us to take an important step.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, the first thing I want to say is that the intention to introduce the European Stability Mechanism into the acquis communautaire was a good idea, the thing is that we are not really going to do that. What we are going to do practically is to introduce a mechanism, which will continue to be in its purely intergovernmental operation, within the acquis communautaire, but we do not fully communitize the operation of the European Stability Mechanism, which is very bad news. We also have a problem with the role of Parliament in this reform. Anyway - some Members have said so - we should be in the middle of the codecision procedure and not simply in an approval procedure that requires us to do this mid-debate report. The European Stability Mechanism has had a lot of problems from the beginning because of its opacity, because of the way it did conditionality, because of the way memorandums of understanding were signed ... Mr Regling gave us lessons on everything, but he never came to the European Parliament to explain, and we have been working with an institution practically in a state of economic exception, without any kind of democratic control. Of course, I believe that the experience that its operation leaves in recent years has been one of the most negative that we have had, with bailouts that have been carried out at a very high social cost and without any kind of democratic legitimacy. For this reason, I believe that it was important not only to include this Regulation - as he said - within the acquis communautaire but without touching anything at all, but to carry out an in-depth review of the functioning of the Mechanism. For example, we had proposed and wanted the report to reflect that the European budget contribute to the financial mechanisms of the European Stability Mechanism, because that way we could exercise budgetary control over its activity, which has not been accepted, but which will be in the vote on an amendment we have tabled. The second thing also that we wanted to be in the text is for future adjustment programs to be delegated acts. Why? Because that would allow the European Parliament to be able to exercise our legal rights and reject them. But that seems to have not wanted to be accepted either. But despite this, we will table it as an amendment also in plenary. Or, also, another amendment that we are going to present is that there be something that we have been asking for for a long time: analysis of social impact, especially in the things that the Mechanism does and the policies that the Mechanism develops, something that has not been done. In Greece it has not been done, for example, and it has been a real disaster. And also more ability to control the appointment of the CEO. We ask for capacity in the appointment of him, but in a truly democratic process of Parliament with a shortlist from which we can choose. And finally, the issue of the backstop: it is all very well that the ESM is going to function as a backstop, but a backstop does not work if it requires unanimity in the Council. And we should have also introduced a request that the operation of the protection mechanism occurred automatically based on certain criteria. A protection mechanism submitted to the unanimity of the Council, frankly, is not a protection mechanism. Therefore, I have to say that we are not satisfied with either the report or the proposed reform.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, do we need a European Stability Fund? Yes, we do, and that is why we do not need, Mr Dobrowski, a European copy, a European replica of the International Monetary Fund. And I tell you this because in Greece we lived painfully, on the backs of the Greek people, the painful consequences of the wrong neoliberal recipes and the wrong multipliers of the International Monetary Fund. And we now need a European Stability Fund which, as Mrs Hübner said, needs to be integrated into the European legal system, working with the Community method and accountable to the European Parliament, and not just the national parliaments, because that is not guaranteed by the intergovernmental method, but the Community method. And, in addition, it must not only replace the International Monetary Fund, but also the recipe of the International Monetary Fund, the Schieble doctrine, neoliberalism. That is why we need to make positive changes, so that it is accountable not only to the European Parliament, but also to the Court of Auditors. And we also need a Vice-President of the Commission, who is responsible for the issues of the eurozone, not only the economy, but also social cohesion. If we do not do this we will be far behind the requirements.

name: Marco VALLI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we cannot as a group absolutely accept the basis of reasoning that exists in establishing this European Monetary Fund, as it is a replica of the European Stability Mechanism, which is being institutionalized. In concept, what is being done is to give conditional loans which, as my colleague Papadimoulis correctly said, humiliated the Greek people to the extent that the European Stability Mechanism, the Commission and the Monetary Fund have lent this money in exchange for thing? Of reforms, tears and blood, devaluation of wages, a devastating social impact: the Commission's admissions of blame on this type of mechanism. You want to institutionalize this principle thinking that making it more democratic makes it softer. This is a great crime. We should completely review this type of construction and start from the analysis of the profound imbalances within the Eurozone, because there are imbalances and these tools are not needed. We need a real democracy, but in this case you are absolutely not demonstrating it by proposing this European Monetary Fund.

name: Michał MARUSIK
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President! We are talking about the market. The mechanism of the free market is that non-profit companies and enterprises fail, while those that best meet the needs of consumers develop. It is thanks to this mechanism that we can enjoy an abundance of goods. In a free market, only two factors actually determine success: consumer demand and low production costs. Any administrative interference in the free market, on the one hand, helps those who are ineffective and should fail to survive, and on the other hand, they burden those who have found a way to succeed and could thrive. The creation of an institution such as a monetary fund is another mechanism of very strong interference in the economy, and interference that strictly defies the judgments of the free market. The result of this can be - and will certainly be - only one: the development of effective companies will be stunted, and consumers will be burdened with financing companies that should have failed as ineffective. The creation of such a fund and the allocation of large financial resources to it also means oligarchic privileges for large corporations, and after all, any privilege given to anyone is, in fact, discrimination against all others. Thus, the mechanism of ever stronger punishment for efficiency and reward for inefficiency is becoming popular. In this way, the Union will give Europe growth, but with a negative sign, unfortunately. Detriment.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in 2010, the troika made up of the European Commission, the ECB and the IMF imposed unprecedented austerity measures on the Greek people, who obviously quickly fell into misery under the blows of these few international civil servants. This show obviously made you want, because now you are claiming your own IMF, the IMF. You write it, moreover, in black and white: the primary mission of this EMF will be to provide transitional financial assistance to Member States in need, but, of course, on the basis of specific conditions agreed in the adjustment programs. . But we know what these adjustment programs mean: in Greece pensions have been drastically cut, wages have fallen, companies have been privatized and, of course, unemployment has exploded. Here it is, the unsurpassable horizon of Europeanism, the endless purge, ordered by a Germany which rules Europe with an iron fist. One thing is certain, dear colleagues, if I do not expect much from the sovereignist movement in France, I can still count on you to make Europe hateful to the peoples and unbearable to the nations.

name: Markus FERBER
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I think we saw one thing very clearly in the financial and sovereign debt crisis: the European Stability Mechanism and its predecessor, the EFSF, have proven their worth. He made decisions apolitically, on the basis of facts and clear rules. That is significantly more than can be said of the European Commission. The ESM and EFSF played a key role in making the programs a success in Ireland, Portugal, Cyprus, Spain and Greece. For me, this leads to a logical conclusion: what has proven itself should not be questioned in principle. We are welcome to consider how we can improve the exchange between the European Parliament and the ESM or a European Monetary Fund, for example through an interinstitutional agreement. But we shouldn't go too far. In the end, the funds are made available by the Member States. This means that in the end the national budgets are also liable and the national parliaments are responsible for oversight. This is also dictated by the liability principle. Conversely, that also means that we should reject some of our colleagues' proposals, for example that we should vote by majority vote on macroeconomic adjustment programs or that a European finance minister can think about the allocation of funds as he sees fit. The principle of liability as a leitmotif is central.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, from the beginning of the economic crisis, the deficiencies of the euro's architecture and, above all, the need to continue working and deepening the Economic and Monetary Union became apparent. And it is true that steps have been taken in this direction, especially in reducing risks, but we still have a lot to work on, such as completing the European deposit guarantee system or having a real budget from the Eurozone that allows eurozone countries to defend themselves against new economic crises. And under this umbrella of the Economic and Monetary Union, today we are discussing the reform of the current European Stability Mechanism, which was already launched in 2012 but which, in the opinion of this Parliament, must be modified. And in this sense, for example, we believe that this European Stability Mechanism should be integrated into the Union's legal framework. This integration would allow management in accordance with the community method and, in addition, among other things, would facilitate the coordination of economic and fiscal policies and would give it greater democratic legitimacy. On the other hand, I also think that it would be interesting if the European budget could contribute to this mechanism, because this would give the European Parliament the possibility to exercise budgetary control and, in addition, the Court of Auditors to be the external auditor. Socialists have denounced on innumerable occasions the abusive conditionality and excessive adjustments that were demanded of the countries under the mandate of the troika. The damage caused has even been recognized by some of the leaders of the European Union and that is why, looking ahead, we also demand that adjustment programs take into account the social impact of the measures that are proposed so as not to return to fall into mistakes of the past. I am aware that these are just recommendations from the European Parliament and that they do not actually have legal value, but they do have important political value, so I hope that they will take them into consideration.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! At the beginning of the European stabilization mechanism there was a breach of contract. The European treaties were broken when the no bailout clause was broken, and this gave rise to the European stabilization mechanism, ESM. Today we are talking about replacing the ESM with a European Monetary Fund, and that would again be a breach of contract, because the European Union has absolutely no competence to set up a European Monetary Fund. Nowhere in the European treaties is it authorized to set up a monetary fund. This is again an example of the EU trying to take on one competence after another, and unfortunately the experience we have had with it is always a bad one. When the EU was given responsibility for monetary policy, it immediately led to a major euro crisis. When the EU was given responsibility for asylum and refugee policy, it led to a refugee crisis. With what justification do we actually want to hand over the competence for macroeconomic stabilization, for financial stability, to the EU? It's illegal, it's against the Treaties, and there is absolutely no reason why we should do it. The member states are also responsible under the European treaties.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: – Madam President, listening to this discussion, I sometimes get the feeling that we are suffering from economic amnesia. We don’t know the history. We are speaking as if the mismatches of the economy appeared with the euro. I’ll give you one example, just one example. Go back in British history to 1956. What you had in Britain in 1956 was a deficit budget and an over-valued pound and then you had the crisis there. Crisis mismatches have been part of the history of Europe since, well, since the beginning of history. There was one good German, even if German bashing has been very popular in this House. Willy Brandt, in 1969, came to a meeting of the European Council and said that Germany was ready to give 30% of its currency surplus to Europe as starting money for a European monetary fund, but on one condition: Europe had to be able to manage its economy and if it couldn’t, it shouldn’t come to this House and blame others for something it had done itself. So, thank you, but read the history and try to understand what this is all about.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – A Uachtaráin, bhuel, aontaím leis an iar-chainteoir a bhí againn ansin mar i ndáiríre cé gur meicníocht eile í seo atá á cur ar bun againn, agus is cuma má tá tú ag glaoch an Stability Mechanism air nó EMF, is an rud céanna atá ann. Agus i ndáiríre cé go dtuigim go bhfuil gá le meicníocht den tsórt seo, ag an am gcéanna mar Éireannach, a Choimisinéir, chaithfeá tuiscint canathaobh go mbeinn amhrasach mar gheall air agus canathaobh nach mbeinn chomh fabhrach. Mar nuair a chuimhnímid ar Éirinn ach go háirithe, cosúil le tíortha eile ar nós na Gréige, táimidne fós ag íoc as an bail out uafásach a tharla dúinn roinnt blianta ó shin agus beimid ag íoc as go dtí 2040. Mar sin, tá sé an-deacair orainn a bheith dóchasach go mbeadh a leithéid de mheicníocht mar seo chun obair ar ár son, go háirithe nuair a chuirimid i gcás, abair an oiread sin daoine atá in Éirinn - tá géarchéim tithíochta againn - níl siad ábalta morgáiste a thógaint amach ón mbanc, tá an ráta úis is airde againn ó thaobh iasachtaí a fháil ón mbanc chun morgáiste a fháil, tá an oiread sin daoine i ngéarchéim eacnamaíoch anois in Éirinn go bhfuil sé an-deacair orthu aon saghas slí bheatha a bhaint amach. Mar sin, canathaobh a bheimis dóchasach go n-oibreodh meicníocht mar seo? Caithfidh sé a bheith trédhearcach agus caithfidh sé a bheith cuntasach chomh maith. Agus rud amháin eile a chaithfidh mé a rá mar gheall ar na bainc, ach go háirithe aga baile, ní dhíolann siad oiread is pingin chánach - pingin chánach - cé go bhfuilid ag déanamh brabús ollmhór. Agus arís, táimid ag caint ar na cáiníocóirí a bheith fabhrach i dtaobh meicníocht mar seo a chur chun cinn. Mar sin, nílim ró-dhóchasach agus ní dóigh liom go mbeidh muintir na hÉireann ró-dhóchasach faoi ach an oiread. Tuigim go bhfuil gá leis, ach ag an am gcéanna, ní dóigh liom go bhfuil sé maith go leor.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, sorry, but what good is a new European Monetary Fund? Are there any other German and French banks that need to be bailed out? No, thanks, we have already given for our part. We have already had this experience with the bailout fund in 2010, where with the excuse of saving Greece and saving Spain, Italy had to shell out 60 billion euros in three years, which went straight into in French and German banks. The Spaniards and the French have not seen one euro of these figures. Among other things, this new Monetary Fund will increase financial instability, rather than decrease it, because granting loans in exchange for austerity is a real blackmail, which France and Germany do to countries in difficulty, forcing them to a restructuring that still empties of plus their political and economic sovereignty. Then we will come back here, in this House, in a few years and we will have to listen to the next President of the European Commission who will apologize, once again, as happened with Juncker, to Greece, which he destroyed together with the International Monetary Fund. Experience has shown that austerity recipes blocked the recovery and triggered the recession. So now is the time to change direction and allow member states to make expansive economic policies to combat unemployment, poverty and social and economic inequalities.

name: André ELISSEN
text: - (NL) Mr President, today we are talking about the establishment of the European Monetary Fund and the so-called blessings of the euro. Membership in the single currency assumes Member States with roughly the same gross domestic product per capita and comparable economic conditions. This was absolutely not the case when the euro was introduced. The introduction of the euro has been a major mistake and has contributed to economic problems in the European Union. Examples include over-indebtedness and weak economic growth. Countries outside the EU and the euro, such as Norway and Switzerland, have suffered significantly less from this. The Netherlands has already provided tens of billions in loans and guarantees to deceitful countries such as Greece and Cyprus, countries that did not meet the criteria for joining the euro, the so-called convergence criteria. Mr President, the euro is not money, the euro costs us money. The European Monetary Fund should become a crisis management tool. That is why it is even proposed to kill the veto of national parliaments. A small country like the Netherlands then has nothing to say at all. To be clear, we are against a European Monetary Fund. We propose to end the European Stability Mechanism as soon as possible.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Is there a problem with the interpretation now? Can we fix it? Okay. Voimme siis jatkaa.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The European Parliament has been calling for years for the european bailout ESM to become the European Monetary Fund. We have already done so in our report on the causes and consequences of the greatest economic, financial and social crisis. We have done so in our own-initiative report on the review and control of the troika, and we are doing so today with full conviction that we are learning another lesson from the financial and sovereign debt crisis, creating a stronger economic and monetary union and contributing to financial stability in the European Union.  However, we naturally want this European Monetary Fund to be under the control of the European Parliament on the basis of Community law and not just as an intergovernmental, intergovernmental instrument. With this monetary fund, with stability aid, we only want to help Member States in need under strict conditions and reforms. We want this fund to have at least EUR 500 billion and possibly be part of the European budget, and which, as an ultima ratio, it also takes over the common backstop for the resolution fund of the Banking Union.  This fund is necessary to make Europe more independent, to make Europe more stable, to strengthen the euro and to be able to intervene in Europe in need without foreign aid, and to strengthen the Commission's work on rehabilitation and aid programmes. We stand by this development and ask the Member States to do everything possible to finally create the framework conditions for this.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, it makes a little laugh to hear sovereignist colleagues demanding the decision-making autonomy of their states forget that the European Monetary Fund – which will not be called that, because it will continue to be called the SSM – has so far been used through decisions by the Member States, essentially, and not through full inclusion in Community law. This report is based precisely on this consideration, on the difficulties that have arisen in essentially intergovernmental management, and it wants the new Monetary Fund to have the legitimacy it deserves. In this report I would like to stress precisely the importance of bringing it back into Community law, although not yet satisfactorily.  In any case, we must give Parliament a real right of supervision and action. Need more? Yes, of course, starting with the name, which is in fact no longer the European Monetary Fund, but continues to be called as before. There is certainly the usual confusion about the names that our institutions always produce.  (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Thank you, Madam, for accepting the blue card. It is a genuine question. You used a word that was very interesting to me: ‘sovereignists’. I have not heard that word used in this kind of context before. Could you explain to me what you mean by ‘sovereignist’ – is it a pejorative term or is it purely a descriptive one? It struck me as soon as you started speaking. I wasn’t going to blue-card tonight, but I just had to ask you, so could you explain ‘sovereignist’ to me?

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Answer to a blue card question. – Of course: 'sovereignist' is the one who believes that competences within the European Union should be brought back into the individual States or managed in an intergovernmental way. Those who are federalists, like me, think that the sovereignty that the Member States can no longer manage must be brought up to Community level and therefore really managed. The currency is certainly one of them.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Speaking in the debate on the Council regulation on the creation of the European Monetary Fund, I would like to express my hope that this will significantly strengthen the financial stability of the Union, the credibility and growth prospects of the euro area countries. The transformation of the existing intergovernmental institution, the European Stability Mechanism, into a fund within the institutional and legal framework of the Union, the establishment of a mechanism for cooperation with the European Parliament, national parliaments, as well as rules on transparency of public access to documents are all solutions that increase democratic accountability from decisions taken. In doing so, I would like to express my hope that the Fund, as well as other solutions for changes in the structure and functioning of Economic and Monetary Union, will be in line with the principle of openness towards non-euro area countries and with the principles that underpin European integration, including the rules of the single market. They must not interfere with the competitiveness of the Member States and of the Union as a whole. Nor should they restrict the rights of non-euro area Member States, inter alia as regards decision-making, including in particular restricting their access to finance within the Union budget.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Madam President, the experience of a decade of austerity policies, which are a scathing failure throughout Europe, will clearly not have been enough. And Macron and Merkel have found nothing better than inventing a new anti-democratic institution: the European Monetary Fund. Without any control of the European Parliament, the EMF will destroy, like the IMF, the troubled states and organize the rampage of the welfare state to impose the sacrosanct ordo-liberal doxa. In reality, Macron and Merkel's Europe is a machine for crushing democracy: nothing for the people and everything for the banks.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, how helpful – a European Monetary Fund. How helpful. So, when there are countries and organisations and businesses and economies that are struggling, you’re going to pick up taxpayers’ money and throw it over to them. How helpful. It was also really helpful when you got these countries into the eurozone in the first place. That was really, really, helpful of you. The only trouble is, these countries, these organisations, economies and businesses are struggling within the constraints of that zone you so helpfully got them into and now, rather than saying ‘OK, look, it’s not working out here. OK, these economies need to work out for themselves how to do it, these businesses which are unprofitable need to collapse and be replaced’ – because that would be the market, that would be free market capitalism and that’s sinful, isn’t it? – instead, you’re going to get huge sums of taxpayers’ money and prop up things that aren’t working. I like to be helpful as well. I’m a helpful person in a room of helpful people and what I would strongly suggest to you is that you need to understand you cannot book the market. You’re forcing square pegs into round holes and all this is doing is wasting billions of taxpayers’ money on impossible projects – again.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, the euro area is inherently fragile, because it includes states whose economic levels are too heterogeneous, like Germany and Greece. The Nobel Prize in Economics, the American Joseph Stiglitz, explained it himself. It is in danger of being swept away by the next financial crisis. The European Union is thus trying to create increasingly restrictive safety nets. The European Financial Stability Facility, established in 2010, took over the European Stability Mechanism in 2013. It is the latter, considered too intergovernmental, that is now being considered to be transformed into a more integrated European Monetary Fund. This new instrument will indeed be a European body in its own right. This is therefore a further attack on national sovereignty. That is why I am hostile to it. It is obvious that this EMF will do as its model, the IMF, it will condition its financial aid to the States on the implementation of a programme of privatization and austerity imposed in the name of ultraliberalism, which takes the place of thought in the European Union. I will therefore vote against it, because I do not want France to be the toy of the EMF tomorrow.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: – Mr President, from the outset I have stressed that if the European Union wants to create a financial instrument to assist Member States in financial difficulty, then the rational solution is to transfer the European Stability Mechanism from the intergovernmental framework to the legal framework of the European Union. It is a positive fact that both the Commission's proposal and the report we are debating today support this transformation. I regret that the Council has decided not to call into question the Commission's proposal. I would like to stress that I support the proposal in the report, that this new European Stability Mechanism should also be open to Member States that are not in the euro area, but are obliged to take the necessary measures to enter the euro area, but with an amendment: this possibility should be offered only to Member States which have taken the decision to adopt the euro and which fulfil the programmes agreed for this purpose with both the European Commission and the Central European Bank. Also welcomed the proposal in the report, that this new European Stability Mechanism should also be given the back stop function for the Single Resolution Fund, so that we can also strengthen and develop Pillar Two of the Banking Union.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, our debate confirms that this Parliament wants the reform of the European Stability Mechanism to help to make the Single Resolution Fund operational in order to move towards the completion of the Banking Union, as planned. But we want much more, we want a truly European stability mechanism, integrated into European law and subject to the control of this Parliament. We want you to have more autonomy vis-à-vis the IMF and therefore turn the troika page. We want you to do more in supporting states and learn all the lessons from the assistance programmes of the past, which also means that you will not fail to make a serious assessment of the social impact of the measures to be included in future assistance programmes. These are the messages from the interim report that we are going to adopt, and we now hope that the Council and the Commission will listen to this Parliament which represents European citizens.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a great deal of ink has been spilled on the creation of a European Monetary Fund in the footsteps of the hated International Monetary Fund, which has torn apart entire countries and societies, with Greece the last victim of the guinea pig. So instead of looking for IMF-style mechanisms that have impoverished the Greek people, it would be good to hit the causes that led eurozone countries to risk and bankruptcy. One is the root cause and that is the structure but also the policy of the euro area. Eurozone built to serve German interests. The eurozone operates on the basis of the Straitjacket of the Stability Pact, which imposes austerity and violent fiscal adjustment. For this reason, the Stability Pact should be abolished, the ECB should become a last resort lender, the European System of Central Banks should be decentralised, and member states should regain their monetary sovereignty up to their share of the ECB's capital.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the Commission for preparing this report and I’m convinced that we are taking an important step forward when it comes to the strengthening the Economic and Monetary Union in the EU. The European Monetary Fund (EMF) aims to replace and absorb the European Stability Mechanism as an efficient and key anti-crisis mechanism. It fills a significant gap in the existing system of governance in the euro area, in the first place. What are the tasks? First of all the EMF would provide support to Member States in financial distress. One could say that is the ESM’s role, but this, as I will explain, is something which will be provided in a more efficient and prompt way. The second task is that it will serve as a backstop for banks that fall into financial trouble. So there is a chance that, by providing financing both to states and to the banks, we are finally going to break the vicious nexus of sovereign-bank connection. The mechanism will be fiscally neutral so it does give us a guarantee that it is not going to transform itself into a permanent payment transfer mechanism. Further advantages include the fact that, in terms of governance, it is going to be much more efficient because, as part of the legal framework of the European Union, the decision-making mechanism will be faster and it will be more willing and able to face crisis situations in Member States. Lastly, just one reservation: we should not consider the EMF as a competitor of the IMF, and I would urge the Commission to design the whole solution in such a way as to still have access to, and to benefit from, the IMF as an international institution.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: Mr President, the economic crisis of 2008 highlighted the devastating consequences of an incomplete union that organises the free movement of capital but refuses to provide economic solidarity. In this sense, the completion of a monetary union is necessary and essential for an integrated economic and monetary policy. I would like to sincerely thank the co-staff for their work and I welcome the introduction by this text of a safety net which allows for coordinated intervention in the event of an economic crisis in a Member State, not only for the benefit of that Member State, but also as a means of avoiding chain reactions in the euro area. Unfortunately, this European Monetary Fund remains an intergovernmental purpose, guided by the rules set out in the Stability Pact. Without Parliament's decision-making mechanism in the management of this Fund, nor the monitoring mechanism, it will be in line with the austerity policies implemented in particular in the management of the Greek economic crisis. Without co-decision, transparency and democratic participation, the logic of the pay-maker will constitute poor governance of monetary policy and we will once again know the disastrous consequences of these policies on public services and child poverty.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. Chairman, at the very beginning of this report it is stated that the introduction of the euro is one of the most significant political achievements of the European project. How for whom. Maybe we should ask the Greeks or the Italians?  However, it is true that the euro has been useful for the political project itself because it has further centralised Europe and reduced the room for manoeuvre for Member States. The same will happen with the establishment of a European Monetary Fund, which represents another integration step. The creation of the European Financial Stability Facility and its transformation into a European Stability Mechanism were logical moves in the context of the terrible financial crisis and the need to stabilise and make the eurozone more resilient.  The Initiative establishing the European Monetary Fund actually wants to make crisis mechanisms permanent and reinforce the role of supranational structures in the supervision and management of financial assistance programmes in the future. There's really no need for that.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Mr President, the creation of the European Monetary Fund is a logical continuation of the stability mechanism established after the financial and euro crisis, when it was clearly noticed that the Member States were unable to voluntarily take care of the Stability and Growth Pact and, even at the time of the crisis, the financial capacity. It therefore forms a whole with sixpacks and twopacks, and it will be essential in future to form an independent operator operating under Union law and not under the decision-making power of the Member States. Its tasks must include taking decisions and decisions on the basis of mutually agreed principles and legislation. I believe that this is necessary when we look at stability over a longer period of time. Or do you think – hand on heart – the Member States will decide on the same criteria and with the same rigority on the aid package for germany, France, Malta and Cyprus, for example? If we really want a mechanism that has market forecastability and, by extension, credibility, we need, in the longer term, a monetary fund with an independent status, without any case-by-case consideration by the Member States. Well, at this stage, we are where we are, in decision-making, and logically we have already moved on from the previous state of the Stability and Growth Pact, but there is still significant work to be done on this issue, as with the development of EMU as a whole, in the future.

name: Jens GEIER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The European Commission's proposal to transposition the European Stability Mechanism into EU law is all well and good, because that is the only way to guarantee democratic control by the European Parliament. The Council should not put this important issue on the back burner. It is clear that the current governance structure of the eurozone needs to be further developed, and that a eurozone budget with a stabilization function is needed to cushion asymmetric shocks. A eurozone budget must be part of the overall budget of the European Union, there must be no duplication or ancillary structures. That is why it is also clear that there can only be a meaningful eurozone budget if the multiannual financial framework provides for appropriate resources for it. That is why the ideological fixation on 1% of the European gross national income of some Heads of Government is wrong in the negotiations for the multiannual financial framework. Anyone who wants the EU to deliver must also give it the means to do so. It must not be taboo to finance the EU budget with real own resources. It would be economically sensible and politically intelligent to use the revenue, for example, of a European-coordinated financial transaction tax or a digital tax to finance the eurozone budget.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I welcome the work towards the establishment of the European Monetary Fund in order to ensure greater responsibility for the development and monitoring of financial assistance programmes for Member States. A European Monetary Fund should have greater responsibility for the development and monitoring of financial assistance programmes, however, it would be important that decision-making remains firmly in the hands of the Member States.  The next EU budget can help to foster sustainable growth, put in place more effective reforms and help us to build a better society that improves all our citizens’ lives. I think the future of the Economic and Monetary Union should look to strengthen financial stability and regain public trust. Priority should be given to the completion of the banking union and strengthening the European Stability Mechanism (ESM). Additionally, focus must be put on the development of the capital markets union, which has huge potential to provide for a new mechanism for financing our businesses and can be complementary to the EU investment plan. I welcome a number of provisions in this draft report, including that participation in this initiative should be possible for all Member States and not just for the eurozone. Additionally, I welcome the calls for the ESM to have sufficient expertise and for the governance framework to be assessed to ensure an effective decision-making procedure. I welcome the initiative Parliament is taking in putting forward its position on this issue, given the relatively slow process in Council and again, not for the first time, Parliament is showing initiative in the interests of citizens.

name: Alfred SANT
text: – Mr President, progress on the establishment of the European Monetary Fund (EMF) will remain problematic unless the fundamental political divide that underpins the decision is faced and resolved.  Crucially, the eurozone needs to improve and enhance the institutions that oversee its operations and protect it from the effects of crisis. This will inevitably oblige some centralisation of institutions and their functions.  However, there remains a profound mistrust among Member States, not least the smaller ones – but not only they – that proposals being made go in the sense of federalisation, which they do not want or which they consider premature.  Insisting that the European Monetary Fund should be integrated as of now in the Community method exacerbates this tension and hampers forward movement. The report claims that an intergovernmental arrangement would slow down the European Monetary Fund. Perhaps it is better to have a slow EMF, initially, to one that remains work in progress.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Economic downturns and downturns are the standard in the free market economy, ba, they also have a healing effect on the economy and doing business. Trouble arises when the downturn turns into a recession. Then not only companies and state budgets are suffering, but above all – and this is the biggest damage – citizens.  The European Union therefore needs a smooth, strong instrument for stabilising periods, cycles. Moreover, the countries of the European Union need support during periods of economic downturn or, god forbid, recession. Transforming the Intergovernmental European Stability Mechanism into a European Monetary Fund could therefore be a good solution. Personally, I would not argue for a name, other matters are more important: firstly, the transfer of member states' powers to the Level of the Union, secondly, the abolition of the unanimity requirement in favour of a qualified majority, of course, a strengthened qualified majority, and thirdly, it is also important who could be the beneficiary of the support from this fund. The European Monetary Fund should also provide a common protection mechanism for the Single Resolution Fund.  To conclude, I am convinced that the mechanism we are talking about must be permanent and very strong in the European Union. Then we will be able to count on its effective operation.

name: Inese VAIDERE
text: – Dear Chair of the Sitting! Honourable colleagues, I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs and express my satisfaction that, once again, we have also been actively working on politically sensitive issues that the Council has not yet resorted to. I support the reforms of the European Stability Mechanism (ESM), which are very important to us if we want to be forward-looking and think about instruments to prevent economic crises in a timely manner. Of all the Member States, only 19 are in the euro area. This makes it difficult for European monetary and economic cooperation when the economy is at risk or other unfavourable macroeconomic factors are at risk. A model of cooperation should be established in which all Member States can adopt rapid and effective solutions for the provision of assistance. The European Commission's proposal provides a good basis for creating such a model. The European Monetary Fund, whatever its name, will be very important in integrating it into the legal framework of the European Union to help countries in difficulty, and it is important that The Member States have a say in this. It is also important that its functions do not duplicate the functions of other institutions. However, this is little to do today if we want an effective and transparent decision-making mechanism. The Instrument Box for the Stability Mechanism, including democratic accountability to both the European Parliament and the Member States, must be increased. By expanding the range of instruments, it will be necessary to find a golden middle ground between solidarity between Member States and, of course, responsibility. Member States in difficulty will have to take greater responsibility for their own citizens and for other European citizens.  I therefore agree that reforming the European Stability Mechanism should place greater emphasis on support for Member States rather than banks, from which it is sometimes problematic to hold accountable. We must be open to ourselves and to the people. The discussion clearly shows that Member States have a different view of the future of the ESM, but this discussion is a good basis for the reform mechanism to be improved.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I have been listening carefully to your exchange of views and it’s another example of the vitality of the discussions on the Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) deepening. We can only support such reflections about the future completion of the architecture of the EMU. The work is far from finished. We believe that our European Monetary Fund proposal is a step in the right direction, and let me reiterate why this is the case. First, an integration of the European Stability Mechanism (ESM) in the Union’s legal framework would bring the benefit of a better articulation of financial stability support to Member States in crisis, with a framework of economic policy coordination and supervision of the financial sector. The Commission, Council and ECB play a key role in that regard. It would also allow for the ESM’s accountability to be enhanced at the European level, next to the national level, and increase its democratic legitimacy. Clearly, the ESM actions not only concern individual Member States in receipt of assistance but the euro area as a whole. Moreover, it would allow for an increase in transparency and a judicial review of its actions, as is the case for Union institutions. Let me also emphasise that the integration of the ESM in the Union framework would also be an acknowledgment of the importance the ESM has gained since its creation. Let me conclude by saying that, regardless of how the ESM will work in the short to medium term, it is clear that the Member States and the ESM must respect existing tasks and roles set out in the EU treaties, without this affecting the balance of competences between the Union and its Member States.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: I don't know what I' – Mr President, I thank my co-rapporteur Peter Silva Pereraz for his excellent cooperation. I thank the shadow rapporteurs, as well as our advisers and colleagues, for their excellent work.  I would like to point out that the Member States cannot deal on their own with systemic risks that threaten the financial stability of the European Union. This is not only about the profitable firms mentioned by Mr Marušík, but also about the shocks that these profitable firms can suffer in a globalised economy and, together with them, to take entire regions, states and problems into other countries. We need to have the tools to deal with such threats. The current intergovernmental nature of the European Stabilisation Mechanism reduces its ability to respond effectively to economic and financial shocks. Therefore, the future integration of the European Stability Mechanism into the Legal Framework of the European Union will strengthen its capacity for action and efficiency. Until this happens, we call for meaningful reform to be carried out in the short term through the revision of the Treaty on the European Stabilisation Mechanism, without prejudice to more ambitious developments in the future.  There's no individualism in place here. Only by working together will we bring greater certainty and stability for the euro area and, ultimately, for the whole of the European Union.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, March 14, 2019, at 12.00 p.m.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the report by Markus Pieper, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of competition in the air transport sector, repealing Regulation (EC) No 868/2004 (COM(2017)0289 - C8-0183/2017 - 2017/0116(COD)) (A8-0125/2018).

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We are a Europe of freedom and values, we are a Europe that stands for fair competition, and we are a European Union that is strong whenever it holds together. American tariffs on European cars, Chinese cheap imports of steel and aluminium. If the Union stands together, Trump & Co will do nothing against our industry. Of course, this only works with the right foundations, in other words with trade agreements between the European Union and all parts of the world. We now have such a basis with the new 868 regulation to ensure competition, including air transport, in other words in an area to which WTO rules do not yet apply. What is it all about? In other parts of the world, airlines are subsidised by the state, partly to a degree that distorts competition. Global market shares have already shifted to the detriment of EU airlines, despite increased efficiency and structural changes in airlines. Therefore, if distortions of competition give rise to complaints, then we in the European Union must become concrete, with concrete measures against subsidised dumping airlines, but also with appropriate reactions when non-European states or regions discriminate against our airlines, for example in terms of landing rights or clearance. The 868 Regulation allows investigations to be initiated even if damage is imminent or discrimination has only been announced but has not yet occurred. The fact that the Commission can take action even in the event of imminent injury is a deterrent. It is to the credit of the European Parliament that Directorate-General TRAN is already taking action in the event of imminent injury, i.e. not only in the event of damage to be proven. We achieved this in the trialogue negotiations. And only then will the 868 Regulation get teeth. It is now a real deterrent instrument that, if things go well, we will never have to use. The 868 regulation is thus also a diplomatic instrument for Europe and its Member States, which alone cannot defend themselves against discrimination. However, if we deal with the EU-28 together, we will also have global influence in air transport. The answer to "America First", "Gulf-Airlines First" or "China First" is "Europe together". Thank you to the Commission for the good presentation. Thank you to the Council for the difficult but fair negotiations. And thank you, ladies and gentlemen, who have contributed greatly to this. We now have a strong building block for a strong and resilient Europe, another strong building block for a strong European Union.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. I am able to represent the Commission on behalf of my colleague, Mrs Bulc, mrs Bulc is ill, but I am grateful that the discussions are taking place here this evening in this constructive way. I would like to thank Mr Pieper very much for his role in advancing the report on this and the content in Parliament, and I thank the technical committee for the essential content that stems from his work. Both the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs have done important work here.  The adoption of the new regulation on the protection of fair competition in air transport is a major milestone in the implementation of our European aviation strategy, which was adopted by the Commission four years ago and which can now also find a legal basis here. This legislation is a core element of our instruments for fair competition in European aviation and in foreign policy with other countries when it comes to fair competition. The changes in this sector of the transport of people, goods and goods in aviation around the world are considerable. This makes it all the more important to have a common European policy and instruments that are given to us so that we can organise and guarantee fair competition for all airlines. We are talking about air transport to and from the European Union, and at present we currently have half of our airlines based in the EU and competitors who are at home in third countries. We accept and value this competition, but also connectivity, regardless of who guarantees it.  For flights to the EU, third-country carriers have our guarantee that certain European rules will apply to them in the same way as to EU companies. As the EU, we want to guarantee fair competition on equal terms. However, we note that unchanged – in part, increasing – EU companies outside the EU do not always find the same fair conditions, but that discrimination and discrimination can take place there. We in the Commission, with the support of this House, are pursuing the idea of competition based on a multilateral framework and globally harmonised rules, but neither the WTO nor the ICAO directives are realistic for fair competition in the near future, and that is why we, as the EU, are currently negotiating comprehensive air transport agreements with third countries that deal with this fair competition. To date, flights between the EU and third countries have been largely regulated by agreements concluded by individual EU Member States. However, an appearance with 28 or 27 EU countries towards third countries does not seem very wise, and that is why the regulation that is now to be agreed for the EU provides the basis for a credible and efficient instrument with which we can combat and adequately tackle unfair practices in the interests of our Member States, our citizens, jobs and air carriers.  This regulation, which you have before you this evening and which you helped to shape, is fundamentally different from its predecessor, which dates back to 2004 and which was inefficient, in fact not really practical. The current regulation is adapted to the specificities of today's aviation sector and is clearer, more effective and more efficient in its procedures. We in the Commission continue to attach great importance to negotiating air transport agreements with third countries. In its relations with its partners in third countries, the EU will always prefer dialogue and negotiated solutions over unilateral measures.
