In this sense, I think today is an important day for fair competition between EU companies and third-party companies, and also for our citizens, who can and should fly with both.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: Verfasser der Stellungnahme des mitberatenden Ausschusses für Wirtschaft und Währung. – Herr Präsident, lieber Kommissar! Seien Sie erneut in diesem Parlament willkommen!  Mr President, in the context of increased competition between air transport operators at global level, fair competition, with a level playing field, is an indispensable general principle that the EU has to push for. Calling for the same rules and fair competition for all carriers cannot be labelled as mere protectionism. Just as I have been calling on some European carriers to restructure and to stop receiving state aid, I now call for more financial transparency and clearer rules regarding third-country carriers’ operations in Europe and their investments in the EU. Europe represents 500 million potential passengers for third-country air carriers’ routes to Asia. They fly to Europe to feed their respective hubs and fill their planes. Increasing traffic towards Asia should be borne in mind when the Commission is negotiating comprehensive aviation agreements with the rest of the world. I believe the EU should link the financial transparency clause in the aviation agreements to third-country investment in EU airlines. If third-country airlines receive subsidies, why should they be able to control EU airlines achieving the same results? This, to me, is not fair competition.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, thank you very much. A warm welcome to Commissioner Oettinger. I hope he wants to convey our greetings to Violeta Bulc. She is back on the mend I understood today via the app, but nonetheless. I would also like to thank my colleague Markus Pieper for the hard work he has had to do to bring this matter to a successful conclusion. And the funny thing is, Mr President, that this dossier has still been terminated under the Austrian Presidency. But we are apparently a little late to discuss the outcome of the trialogue here. It is clear, Mr President – my colleague from the ECON Commission, but also the Commissioner has already said it – we have a very important dossier here at the headline, which has a lot to say about internationally. Moreover, the dossier has become even more important in recent months. We see different nationalist tendencies in the world. It is a major task, including for the European Union, to keep international air travel open. It's easier said than done. But keeping international air travel open in a fair market – and that is what we are talking about here tonight – is very important. There's quite a lot of unfair competition. And there's also illegal state aid. This is not just about kerosene and about runways. It is not only about Arab countries, but also when we look at China, Hong Kong and even Singapore, our European airlines are facing unfair competition. I hope that this dossier can improve that position and put it in a fairer position.

name: Gabriele PREUSS
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report The foundations of our prosperity in the EU are fair competition and social balance. This also applies to international aviation. So, as legislators, we must protect our companies and workers from unfair practices with clear rules in order to secure long-term skilled jobs throughout Europe. Unfortunately, we are living in an era of trade conflicts, and only with sufficiently deterrent instruments can we ensure fair rules for Europe in global competition. A revision of Regulation No 868/2004 was therefore urgently needed. On the Council's side, however, a bizarre picture has emerged in parts. It was simply inconceivable to me that a group of states actively opposed such a trade defence instrument and wanted to give unfair subsidies to EU airlines, only to maintain the ideological paradigm of the supposedly free market. It is therefore a great success for us as a Parliament that we have been able to draw up a robust legislative text for European aviation. We now have an effective instrument to protect ourselves from harmful subsidies from third countries. This is not protectionism to the detriment of passengers or connectivity, because our airlines need not fear fair competition. Across the political groups, we have reached a broad and fair compromise on the regulation, and we owe this mainly to our rapporteur, Markus Pieper, and his team. But I would also like to thank all the other contributors for their constructive cooperation.

name: Jacqueline FOSTER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, we’ve come a long way since the first exchange of views on this proposal. The original Commission text of Regulation No 868 unfortunately took a protectionist approach that would have allowed the Commission to impose penalties on third-country carriers before complaints against them had been properly investigated. This sent a hugely pessimistic signal to our international trading partners and would have globally damaged our connectivity and our reputation. The original text would also have enabled uncompetitive European carriers to complain about their competitors, giving the Commission power to punish them before reviewing evidence. Of course it’s right to crack down on unfair competition but not at the expense of damaging consumer choice, increasing ticket prices and costing jobs, as well as affecting the supply chain. However, following the trilogue, I can now support the final agreement, not least because it clarifies Member States’ competencies, for example on dispute settlements through their current bilateral air service agreements with third countries, and more. Therefore, I think we now strike a satisfactory balance, which I believe will allow the market between the EU and third countries to grow and innovate. For future reference, the EU should always take an outward-looking approach, which is more advantageous in the long term. Mr President, this is probably my final speech in this Chamber. My first was in 1999. May I take the opportunity to thank the interpreters, both here and in Brussels, the Secretariat and all the staff of the European Parliament bodies for their support and professionalism. I wish them all very well in their future endeavours.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I will start by thanking Jacqueline Foster for being very good colleague. I have enjoyed working with her and I wish her the very best. As concerns this draft regulation, I would keep three key words in mind. One is ‘efficiency’, one is ‘complementarity’ and the third is ‘dialogue’. Efficiency because finally we have an instrument of a purely trade-defence nature. The regulation will now empower the Commission to investigate if there is a reason, or rather a reason-based complaint, and on its own initiative. Efficiency also because the Commission will not have to wait for EU airlines to be affected: it will be in a position to act if there is evidence of a so-called threat of injury, and that has been one of the key issues in the negotiations. Efficiency too because we have a clear timeframe: a timeframe to investigate and a timeframe to terminate the investigation. We also have the possibility of shortening the timeframe should a matter of urgency arise. And efficiency also in the sense that the regulation provides the Commission with actual means to restore fair competition through the adoption of measures of a financial or operational nature. Complementarity: of course, the regulation as such would not make our industry competitive but, together with the comprehensive bilateral agreements that we are concluding, we have a whole system. An investigation, as it proceeds, can, at a given moment, feed in into the bilateral efforts to resolve a problem. And lastly dialogue: we will have a dialogue and consultation with all stakeholders in the Member States concerned and that through the ‘Union interest’ test. Secondly, we will have a dialogue with the partners, as I have indicated, through the bilateral agreements and their mechanisms. And, finally, Parliament will be informed in the course of the negotiations. So this is not protectionism. This is a good tool that we will have.

name: Karima DELLI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are going to vote on one of the latest regulations of this mandate for the aviation sector. Unfair competition in the aviation sector is a scourge. Take, for example, the Gulf companies: they are subsidized by their states, particularly to pay kerosene and airport charges, which is a real scandal. These practices are the cause of the destruction of thousands of jobs among their competitors who cannot keep up, and so many employees put on the hook. This scourge leads to another scourge, because every time this unfair competition causes the closure of a direct link between Europe and Asia, it is in favour of a longer, therefore more polluting, route through the new Gulf hub. We see clearly, through this aviation sector, that social and ecological issues are intimately linked. The explosion of air traffic is a social and climatic bomb. As employees, consumers and citizens, we are all victims. As I recall, the aviation sector is 3% of global emissions - the equivalent of emissions from a country like Germany. What is this text doing to remedy this? Too little, I'm afraid. The evil is deep. Air reform is a huge challenge. We saw, during the Paris agreement to save the climate in 2015, that the sector was even excluded from the negotiations. But what makes me sad is to see Europe today submitting to a global system that refuses to take its part in the fight against global warming. However, we have voluntary countries in Europe, ready to take up the problem of aviation head-on, and which are now putting several solutions on the table, such as the creation of a kerosene tax or the ban on direct mail flights, as was recently done between Brussels and Amsterdam. Commissioner, we no longer have time to wait for the airline industry to reform itself. It is up to us, the European legislators, to take these challenges hand-in-hand and meet them. The aviation sector is an economic challenge, a social challenge, but it is primarily a climate challenge. On this climate challenge, the Commission is too silent.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, this proposal for a regulation has a number of issues that we do not follow. Built in the context of the single market and the European aviation strategy, it is part of the EU's vision that promotes concentration in the sector, facilitating the creation of European aviation monopolies. A strategy that contributed to the degradation or destruction of flag companies, which fueled the privatization processes of the sector, both airlines, infrastructure or services such as assistance at scale. This process results in severe damage to countries, but also to workers who have seen their labour rights and precariousness in the sector significantly degraded.  It is in the sacrosanct competition that this proposal focuses, based on a dichotomy between european and non-EU companies in the single market. It seeks to interfere in the organization of the sector in foreign countries, creating conditionalities for the authorization of operating companies that have state subsidies. Nothing new. They also interfere with national strategies for the aviation sector.  Omitted are the consequences of so-called competition between EU-based companies and the single market to foster so-called low-cost companies that add up to profits at the expense of the degradation of the quality of service, the assault on workers' rights, as often as in breach of labour laws. These are bigger reasons for rejecting this proposal.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as we know, within the European Union we have strict and strict rules on fair competition in order to protect access without discrimination to services for all companies.  However, we find that the same reciprocity is not always guaranteed in other countries and that it is difficult for our authorities to take compensatory measures or to carry out checks on measures taken outside the Union, even within the framework of bilateral agreements between the parties.  I therefore think it is important that action be taken to revise Regulation (EC) No 868/2004 and to introduce more concrete and effective measures, both in terms of initiating investigations and in terms of repair measures, especially when we consider that the current regulation has never been used. If we want to protect our citizens' right to connectivity and want to ensure fair competition for our companies and industry, it is therefore absolutely important that we have effective and effective control instruments.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The regulation says that unfair competition is one that involves receiving privileges and subsidies from the government. Well, bravo, I agree with that. This is unfair competition when you take taxpayers' money and give it to a company, because it's money that actually comes from theft. Only that we are in the European Union. We do nothing else here, we subsidise everything: agriculture, transport, students, NGOs, and at home and abroad, so we also subsidise aviation. A few years ago, the European Commission agreed that my country, my government, would steal taxpayers in Poland and support Polish Airlines. In Europe, too, airports favour their favourite carriers, so it is very inappropriate that we see a blade in our neighbour's eye, and we do not see the beam in our own. However, it seems that the report was written under the dictatorship of the airlines and not out of a sincere desire to protect competition.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Air passenger transport is a huge driver of the European economy. In recent years, we have seen a significant increase in connections within both the European Union and to third countries. The market is growing rapidly in the shadow of competitive pressure from outside the European Union. The sources of this pressure lie, inter alia, in the competition for access to emerging countries' markets and the increasing process of globalisation. Major competitors for European airlines, for example, have been carriers from the Middle East, which have enormous capital and offer a high standard of connections at a relatively low price. In addition, they do not necessarily have to comply with EU regulations, which on the one hand facilitates their rapid development and expansion, but on the other hand absolutely distorts competition.  I agree with all my previous previous members, who say that we should make every effort to ensure that new agreements with emerging and strategic markets are concluded precisely in the light of the fair competition clause. An efficient system of compensatory measures is needed to ensure a level playing field for European airlines, and I believe that this regulation will be a tool that will strengthen the European aviation industry. Remember, however, that in the end it is the passenger who chooses the airline. This is determined by both the price of the ticket and the quality of services, the certainty of travel and the timeliness. I hope that the airlines that we will strengthen – European airlines – will have this absolutely in mind. Respect for the customer is very important and can not be covered by even the best regulations. (Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska refused to answer the question asked by raising the blue card by Dobromir Sośnierz)

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: –Mr President, colleagues, Commissioner, I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Pieper, on obtaining interinstitutional agreement on one of the most important dossiers on the future of air transport at European level. Union airlines are at the heart of a global network that connects Europe both internally and with the rest of the world. It is therefore absolutely necessary for us legislators to protect the aviation sector by means of tools and mechanisms that penalise unfair practices of companies in third countries, but also ensure effective connectivity. Such practices, as in the case of State subsidies, can seriously distort competition in the air transport market. As regards air transport activity at European level, it must take place in an environment characterised by open and fair competition, taking into account, however, very important aspects, such as working conditions, service quality standards, but also environmental protection. Finally, as co-chair of the Intergroup for the Development of European Tourism, I would like to send a message to European companies and draw their attention to their own business practices, which often cause them to lose to companies in third countries. My recommendation is to stop discounting the quality of the services they offer for an additional profit to the detriment of the interests of passengers and to maintain a balanced value for money. Europe must remain at the forthgoing global level in terms of both quality of service and quality standards, as well as passenger safety and social conditions offered to employees.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Competition in the aviation market is not only needed but also expected by passengers, but must be carried out on a sound basis that excludes illegal practices by third countries towards European carriers. The European Union must have the tools to defend itself against unfair competition from airlines that benefit from various forms of subsidies or administrative barriers directly affect competition from Europe.  I believe that this regulation offers a chance to eliminate such practices unless it is applied hastily and to the obvious detriment of passengers. Above all, however, we need comprehensive international solutions that will ban unfair practices on the aviation market. In open skies agreements with third countries too, we need to put more emphasis on this element. Only then will this phenomenon be effectively eliminated.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, Regulation 868 must certainly be implemented, because that is the only way to stop unfair competition from third-country companies, companies which have actually found the opportunity, also because of the inaction that existed in the European Union, to compete unfairly with European companies. However, there must also be competition at home, on domestic flights. And I wanted, Commissioner, Mr Oettinger, to highlight once again the issue with aegean airline, which is literally a monopoly in Greece, and there are expensive tickets. From Crete to travel by air to Athens, you pay more than you pay the ticket from Athens to Berlin. This also applies to expensive tickets to the Aegean islands. There must also be measures in these matters. I have reported it since November 2018. I haven't gotten an answer. We cannot have this monopoly status in Greece, with expensive tickets from Crete to mainland Greece, from the islands to mainland Greece.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, I was concerned when the debate started with the rapporteur saying ‘if we all get together, we can take on China and Trump’. I thought, ‘hang on, where are we going with this?’ But then I saw ‘safeguarding competition in air transport’, so I thought ‘this must be alright, we’re going to be okay, it’s about free trade, surely’. Then the Commissioner started off by, first of all, congratulating us on a constructive debate before we’d started – which I thought was kind of him – and then went on to a list of shiny new rules of things they want to do. Now I find out really, after listening intently all the way through, what this is about, actually, is taking away individual deals that have been done and the EU taking on the negotiating. You’ve noticed that some of the countries in the world give state aid and boost up their airline, so you think, ‘we are going to get back at this, we’re going to dip a few quid in ourselves’.  What it turned out to be was nothing to do with free trade but everything to do with state aid, and I’m a little concerned that maybe the whole competition part of this was a misnomer and maybe it was just about helping with state aid.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, as MEPs, we probably fly more often than most people in society and obviously we have a huge interest in air transport. It is important that it should be competitive, both for us and for everybody. It was through the work of the European Union that the emergence of many of the low-fare airlines came about. Ryanair is an airline that I fly with regularly. Years ago, when there was no Ryanair, flights were costing hundreds and hundreds of euro. Then the fares came down dramatically: all the others, including Aer Lingus, our own passenger airline in Ireland, are now competitive. The point being made here is that they must be competitive on a global level as well. Especially, I think we must look to eliminate any bad practices in third countries, and I agree completely with the Commission on trying to do that.

name: Seán KELLY
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I take a broad as-opinion of your speech as far as you have done in the draft regulation, by your rapporteurs, by Mr Pieper, by the Council and by the Commission. Some of the speeches have mentioned problems that are true. This regulation does not solve all the problems, but it is a great step forward towards fair competition in the interests of airlines based in the EU and also in the interests of those who want to participate in this competition from outside but who should observe the same rules, and ultimately also in the interests of passengers, namely citizens. , from consumers who, on this basis, can choose and book low prices for good performance among different competitors. A clear vote by Parliament will bring the process to a conclusion. There is still a lot to be done for my colleague, Mrs Bulc, for the Commission, to do a great deal for you in the area of completing an aviation market of tomorrow. Once again, however, we are taking a major step in the right direction with today's draft regulation. Thank you very much for your support!

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Dear Günther Oettinger, whether energy, household, today's transport – always convincing. I would like to thank my colleagues for their genuinely supportive contributions and also for their concrete support. Once again, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs from the other groups, all the staff of the negotiating teams and, of course, our assistants.  I am pleased that all the EU countries are obviously pulling together here and that we have also succeeded in allaying the fears of some smaller countries. This was about ensuring accessibility and accessibility in conflict situations. But we have also found a solution to this in the regulation. I am also pleased that it was Parliament that gave the regulation a stronger impact. If the Union can intervene now in the event of imminent injury, that is precisely the difference from the old Regulation (EC) No 868/2004, which has remained ineffective here.  Ladies and gentlemen, all in all, tomorrow will be a good day for European airlines and a good day for a resilient Europe. If we stand together in Europe, in the Union, we can stand up to the egoisms of corporations and nations.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, March 14, 2019, at 12.00 p.m. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Written. – It is good that European Transport Commissioner Violeta Bulc is considering improper state aid to airlines from outside the EU, but in the meantime she is completely forgetting workers' rights within the EU. Airlines such as Ryanair, which knowingly violate the labour rights of their pilots and cabin crew, can continue to fly around Europe undisturbed. That has to stop. Price fighters who flout the rules and hide in another Member State must be tackled, for example with a landing ban or by preventing the opening of new bases. That puts the race down on wages, work schedules and workloads for aviation workers.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. The European Union is finally tackling the unfair practices of airlines from third countries. Until now, European airlines have been confronted with an offensive strategy by their state competitors in the Gulf countries, which jeopardized the viability of a sector that employs more than 300,000 people in Europe and generated 123 billion euros in profits in 2016. We have built up a space without internal borders, but that does not exempt the aviation sector from strict rules. Anti-competitive practices must be combated if the millions of citizens who fly to travel can benefit from them. This report is a game-changer, as the European Commission will see its prerogatives increased to investigate potential unfair practices and impose countervailing measures to repair the damage, if it is in the interests of the Union.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the report by Monika Hohlmeier, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2020 budget, Section III – Commission (2019/2615(RSP)) (A8-0172/2019).

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I would like to begin by thanking you very much, a thank you to my shadow rapporteurs, who have worked hard with me to draw up good guidelines and, in particular, to set priorities for 2020. It is not an easy year because this year, on the one hand, is the transition to the multiannual financial framework and we must try to make a sensible transition. Secondly, it is not an easy year because, in the Brexit vote, we are moving from one disaster to the next, so to speak, and ultimately we do not know what is to come in the end, and thirdly, because we face major challenges – on the one hand, the promotion of competitiveness, jobs, social prosperity within the European Union, then challenges in the area of development aid and in the areas of migration flows and people. , which suffer a great deal in other countries, and thirdly, of course, issues of security, that is to say internal and external security, and issues relating to the fact that we want to protect our citizens as much as possible.  I would simply ask, Commissioner, that you also respond in particular to our wish, particularly in the area of Erasmus and youth, because we firmly believe that only if young people have safe and good jobs, if we have an industry and an economy that is able to offer competitive jobs, and we want to invest in these technologies of the future, so to speak. , want to educate young people well, but also want to enable them to get to know other countries as part of their training, to get to know their European neighbours, to have contact with them, and to promote these programmes in particular.  We also have programmes where the success rate in the area of Horizon Europe is quite low, and I repeat it – I think I repeat myself slowly every year, and somehow I get a little tired of repeating it – because I actually want programmes like COSME, programmes such as Future and Emerging Technologies, where we sometimes have up to 97% rejection rates, not because the programmes are bad. , not because the projects are bad, but because we do not receive enough money from the Member States – and I also hope that young people in the European Union will have promising jobs, jobs in which they can find social protection, sustainable jobs, and that companies will be able to encourage and support investment in this area. I believe that this is our core mission to fulfil these two tasks, to promote young people so that they are well qualified on the one hand, in such a way that it is permanent, and, on the other hand, to support jobs and innovation in such a way that sustainable jobs can be created here in the European Union, competitive with other countries on the planet.  I hope that this year – and I am quite frank in this regard – we will meet Member States that are not talking to us again in the last three days; since the Council is not here today, I am still saying this into the microphone and put it in the Minutes, because it would make sense if we did not discuss the essential issues with each other at three o'clock in the morning, but could perhaps agree on essential content beforehand, even if that is only in the next parliamentary term. Nevertheless, I would like the Council to deal with this budget as early as possible, and I would be very pleased if the Commission took our priorities into account.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. With your debate today, you are opening up the budget discussions for 2020 – a special year, firstly because it is the last year within the framework of our 2014-2020 budget, and secondly because we have uncertainty with Brexit and no one knows today whether our UK colleagues want to participate in the budget next year with all their rights and obligations. , which they adopted unanimously with us in 2013, including in the Council, and thirdly, because we have a year of change, a year of change in Parliament and also in the Commission. This makes it all the more likely that we should contribute to stability, so that budgetary programmes have a positive effect on the development of Europe and that the objectives we have in common are also supported and achievable with European money. I would like to thank Mrs Hohlmeier for her wise preparatory work, which consists, on the one hand, in bringing together the different expectations of the political groups, of colleagues in the committees, here. This is not easy year after year and all the more difficult in the election year. I would also like to thank the Members who were prepared to get involved and not to campaign around a position of Parliament, and I also thank her for the fact that her objectives, those of Parliament, are basically those that are also seen by the Commission. A year of change. You are now responsible for Parliament's position. I am confident that the next Parliament does not see this diametrically differently, but builds on it. That is why I hope that as many people as possible in the next Parliament will feel responsible for budgetary policy, that is to say, will be re-elected – from the rapporteur to many others who could bring their powers to budgetary matters and could also contribute to the next Parliament. The change in the Commission is an equally exciting question, because the concilication period will in any case start with the Juncker Commission on 29 October, may end with the next Commission on 18 November, or, if we have to stay longer in our tasks, because you do not accept the next Commission on time, with the Juncker Commission. Let's wait and see. In any case, I believe that continuity in the matter is very important for the stability of Europe. "A bridge to the future Europe, investment in citizens, innovation and security" is the title chosen by Mrs Hohlmeier. I think it is a smart title that will convince citizens of the added value of Europe and European finances. Our common priorities are still competitiveness, economic growth, better and more jobs and living conditions, research, the young generation, the fight for ecological developments and the fight against climate change. And we share the view that promoting economic growth and competitiveness is a very high priority. The last six years have been, by and large, good years for the European economy. Year after year, economic growth was higher than initially predicted. Year after year, we had more tax revenue than the estimate predicted. Year after year, the number of jobs has been increasing, unemployment and youth unemployment have fallen – far from sufficient, and much remains to be done. But the last six years have been good years. And, according to all the forecasts, economic development is now gloomy. All the more reason why a 2020 budget must have instruments that are used against stagnation, against recession, against a crisis, for economic growth, for jobs, for prosperity, for competitiveness within the framework of our limited finances. From COSME and our SMEs to start-up funding for innovative minds in the European Union, from Erasmus+ to our intercultural skills, from cybersecurity to the fight against climate change and for nature conservation, we have a wealth of programmes that are heading in the right direction and that must now be decided and strengthened within our limited resources. And in doing so, we need as much flexibility as possible. Parliament and the Commission should fight together, and in part also against the Council, to ensure that flexibility can be taken in a timely manner and that we can respond to the challenges and tasks that we face next year. We will then ensure that there is a sufficient level of payments, particularly in cohesion policy. Everything that has been done should be paid, made by payments, so as not to see a wave too much into the next decade. to be transferred. The Council adopted its guidelines in the Ecofin Council on 12 February, and today and in the next few days you will be the second budgetary authority to supplement your guidelines and priorities. As the Commission, we will do mediation work as far as we can in order to reach the best possible agreement between the Council and Parliament. The spring trialogue on 20 March is the first opportunity for this. Once again, their priorities are almost identical to those of the Commission. I thank you for the good preparatory work and for the fact that you have all been able, unable to mix the election campaign with what we all have to do in terms of craftsmanship for the 2020 budget in the interests of our citizens – thank you very much.

name: Seán KELLY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, my thanks and congratulations to Ms Monika Hohlmeier, my colleague, and also to Commissioner Oettinger, who is doing such good work on this portfolio, as he did on the previous portfolio on energy. I remember that well. It’s good to have good people leading us and they should be given credit.  It will be important that the 2020 budget sets out the right direction for the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). For this reason, we must ensure that it sets out the key priorities we wish to achieve over the next decade. The budget must be strong, it must be well financed and it must be forward looking, as the Commissioner mentioned.  I welcome the rapporteur’s focus on innovation and research, an area I have been very much involved in in my time in the European Parliament. This is paramount to the EU’s continued growth, job creation in the 27 Member States and indeed the enhancement of our global competitiveness. I welcome the importance the rapporteur has given to successful programmes, such as Horizon 2020, Competitiveness of Enterprises and Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (COSME) and digital investments.  Secondly, I welcome the prominence given to the climate challenge. We have a big challenge ahead to ensure that 2030 targets are met – we discussed those this morning in the presence of Commissioner Cañete – and that we implement the measures needed to ensure that the EU remains at the forefront of climate action. Indeed, it has shown great leadership again during this Commission, starting with the Paris Agreement a few years ago. Without sufficient funding for these actions, we will not achieve anything. Through the very successful programmes and instruments, the EU budget can help to mobilise the actions needed. This has been successful in recent years, with European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), for instance, alone having delivered 35 750 gigawatt hours of additional electricity, 90% of which is renewable. Additionally, it has ensured 5 000 gigawatt hours of energy savings per year. Its successor, which I’m involved in, will also help to make that a reality into the future. InvestEU is a big programme and it will build on EFSI and, indeed, we are actually in trilogues on that at the minute.  These results show the value of an ambitious, strong and adequately funded EU budget. I hope that we can continue this into 2020 and set the agenda for the finalisation of discussions towards the new Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2021-2027.  Finally, I concur with the Commissioner in his reference to Brexit. It is extraordinary that only by 308 votes to 302 they decided not to crash out of the European Union. There will probably be a big deficit in our budget and I hope that the other Member States will see the sense of filling that gap so that, collectively, we can do the things we really want to do and can do better collectively, rather than on an individual basis.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: question “carton bleu”. – A Sheáin, is dócha go gcuirim fáilte go bhfuil tú ag léiriú an oiread sin spéise, go háirithe i gcúrsaí aeráide, ach dá mbeadh aon eolas agat i ndáiríre ar chúrsaí buiséid, thuigfeá nach bhfuil ach méid an-bheag curtha i dtaisce i gcomhair cúrsaí aeráide ach ní leor é. Ach an cheist atá agamsa i ndáiríre ná, cén fáth gur dhiúltaigh do ghrúpa agus gur diúltaíodh dúinne do dhaoine óga teacht isteach os comhair an tí seo chun labhairt ar chúrsaí aeráide? Agus cén fáth go mbíonn do ghrúpa agus do pháirtí de shíor ag vótáil i bhfábhar airgead ón mbuiséad a chaitheamh ar bhreosla iontaise seachas a bheith ag caint ar ghnéithe eile de, conas mar is féidir linn maireachtaint i bhfad níos fearr gan é seo? Chuireann sé sin ionadh orm. Mar sin, b’fhéidir go dtabharfá léiriú dúinn ar cén tuairimíocht atá laistiar de sin.

name: Seán KELLY
text: blue-card answer. – Probably, being truthful, it’s political point scoring, but we can handle that fairly well. I can say that my Group here in the European Parliament, I’ve been involved in climate change, I represented Parliament in the climate agreement in Paris. I was involved in the renewable energy file as rapporteur, so my credentials in climate change are better than anyone’s probably, certainly from the speaker’s point of view.  And secondly, I just want to say that my party as well in government, right now, under our new minister, is actually at the minute preparing our climate and energy plans, which are going to be very ambitious, and also the 2040 targets have put in at least 25% for climate action. So both Fine Gael, my party, our government in Ireland and the EPP Group here in Parliament are leading the change in a very practical way for climate change.

name: Karine GLOANEC MAURIN
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is obviously a great pleasure for me to carry the voice of the Socialists and Democrats in the preparation of this 2020 budget, the last of the multi-year financial framework. This has not escaped anyone: the context is special, since it precedes our common deadline for all, on May 26th. It honours us, but it also obliges us. Defining the European budget is not, in fact, a simple matter of numbers. Drawing the outlines of an appropriate budget is essential to translate our political priorities into a concrete picture. What we are advocating is a budget that enshrines investment in a sustainable and inclusive development report. For, yes, it is possible, no displeasure to the bearers of populist and nationalist rhetoric, who dress their discourse with false truths and lies. First of all, I would like to thank Monica Hohlmeier, our rapporteur, because she has made quality initial proposals, budgetary guidelines which have enabled constructive compromise work and which have given each of us negotiators the opportunity to feed a constructive report for a sustainable European future. The priorities that have guided the work I have done on behalf of my group are as follows. The first is to strengthen the social dimension of the budget by being very vigilant. There are a number of important things. First, the future of the youth employment initiative, a program that has already proven its worth and continues to help thousands of young people outside the traditional channels to move into the labour market. Secondly, the preparation of the effective implementation of the European social rights base from the 2020 budget. Then, the promotion of policies of inclusion and the fight against all forms of discrimination, but also the enhancement of cultural policies and policies in favour of youth and citizenship, such as Erasmus or as a creative Europe. Nor should we forget, it is important, to protect European citizens and to respect the commitments made in the fight against climate change under the Paris Agreement. We must also increase our vigilance in defining a migration policy that focuses both on the origins of flows, by pursuing development policies in the countries of origin, and on the integration of refugees on European territory, without merging this aspect with security issues. The second priority is to strengthen the anticipatory dimension of supporting this budget in the face of all the changes facing Europeans, in order to avoid the stagnation of our economy, as the Commissioner said, while stimulating competitiveness and sustainable, green and inclusive growth for a society of solidarity. The third priority is to provide all the solutions to avoid the new payment crises, as the Commissioner said earlier, and I do not hide from you that the latest information on Brexit is causing real concern. The fourth priority is the use of all the opportunities and flexibility instruments in the MFF and the current financial regulation to develop a strong and ambitious budget. It is time for the Council to take responsibility. To be pro-European in speeches is honourable, but to be pro-European in fact is more engaging, and it is indispensable today. Therefore, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the proposal for this 2020 budget that we are carrying today is not only responsible but also a bridge to the next MFF. It is up to all of us, European legislators, you, the Commission, and above all the Council, and with it, to make it concrete.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this may be my last budget. One thing is certain, however, for meds in the current Parliament, this is the last budget to prepare. As you all pointed out, this is also the last budget of the 2014-2020 Multi-Year Fiscal Framework. In such a context, including Brexit, the effort could have faltered, but it was not, and I thank our rapporteur, Monika Hohlmeier. I will express our support for the guidelines and lines of force it proposes for the 2020 budget. We wholeheartedly welcome the desire to have instruments and means to stimulate and support strategic investments, particularly in the digital and artificial intelligence sectors, for the benefit of European economic growth and the creation of quality jobs. We support the demand for additional resources for programmes such as COSME and FET (future and emerging technologies), which undoubtedly contribute to the success of start-ups and the development of small and medium-sized enterprises. We strongly support the strengthening of the resources for Erasmus, the youth employment initiative, the European Solidarity Corps, Commissioner, whose barely created it has already attracted 93,000 applications from young Europeans. Congratulations on this idea. We also wholeheartedly support Mrs Hohlmeier's emphasis on the need to provide the necessary payment appropriations as early as the 2020 budget to avoid the mountain of late payments that we had to resolve in 2014 and 2015. I have lived through this period and I have bitter memories of the Council's insensitivity to the serious problems that these delays have caused for companies, research centres, researchers and ordinary citizens. We support the necessary strengthening of the means to ensure better control of our external borders, to intensify the fight against smugglers in the Mediterranean, and to improve the conditions for the reception and integration of those who need our protection and to whom we have a duty to grant asylum. We support the additional budgetary efforts that we must devote to strengthening our security, domestically, on the one hand, by enabling the many instruments and agencies we have created to operate effectively, while ensuring scrupulous respect for citizens' rights, and externally, on the other hand, by giving substance to the efforts finally undertaken to lay the foundations for a coordinated defence capacity at European level. Three more concerns to conclude. Research and innovation, as you all said, are the keys to the economic future of our society. Our words are not followed by deeds. Today, Europe is ahead of South Korea, Japan, the United States, and soon China, in terms of the share of GDP devoted to research and development. I cannot understand and I do not accept the attitude of the Council which, by refusing the application of Article 15, paragraph 3, of the financial regulation, has not authorised for this year's budget the appropriations available for the Horizon Europe programme, because of the non-execution of certain projects. Such an attitude is unacceptable and must change. On the other hand, we must step up the fight against global warming, young people shout it in the streets, we proclaim it envy in our debates, our seminars and our publications, and yet I must note that, over the period 2014-2020, we have not devoted the 20% of the total budget that we have agreed to spend on it to protect the environment and combat global warming. This is not acceptable and it has to change. Finally, I want to break a spear in favour of increased support for our budget for UNRWA, the UN agency responsible for helping the few million Palestinian refugees. Donald Trump has suspended U.S. aid to UNRWA. We must not become as ugly as Mr. Trump.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for this report on the 2020 budget guidelines, the last budget in the current MFF and a budget that should be a bridge to the next MFF. On many aspects it can be a good starting point for the upcoming negotiations. For instance, the report is right when regretting that the Union is falling short of our climate goals, and that we are not even in a position of achieving the moderate 20% target of climate-related spending. This morning, we’ve heard here in the presence of young climate activists a debate on the need to take action against climate change. These engaged youngsters asked for urgency in delivering a climate-neutral economy based on renewables as soon as possible, but we are not delivering, not in climate change mitigation, not in halting biodiversity loss and time is running out. That’s why we need a much greener budget, that’s why we need climate-mainstreaming and climate-proofing. That’s why we need to act once and for all in accordance with the Paris Agreement and the SDGs.  The report is also right when calling for a higher social ambition in the next budget. Yes, without social cohesion, there is no union of equal citizens. We need more resources for the Youth Employment Initiative, to fight against poverty and for the integration of migrants. We need to deliver on the pillar of social rights, because social rights are also European added value.  It is also positive that the report underlines the need to bolster innovation, technological transformation and digitalisation, but the report is wrong in insisting on the need to fund defence through the EU budget. The defence spending that many of you see as a priority will be inefficient. It won’t address in the correct way problems of fragmentation, duplication and overcapacity, and there are indeed other much more pressing priorities to be covered by the EU budget.  Finally, a word on the procedure. Members of the Committee on Budgets and Commissioner Oettinger will surely remember what happened with Article 15.3 of the Financial Regulation during the last conciliation. This time, from the very beginning of the budget negotiation, we say very clearly that we want this provision to be used. This time we shouldn’t be fooled again. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for taking the question. I’m intrigued by the answer to this one, because I heard you say the word ‘more’ a lot, and this is a really ambitious and big budget that’s being put forward, it’s forever growing. Do you think there could ever be a time when the EU budget would actually shrink or stay the same, or do you think, like Mr Creosote in the Monty Python sketch, it’ll just keep on eating and eating more taxpayers’ money until eventually one day it just explodes, because it has had so much money in it? I’m intrigued to see if you think it’ll just continue to grow.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you very much for the question. That could trigger a long debate and maybe we could go into the details of the next MFF. Of course, budgets cannot grow forever, because resources are limited, but a budget has two sides — expenditure and income — and we have to approach also the income side of the budget, which will be the way that will allow us to increase, little by little, not in a huge way, the resources, the budget, that the EU needs; because I believe in a stronger European Union — contrary to you —, and for this I think we need more resources and more budget.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. – A Uachtaráin, ar an gcéad dul síos, ba mhaith liom go mbeadh sé de bhéasa ag an gCoimisinéir Oettinger éisteacht le cad atá á rá agam mar tá sé tábhachtach go n-éisteodh sé le Feisirí seachas a bheith ar an nguthán nó seachas a bheith timpeall an tí ag caint le daoine eile. Tá sé maslach nach bhfuil tú ag tabhairt éisteacht dúinn agus an chéad uair eile a bheidh tusa os comhair ár gcoiste, gach seans nach mbeimid ag éisteacht leatsa ach oiread.   Ar aon chuma, cé nach bhfuil sé de bhéasa agat, táim chun labhairt leis an gcuid eile dos na feisirí anseo. Tá dúshlán ollmhór os ár gcomhair, go háirithe de bharr Breatimeacht. Táim an-sásta le Monika Hohlmeier agus leis an gcoiste agus an méid oibre atá déanta acu agus mo chuid leasuithe isteach ó thaobh tacú le síocháin an Tuaiscirt agus le Interreg. Agus táimid ag lorg go mbeadh leanúnachas ann don tacaíocht sin, mar go háirithe le Breatimeacht, tá dúshlán ollmhór os ár gcomhair.  Caithfidh mé a rá, níl aon rud tugtha i ndáiríre do chúrsaí aeráide, tá sé sin léirithe cheana féin, agus tá i bhfad an iomarca airgid - agus aon phingin atá dul i dtreo cúrsaí míleata is pingin an iomarca é. Nílimidne mar thír atá neodrach sásta glacadh leis sin. Ach arís, mar a deirim, beadsa ag caint leatsa nuair a bheimid istigh sa choiste mar gheall air seo. Chomh maith leis sin, tá ár n-iascairí - tá dúshlán ollmhór dóibhsean, tá dúshlán dár bhfeirmeoirí. Agus nuair a bhíomar ag caint mar gheall ar na plans a bhí ag an gCoimisinéir i dtaobh Breatimeacht - na contingency plans seo - ní raibh aon rud suntasach ann i ndáiríre mar an rud a tharlóidh, cé go mbeidh eitleán againn, níl aon parachute ann. Bhí sé go léir ag brath ar ‘má aontaíonn na Sasanaigh linn’, rud atá ag teacht chun cinn anois nach bhfuilid ag aontú le haon rud agus go mbeimid i gcruachás ollmhór. Mar sin, níl a fhios agam go díreach cad iad na rudaí praiticiúla atáimid chun déanamh mar choiste buiséid nó mar bhuiséad an Aontais Eorpaigh chun dul i ngleic leis na dúshláin atá againn de bharr Breatimeacht. Táimid ag druidim níos cóngaraí is níos cóngaraí. Gach seans nach gcoimeádfaidh siad leis na coinníollacha a bhí acu agus nach mbeidh siad ag íoc isteach fiú amháin i gcomhair 2019, gan trácht ar 2020. Mar sin, fágfaidh mé ansin é, tá mo chuid ama imithe agus tá áthas orm go bhfuil tú faoi dheireadh tar éis tosú ag éisteacht liom. Go raibh maith agat.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, unlike the previous speaker, I don’t mind the Commissioner being on the phone. He might be on the phone to his bookies placing a bet on some of the things in this and I’ll get round to what I think is quite a wild bet in a moment.  This is a really ambitious budget proposal. There’s lots of extra spending. What have we got here? It talks about Erasmus getting lots more money, more money for free movement, more money for the administrative budget and of course military spending — you know, that thing that we were told in the UK wasn’t real and was a dangerous fantasy. There’s lots of that, but then there’s something in paragraph 28 that I think is really important. The UK will pay up its share into these schemes, you say. Well, at the moment, nobody really knows what’s going to happen. Yes, okay, you’ve been fortunate. You’ve got Theresa May, who throws money like confetti because she frankly doesn’t know what she’s doing and you’ve got the Labour Party that would love to come in and be friends with you. All of this probably means you’re making a good bet there but, on the other hand, there is chaos at the moment. As anyone who turns on to the BBC Parliament channel or reads a British newspaper will know, there’s complete chaos and it could well be that these jaded old parties with their pathetic, timid leaders may well crumble and split into independent pieces, and then you might get someone who listens to what the British people are saying and they are not quite so keen to throw billions and billions of pounds as a farewell gesture, when there are problems at home that need looking at and issues at home. So yes, I understand why you’re taking a gamble with this and why you’re spending such huge amounts on the expectation of British money, but I do think you’re being a gambling man and you’re all counting on something that no one can be absolutely sure of. So, be careful with that because the British might just say ‘non’.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. We are discussing the 2020 budget and this is an extremely difficult and complicated budget for the whole of the European Union. Mrs Hohlmeier's thanks for taking up this task are all the more to be said.  Why is this budget difficult? Firstly, this is the last budget for the 2014-2020 perspective, which really means even a greater flow of invoices for projects that have been carried out in previous years. We need to be aware that, over time, 2020 will be the year of increased spending on some of the projects that have already started. Secondly , this is the last year – from a financial perspective – which is in a very precarious and unclear situation with Brexit. As my honourable predecessor said, we are in chaos, and the budget must therefore be designed in such a way that it can be adapted in some way to an unpredictable and chaotic situation. It is not inconceivable that the 2020 budget will have to be modified depending on the situation that will be with Brexit. Thirdly, it is a budget that is actually being prepared in parallel with the work on the new financial perspective. And what is interesting about this budget is that, in fact, this budget introduces certain elements as early as 2020, which we are working on for the years after 2020, and therefore today, as if the rapporteur shows us that there are certain elements that need to be done without waiting for the first january 2021. It therefore draws particular attention to the need to strengthen projects – i.e. actions – on pro-development actions such as Horizon 2020 and Erasmus. We are talking about this in a new perspective, that this needs to be increased – even three times in the case of Erasmus – but already in 2020 we need to go down this path. Similarly, it is very interesting that we are entering the path of defence – in the programmes preparing the future defence fund, in other words – 2020 is really a preparatory year for the new financial perspective, not just a closing year. Similarly, when we talk about innovation, about modern solutions, and also about climate issues. In other words, 2020 is, on the one hand, an uncertain, unclear situation when it comes to Brexit, on the other hand it is a matter of increased spending, and at the same time building a bridge between 2014-2020 and 2021, and in this sense this budget is an extremely challenging one and will have an impact on the next perspective.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: Mr President, I would first like to thank Monika Hohlmeier for listening and making the necessary compromises. The 2020 budget is the final stage of the 2014-2020 multi-year fiscal framework and, once again, Parliament will commit itself with determination and conviction to impose its priorities. Speaking of which, dear Mr. Etheridge, I regret to tell you - I think he's gone, too bad! That, contrary to what you have said, the European Union's budget has been shrinking steadily since the 1990s. Commissioner, I am speaking to you. I would so much like to be wrong, I would love to see an end to this absurd tussle between Parliament and the Council. I would so much like, Commissioner, that the Commission does not systematically place itself in the intergovernmental logic on budgetary matters. I would love to be able to assure us with conviction that Parliament will commit to stopping this budget, if and only if funding for the fight against climate change increases in line with the commitments made in this multi-year fiscal framework 2014-2020. I would so much like to be able to ensure that the 2020 budget will be able to strengthen the financing of the integration of migrants and asylum seekers and to end the UNION's funding for the outsourcing of our immigration policy. I am so worried about the European project and I would so much like to be able to promise that the new challenges will be able to benefit from new funding, that Parliament will not accept that the new priorities are financed at the expense of solidarity policies. I would so much like that Brexit does not, once again, be used as a pretext to cut the EU budget. I would like to convince you so much that gender-based budgeting is broken and that there is an urgent need to accelerate this process for gender equality. In conclusion, I wish Mrs Hohlmeier all the courage to ensure a budget that lives up to the ambitions we are displaying and not to reap nothing but crumbs. Mrs Hohlmeier, there is indeed work to be done.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: – Mr President, of course I have my written prepared talking points which say that the Guidelines report contains many important priorities, such as youth employment, research, as well as climate spending. The key problem is the strong emphasis on defence spending. On that sentence, I shall put away my prepared notes and say that, personally, I am different from the Greens and not so worried about defence spending, because good defence can serve us quite well at a certain points in time.  Allow me please to speak from my heart now, and it’s perhaps not so much about budget. I would like to point out, contrary to Ms Ní Riada and Mr Etheridge, who said that the Commissioner was not listening, but actually Mr Oettinger was receiving information about Brexit through his left ear, and listening to us through his right ear, so dear Mr Etheridge — where are you by the way, are you listening? Ah, no — learn to multitask, otherwise you’ll never become a Commissioner. So now I go to my budget experience and say it has been a great honour to serve on the Committee on Budgets, to learn from Mr Deprez, Mr Olbrycht, Mr Fernandes, from our great rapporteur, Monika Hohlmeier, and Ms Gardiazabal and many others. Even from Mr Kölmel, by the way, he is a good economist, but we never actually delivered as much as we had hoped on climate change policies. And now my final point is that, on this very Friday, the school strike for climate comes to Estonia for the first time. My son will be among the participants, my father, a former Member of this Parliament’s Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, will be there and will give his support as a climatologist. Where do you think I shall be? Of course, I will be with them. And that is why I will go there and I will introduce the ALDE amendment which puts the specific nexus between future trade agreements and the Paris Agreement. That’s great. Bravo for ALDE.  I will finish now, I know we are late so let me just conclude. As Mr Deprez said it might be his last budget speech, and so might it be mine as well because, you know, times are scary, but in climate change, we will find a way and I shall not melt away as an iceberg in the Antarctica, whatever anti-Europeans may think.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the 2020 budget really is a difficult budget and, at the same time, demanding. Because we are all aware of the challenges created by Brexit. But we need to focus on how this budget will pursue policies that empower young people and women. Priority should be given to innovation, research and development. To have sustainable growth with jobs, that means supporting youth employment. Young people, who have now come back to the fore as they fight for the environment. And we welcome the mobilisation of young people across Europe for the environment, because they give a decisive signal. Young people who need to be supported by Horizon 2020 for research institutions, for academia, to have opportunities in education, so that there can be much more funds in the famous youth employment initiative. And, from then on, of course, all European Union policies must support women and we must bear in mind, Mr Oettinger, that we should strengthen the policies of the European Union that take into account gender mainstreaming. This is very important if we are to finally be able to move towards gender equality.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Your comments today enrich the work of the Commission, because we are currently preparing our draft budget for next year, which we intend to present to you in a few weeks' time. This is the purpose of Parliament's position, including that of the Council, and that is what we will build on our proposal. In this respect, I take Parliament's expectations seriously that we will include Brexit implications in the Commission's draft budget. We will know more in the next few days, perhaps tomorrow. And rest assured, the 2020 draft will be based on whether the UK's friends are prepared to participate in the 2020 budget with all their rights and obligations, or whether Brexit without a deal will lead to the conclusion that there will be no deposits from London next year, but also no participation in programmes. Our legal view is independent of this. We believe that the budgetary framework will be binding on all 28 Member States by the end of 2020, that it was adopted unanimously in 2013 and that therefore all legal means should be used to achieve obligations and rights by the end of 2020. Nevertheless, according to the precautionary principle, we could then present a draft budget in the late spring, which will be drawn up without the British and without their deposits and disbursements. In other words, we would then be short of EUR 12 billion, and we in the Commission must close this gap with our proposal. I am not going into detail at this time about the development of the 2019 budget. However, it may be that, in a few days' time, we will have to present to this House an amendment, a kind of supplementary budget for the current financial year, in order, for example, to fill in a funding gap of EUR 6 billion – EUR 12 billion next year, six billion this year. And you know as well as I do that the only level in Europe that has no right to take on debt is the European level. The Member States have the right and the opportunity to take on debt, the regions as well as the municipalities. At European level, we have an absolute obligation to finance our tasks and expenditure through revenue every day, and the road to the bank is and remains blocked. Once again, perhaps in a few days' time we as the Commission could be forced to start deliberations, to make a proposal on how we will make up for six billion this year and how we will make up for twelve billion next year. I will come back to this House and the Council as soon as we have a little more clarity from London. Incidentally, for a Brexit gap in the budget framework over the next decade, as a Commission, we have always proposed my formula to make up for the Brexit gap at 50% through cuts and 50% by slightly higher deposits. If the formula seems comprehensible, fair and convincing, then it can also be the formula for 2019 and 2020. Six billion this year would have to be compensated by a supplementary budget in the form of three billion slightly higher deposits and in the form of three billion made by cuts, and the twelve billion next year with six billion through cuts and six billion with higher deposits. Mrs Riada criticised me for being on the phone for a short time. In fact, I could hardly believe the result in the House of Commons and therefore asked. But I mean, I have listened to at least two-thirds of her speech, she listens to me to zero percent. The Commission does not deserve any respect. But it is clear that democracy takes place in a credible way when one criticises and accepts the answers in attendance, and vice versa. Mr Etheridge, with all the weight he has and which is considerable, has been arguing here about an incredibly high level of European budgetary expenditure. A clear sentence for our citizens: every european citizen who earns EUR 100 through his or her hands, through head work or through investment, will give up EUR 50 of the EUR 100 – through taxes, levies, fees and contributions. That is the national quota of Europe, an average of 50%. And of the 50 euros, one euro comes into Europe's budget, 49 remain in London, Paris, Berlin, Rome, Glasgow, Stuttgart or with social security systems. One in 50 is Europe, 49 are the Member States, the regions, the municipalities, the social security systems. That is why I believe that Europe should at least be worth this one euro of 50 to us, especially if Europe can use it to finance and realise added value. And the Added value can be seen in Erasmus+, for the benefit of a young generation that is experiencing and getting to know Europe at the right time, in major research projects where no Member State or university, not even the best, nor Cambridge and Oxford, can compete on their own against Google and against Silicon Valley in general and against the Chinese. I would like to hope that the friends from the United Kingdom will continue to cooperate with Europe in the field of research. This is what the researchers in Oxford, Cambridge and London want, so that Great Britain does not become Little England in the field of research despite excellence. Added value is the crucial task of European programmes, of every euro we invest at European level, and this is due to Parliament's expectations and also to the Commission's proposal, which I am convinced will bring in the spring. I think Mr Olbrycht's idea that 2020 is, on the one hand, the last budget of the current budget framework, but also a bridge budget to the next budgetary framework. Some programmes are already testing programmes for a modern budgetary framework in the next decade, and we should take this into account in the further discussions. Thank you very much for your speeches, thank you very much for coordinating Mrs Hohlmeier. We will weigh up very carefully what you are deciding, we will also make it largely our basis and then come up with our proposal in the late spring, which will hopefully not include all of them in dramatic, if dramatic, consequences from Brexit, as it could then happen. I hope that as many of parliament's budgetary experts as possible will also be in the next one. And I would like to thank those who do not return for many good conversations. I take Mr Tarand, for example, if he does not come back. I think his collegial and fair manner across party lines was decisive. Thank you very much for that.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has First of all, thank you very much for this very intensive and good discussion. On Brexit, I honestly admit that I was appalled by a result of 312 votes to 308. For it was a question of whether or not to produce a completely disordered mess. And I find this to be something almost spectacular to me and almost a disrespect to friends among friends who have worked together for many years and championed common goals. Nevertheless, there was then a four-vote majority.  I hope that a little bit of common sense will come in, because Britain is not only interested in Horzion Europe. Britain is interested in cooperation in particular on security issues, and more recently the UK is interested in many types of cooperation. Suddenly, when things get away, you realize how important they are. I hope that the sensible forces will still be right and that we will still have an opportunity to develop an orderly cooperation.  I would like to say one or two sentences on what has come from the shadow rapporteurs. I believe that our essential task is to really stand together with the Council and also to strengthen the Commission's back if we are to pursue the necessary finances for our important priority areas. I understand that the Greens – almost like a Pavlovian reflex – have an anti-defence policy, but to make the claim that all expenditure in Europe is double and triple that of the Member States is precisely the wrong intention expressed here to the outside world.  We have the intention to use synergies and not to do everything twice and three times and fourtimes, but to implement projects together, for which otherwise everyone would have to carry out individual research, with individual tenders each country would have to spend more money individually on itself than if we jointly implemented corresponding research and projects together. I would also like, ladies and gentlemen, to have the courage to stand together in the key core areas at such a difficult time at times of European times, not to allow ourselves to be divided, because if we, as a Parliament, face the Member States and defend our position, then we have a chance to achieve a great deal and perhaps to awaken some of them. , that one should not only count against each other in static figures, but also actually see and use the added value of the expenditure that we can generate with each other.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the discussion on the basis of the statement of the Vice-Chairperson of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy - Situation in Nicaragua (2019/2615(RSP)).

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, thank you for this opportunity to discuss the situation in Nicaragua and for the excellent cooperation over these weeks. The European External Action Service and the European Parliament have been working hand in hand, showing in practice, how different institutions can work towards the same goal. Let me also thank honourable Member Ramón Jáuregui for his strong commitment and for heading the European Parliament delegation to the country.  The situation in Nicaragua remains tense. Although the most visible part of the violent repression has passed, there are still so many political prisoners unlawfully arrested. Several of them face charges of terrorism for having taken part in demonstrations. Jail conditions for a number of prisoners are unacceptable. Civil society organisations and independent journalists are continuously harassed and many have had their legal status cancelled.  The European Union has been clear in condemning this state of affairs, most recently in the January Foreign Affairs Council conclusions. We have called on the authorities to free all political prisoners and ensure due process and decent conditions for all. We have urged for a genuine dialogue to be resumed and for political reforms to be enacted. We are ready to use all our policy instruments in response to developments in the country.  The ad-hoc Delegation of the European Parliament, led by Ramón Jáuregui, accompanied by our head of delegation in Managua, has greatly contributed to amplifying these messages. I’m glad that you managed to have a full programme of meetings with the opposition, civil society organisations, independent journalists and families of victims and prisoners to visit inmates without any restriction and to engage in a direct discussion with President Ortega and his wife, President Murillo. I understand that many of these encounters were heavily charged and emotional, and that it took a lot of courage and stubbornness to organise them, but they were necessary and important and we are truly grateful for your work.  Some recent events give us some hope and I am convinced that our work has contributed to creating a more positive climate. First, the Government of Nicaragua held high-level meetings with the Organisation of American States, with some international actors and the business community. Second, 100 prisoners were sent home under house arrest. This was one of the requests that the European Parliament’s delegation had made to President Ortega.  Finally, meetings with the opposition started on 27 February. These initial meetings led to the adoption of a roadmap, setting rules for a negotiation process and identifying participants. The possible inclusion of witnesses and international guarantors for the agreements to be reached remains a sticking point, as do possible re-conditions related to a further release of prisoners.  We are available to consider technical support to the mediation, should that be necessary. The UN, the Organisation of American States and possibly the European Union might be asked to be involved in the process.  Although these are encouraging developments compared to a few weeks ago, we remain very cautious. We still do not know how serious the government is about restoring fundamental rights, as enshrined in the constitution, in particular, freedom of assembly and expression. Heavy police presence in Managua is maintained.  The change of the penitentiary regime for 100 prisoners is a positive step, but we do not forget the over 600 prisoners who remain in jail, often in inhuman conditions and some of them on hunger strike. Nor will we forget that all the accused must enjoy due process and justice as guaranteed by the constitution of Nicaragua. This is why the Civic Alliance is pressing for prisoner’s rights and their release.  We need to see how far the government is willing to go in opening up to the opposition demands and to engage in political reforms. The partisan management of the regional elections on the Caribbean coast of Nicaragua a few days ago did not demonstrate a willingness to do things differently. I hope that a renewal of the Supreme and electoral courts in April will not be another missed opportunity to change course.  We must also salute the work done by the opposition in learning from the mistakes of the failed dialogue in July 2018.  We hope more result-driven negotiations will enable all Nicaraguans to feel represented, find justice and, eventually, cast their votes freely for the future of their country.  So, despite the legitimate doubts that we may have about this nascent process, despite the open wounds and the many victims still seeking justice, we should all encourage the steps currently being taken. We now expect a negotiating table and further concrete signs from the government side, as this is the best way to achieve a peaceful way out of the current crisis.  We Europeans will remain vigilant and ready to react to any further deterioration of human rights and the rule of law, and we will continue to accompany any positive step towards a political solution to the crisis, together with our international partners. Let me thank the European Parliament once again. Your engagement will continue to be precious in the weeks ahead.  (Applause)

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow the European Parliament is going to vote on a resolution requesting Nicaragua's suspension of the Central American Association Agreement and, at the same time, the introduction of selective sanctions for all those responsible for the serious human rights violations that have occurred in the country.  During our visit, Commissioner, to which you referred, in January, the European Parliament was able to see — as other international missions have already done, the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights, the group of independent experts, the high representative of the United Nations, who, by the way, have not been able to return to the country — that the situation in Nicaragua is not compatible with the human rights clause , which is an essential element of our Partnership Agreement.  In the resolution adopted by our Parliament on 31 May, we have already found the murders that had taken place, arbitrary detention, torture and the disrecognisement of all fundamental rights, including the right to freedom of the press.  You were right, Commissioner, that our visit to Nicaragua's prisons was particularly emotional. It's hard to see 20-year-olds sentenced to more than thirty-thirty-five years in prison.
