Unfortunately, the information we receive from Managua is that, indeed, as you said, there are still more than six hundred political prisoners.  The women we meet in La Esperanza prison are on hunger strike for ill-treatment and several prisoners have also been mistreated in Model Prison.  I believe that we would serve the cause we are defending, Commissioner, and that we would disappoint the expectations of the people of Nicaragua if we were complacent about this situation. It is therefore imperative that, in order for this national dialogue to succeed, the unconditional and immediate release of political prisoners, the cessation of harassment of the opposition and the guarantee of the exercise of fundamental rights and freedoms, including the right of freedom of the press, and which can be achieved, Commissioner— has not yet been achieved. , a roadmap for the citizens of Nicaragua to re-own their destination and to take the floor.  I believe, Commissioner, that in this Parliament we have done a very dedicated job, with great patience, but the time has come, Commissioner, to move from words to deeds. Unfortunately, the situation has not suffered or experienced a positive development in the country and I believe that we must be consistent with the principles we practice. E week we had a debate on a mechanism for the implementation of the democratic clause in the House.  The case of Nicaragua is a paradigmatic case, Mr President, and I urge the Commission to be consistent with the decision we are going to take tomorrow in this Parliament.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, I would indeed like to begin by thanking the Commissioner for his words on the cooperation between the European Parliament and the European External Action Service in this area. I'll start by making you a little confession, if you like, intimate. The whole delegation of the European Parliament, which visited Nicaragua for four days, lived excitedly — even with a feeling of great compassion — everything we saw and everything we heard. And I want to begin by claiming that this Parliament is with the people of Nicaragua; with the people who mourn their dead; with the people who suffer because their children are in jail; with the people who suffer restrictions on freedom. This is a bankruptcy, very serious, very serious, absolutely condemnable, of what we call the rule of law and the conditions of freedom and democracy. This is happening in Nicaragua. I would like to address my colleagues on the left, who have made an amendment to our resolution saying that there is no interference from the United States in Nicaragua. No ladies and gentlemen, there's no interference. The problem, Mr Pimenta, if I may, is that there is a revolution that has become totalitarian. Excuse me, there was a revolution that has become totalitarian. There was a revolution that was historically explained and unfortunately crushes freedoms and crushes its people. I have always claimed freedom from the left. "Socialism is freedom," we have always said.  And the European Parliament supports these people. The European Parliament supports serious dialogue. I hope there's a serious dialogue! But it has three basic conditions that are not being met. The first is that political prisoners must be released. The second is that there can be no restrictions on freedom, that there has to be free movement for leaders, for social movements. And the third is that international organizations have to return to the country, because they are respectable and are the credit and observatory that human rights are fulfilled.  And the European Parliament's political position is that if that dialogue moves forward, as the Commissioner said, Europe will help. I'm telling Commander Ortega. If there is serious dialogue and there is a path to freedom, we will help. But if they don't, if they want to waste their time, if they deceive the people, there will be sanctions.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, Commissioner, the opposition to daniel Ortega's authoritarian regime has many faces. One of those symbols is called Alex van Vanegas, former athlete. As a young Sandinist, he fought with Ortega against dictator Somoza. Unfortunately, however, the liberation of one dictator brought another to power. Now Alex walks again, but out of tribute to the victims of the police brutality. The people call him "el maratonista", the marathon man. For Ortega, however, he is a terrorist and a coup-plotter, as is the other symbol, the young student leader Amaya Coppens. 24 years old, a compatriot of mine. We visited her in the prison "La Esperanza". "Show what is happening here" she says, and she asked, "because we don't want Nicaragua to be the new Venezuela". She just ended a 13-day hunger strike. This is her homemade bracelet in the national colors, white and blue. Admirable, courageous and strong. I received a letter today from her father, her Belgian father. Harrowing situations. People like her are the future of her country. You won't let that future languish in a cell. Ortega has chosen the path of repression, censorship and violence. That path is dead. The only way out is for the political prisoners to regain their freedom. This is the prerequisite for a new national dialogue. There must also be new fair elections. We have all said this to President Ortega personally, but the pressure, Commissioner, must be stepped up. It will have to be tangible in the form of targeted and individual sanctions. We have an association agreement. There's a democracy clause in there. I count on us to be true and faithful to our principles and that our treaties are more than a piece of paper.

name: Javier NART
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr. President, Sergio Ramírez, Henry Ruiz, Luis Carrión, Dora María Téllez, Monica Baltodano, Jaime Wheelock, Víctor Tirado, Moisés Hasan, Ernesto Cardenal, Hugo Torres, Gioconda Belli, Brooklyn Rivera, Carlos Tonnermann, Humberto Ortega... All of them are radical opponents of the government of Daniel Ortega.  For those who understand that this Government is a victim of the reactionaries to the salary of imperialism, I will illustrate: they are my fellow Sandinistas fighting Somoza, against the dictatorship of Anastasio Somoza, where I was and where I was wounded on the southern front Benjamin Zeledón. It was an honor to be there. They are commanders and ministers of true Sandinism, today betrayed by Daniel Ortega; they are the ones who, from the barricades, from prison, from persecution and torture, defended and today continue to defend freedom, democracy and dignity for their Nicaraguan homeland, which is also mine.  I will recall that, of the six members of the National Directorate, five are against the regime—the Sandinista National Directorate—as are all members of the 1979 Revolutionary Governing Board, like thousands of fellow Sandinistas. They are the true Sandinistas, today persecuted by Daniel Ortega for defending what they defended yesterday against Somoza: freedom and dignity.  Repression, exile, hundreds of dead, corruption, violation of human rights, that is today Daniel Ortega's Nicaragua, defended, from sectarianism or ignorance, by salon revolutionaries to the last Nicaraguan, of course. Because they don't care about Nicaragua, but their own myths, their own stories, the revolution of others, but never their own.  The motion for a Resolution to be presented tomorrow is the result of a general consensus. It requires the suspension of the European Union Agreement with Nicaragua and the imposition of personal sanctions on Daniel Ortega and that Government which suppresses and imprisons its own colleagues, its own people.  And, from the bottom of my soul, I say what I said in 1979: Long live free Nicaragua!

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, listening to some of the speeches, we often ask whether we are talking about repression and prisoners in Spain and France. The European Union and the European Parliament insist on manipulating facts and thickening the Trump Administration's interventionist strategy of interference and destabilisation throughout Latin America. You know that the social security reform proposed in Nicaragua aimed to ensure its sustainability and at the same time to avoid implementing the neoliberal recommendations proposed by the IMF. They know that the wave of protests, regimenting legitimate expectations and the population's aniggities, was manipulated and orchestrated by sectors of the more reactionary right, deliberately provoking violent and dead clashes. They know that this wave of violence was directed not only against the authorities and the government, but also against members of the Sandinista Front who were attacked, kidnapped and murdered. They are aware of the government's initiative to launch a broad dialogue that will end the clashes promoted by the opposition and build peaceful solutions. They know that the United States Government imposes sanctions and threatens Nicaragua with an economic veto, preventing access to credits from international financial organizations in violation of the Charter of the United Nations and international law.  It is because you know all this that you have only the lie left to attack the progressive peoples and forces of Latin America, as in Nicaragua, who insist on asserting the sovereignty and independence of their country, the right to self-determination, and to freely determine the course of the political, economic, social and cultural development of their countries. (The speaker refuses a "blue card" question from Ana Gomes)

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, history apparently teaches nothing, especially in Nicaragua. There in 1979, in reverse parts, it was the current President Daniel Ortega who risked his life as a guerrilla to oppose a dictatorship that stifled rights and opposition in the blood.  Now the Sandinista Daniel Ortega no longer has an enemy to fight, he no longer has a dictator to depose or the Contras and the CIA to deal with. Now he's the dictator. Meanwhile, the country finds itself torn apart by killings, arbitrary arrests, enforced disappearances, torture and all-out censorship, not to mention the constitutional reforms that have allowed Ortega to perpetuate himself in power, far beyond the limits allowed by the Constitution.  In short, nothing is missing: there are all the ingredients of dictatorship. A dictatorship that is of little interest to the world, because Nicaragua is one of the poorest countries on the planet. A dictatorship that, in order to remain in power, does not count on the support of the people, but on that of the snipers, who shoot at helpless demonstrators and kill hundreds of them.  In the light of these serious critical issues, I believe that it is necessary for the Council and the Commission to immediately activate individual sanctions aimed at targeting those of the regime responsible for the serious human rights violations that are taking place.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the document we are about to discuss certainly contains many things that we can support for a hated country which, many say, will be the next Venezuela. But there is an omission: there is no mention of a fact that everyone knows, that international public opinion knows, that it almost seems that the European Union has wanted to persistently ignore, namely the fact that this regime has for decades given hospitality to the worst terrorists, including the representatives of the Red Brigades, of the terrorism that has bloodied our country.  There is an appeal that comes from the last President of the Moro Commission, and is to return to Italy, finally, after so many appeals and so much pressure from Italy, one of the most dangerous brigadiers and one of the few still in total freedom, who has never spent a single night in his cell, that is, Mr Alessio Casimirri, who lives quietly in the parcel – but the parcel may have ended Hopefully! – is a luxury and successful restaurateur in Managua. Do not talk about this scandal, perhaps also because there has long been another Member State of the European Union that has given the same hospitality.  But then it is time to speak and speak. We call, together with the Italian Government, for Europe to demand the immediate extradition to Italy of this criminal, this murderer. It is time for Europe to wake up and put an end to the omertous attitude towards these terrorists that you have never dealt with, when the relatives of the victims of terrorism are finally demanding justice from Italy.  This is really a disgrace. You must immediately remedy this very serious omission with regard to international public opinion, the victims of terrorism and the murder of President Moro.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, please help us! That was the cry of helplessness of the prisoners of La Esperanza prison, subjected daily to constant beatings, inhumane treatment, deprived of their most basic rights and who cannot see their relatives, when we visited them last January. They're innocent. They are in prison simply for defending their ideas in a country ruled by a tyrant where peace, freedom and democracy are neither guaranteed, fundamental rights are respected, freedom of expression nor assembly is defended. Women, however, who, despite all that they are suffering, do not give up, and thus confess it to us with admirable strength.  After all they told us and what we saw, we demanded that the prison authorities, the Deputy Minister and Ortega himself not have a single retaliation. But, once again, the tyrant did the opposite and the escalation of repression continued, further increasing, until now, a month and a half later, to an unsustainable situation.  The reality of Nicaragua is extremely worrying, at least for all those who feel Democrats and defend fundamental rights not only for us but also for the citizens of any country. Since the crisis erupted in Nicaragua, more than 300 people have been killed, 1,400 injured, nearly 700 political prisoners and nearly 50,000 exiles. Don't you think these figures are enough? I personally find them chilling and I believe that this Parliament cannot remain impassive for another second. Europe has to do something. You have to act. Commissioner, the restoration of democracy in Nicaragua is also the responsibility of your Commission. The Union must be involved and firm. A regime like Ortega Murillo's cannot ask the opposition for dialogue. It's a farce. In order for real dialogue to exist, the immediate release of political prisoners and the cessation of all forms of abuse or intimidation against the Nicaraguan people is essential. That's enough. Nicaragua deserves to live in peace, and the groups in this House should thus pass it on to the revolutionary who betrayed, as has been said very well, an entire country as soon as it rises to power.  These tyrants who arrived with pseudo-democratic subterfuge to appear to have a certain patena or democratic credential are also afraid of free and democratic elections. You know why? Because they know they don't have majority support, and they're afraid of losing the privileges of their looting and unscathed corrupts. From here I defend today the imposition of specific sanctions against the members of the Government of Ortega and their henchmen. If they do not respect the principles of the rule of law, democracy and the most basic principles of human dignity, the democratic clause must be activated so that Nicaragua is excluded from the European Union-Central America Association Agreement.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: – Mr President, first of all, and although you have been absent, I would like to say to Mr Pimenta Lopes that there are no political prisoners in Spain. Spain is a rule of law, a modern and consolidated democracy, and no matter how many times they repeat it, we will not accept that they say quietly that there are political prisoners in Spain. I hope someone gives you the message.  Secondly, you could also hear that there are very few people already in the progressive world who argue that Daniel Ortega has operated one of the largest perversions that can be operated in the direction of a country, in the name of a revolution that surprised the whole world and which the whole world admired. On this revolution, Daniel Ortega has ended up constituting an absolutely totalitarian regime.  That is why this Parliament decided to act and that is why a representation of this House, headed by our colleague Ramón Jáuregui , whose task has already been praised by the Commissioner and I repeat - decided that we would have to raise our voices in this House to join it in the voice of the whole democratic opposition of the people of Nicaragua to call for a dialogue , yes, but a dialogue as long as the minimum conditions that have already been expressed by my colleagues are met: the freedom of political prisoners, freedom of expression and the stopping repression. You can't keep sitting at a table as the crackdown continues.  That is the voice raised by this Parliament and which we hope will be heard by Daniel Ortega's regime.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – Mr President, when protests in Nicaragua began in April 2018, it became obvious that these were not protests against austerity measures, but protests by people fighting for their rights and freedoms. It became a fight against a staggering democracy in a deeply polarised country. Since then, hundreds of people have been killed and more than 700 imprisoned –mostly for political reasons. Despite a government assurance that there would be no retaliation against activists, we regret to see that repression has intensified. This is reflected in our resolution. We looked at the relaunch of the National Dialogue with hope, and we regret that it has come to a halt. Therefore, we must emphasise that is not the EU which will provide a solution to the crisis: it is the Nicaraguan people who must work together to resolve the conflict. We will, however, work in pursuit of our commitments to protect human rights and fundamental freedoms in the country.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the violent repression that the Government of Nicaragua applies to its critics, the expulsion of uncomfortable witnesses, is a planned strategy to destroy the opposition. Today the rulers apply somoza's methods to their fellow citizens; the ones they fought. The members of the parliamentary mission who visited the country in January have seen this as they said today. It's time to act.  Let's put yesterday's opponents in front of the mirror of their degradation. A lasting exit to this crisis requires the release of political prisoners and an end to repression, harassment, espionage and persecution. Fundamental freedoms must be restored. Essential conditions to start dialogue. Also, as detailed in the Joint Resolution, the European Union External Action Service and the Member States should put in place a gradual sanctions procedure which, without affecting the population, signal and penalize the members of the government involved in violations of fundamental rights. It is also time to invoke the democratic clause of the Association Agreement between the Union and Central America in order to suspend Nicaragua.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I was in Nicaragua at the end of January where I met 23-year-old Amaya Coppens, a 23-year-old medical student, in the women's prison of La Esperanza. A leading figure in the April 2018 student movement, she is being held on political grounds. Although Amaya and her comrades have suspended their hunger strike, I remain very concerned about the sanitary conditions of theirs. These persons must be able to benefit from effective and independent medical monitoring, in accordance with the minimum rules of 1955 for the treatment of detainees, as adopted by the United Nations. Recently, about 100 detainees have been "released" in quotation marks, but are in fact in a residential detention regime, under constant surveillance. We need to raise international awareness of the plight of all political prisoners in Nicaragua, who are about 670. Our duty is to help them.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Mr President, a month ago in this House, as our colleague Gabriel Mato did today, the case of young Nicaraguans imprisoned in their country, in prison – oh, paradox! – La Esperanza – what a name! – was reported and who had been retaliated against for speaking to a delegation of European parliamentarians who visited them.  Abuse in Nicaraguan prisons must cease— as we all claim — and the deprivation of liberty of these young women and other political prisoners must also cease. Daniel Ortega's regime, it has also been said, has to take negotiations with the opponents of the Civic Alliance seriously and meet their minimum demands. One of them, the release of political prisoners. It must also end the press crackdown and, finally, other demands that we set out in the motion for a resolution which we will vote on tomorrow.  Since April last year, it has also been said, there have already been nearly four hundred dead and well over a thousand injured people who have claimed the crisis in Nicaragua, unseeded by protest demonstrations in front of the regime. The crisis has to be resolved through negotiations with the opposition and, as we have been demanding in this Parliament since our resolution of 31 May last year, it must culminate in fair, transparent and credible elections. Consensual electoral reform is essential for this.  I would like to ask the institutions of the European Union, Commissioner, and in particular the European External Action Service to pay permanent attention to developments in Nicaragua. It seems to me that it is already inevitable to impose specific sanctions on those responsible for the country and for these serious human rights violations that have occurred. I also believe that Nicaragua's suspension of the Association Agreement between the European Union and Latin America should be prepared. It is a question of activating the so-called democratic clause of the Agreement.  And I'm done. We want for Nicaraguans, as well as Venezuelans, what we want for us: freedom, respect for human rights, the rule of law and prosperity. And from here we must contribute to that.

name: Ana GOMES
text: "Mr President, I have lived the first twenty years of my life under a dictatorship. That's why I recognize one when I see it. And that's what I saw in Nicaragua in 2011, and last January even worse: more repressive, more corrupt and more vindictive against the Nicaraguan people.  From the streets, patrolled by military, police and militias, to prisons, ranks of brave men and women, so many young people, treaties of terrorists. They are Nicaragua's moral reserve. We will not forget them: Lucia Pineda, Miguel Mora, Ireland Jerez, Olecia Muñoz and so many more, including the young Belgian Nicaraguan Amaya Coppens who, with her companions, since 27 February is on hunger strike. So many in Nicaragua will warn us that the Ortega do not want to negotiate, they want to buy time to see what happens in Venezuela. This was proven, Commissioner, by the recent attempt at negotiation, which achieved nothing, not even the release of hundreds of prisoners of policy, and the repression was aggravated. Europe can make a difference. You have to make a difference in Nicaragua. Let's activate the democratic clause. And it is essential to impose specific sanctions on the worst responsible for the murderous kleptocracy around the Ortega Murillo, including the freezing of property and the prohibition of visas. The Ortega Murillo and their minions have to be brought to national or international justice to stop smelling like funeral homes at the center of power in Managua.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I am Portuguese, but I am speaking here today in Spanish because I am addressing in particular the many Nicaraguan friends I made during the visit of the delegation of this Parliament to Managua last January, and to all the dissidents who in their forced exile do not give up and fight daily for the return of democracy and freedom to their country.  It is to all of you that I address, especially to the fathers and mothers who have seen their children killed by policemen and paramilitaries during the protests, all the students who have their careers and their future interrupted as a penalty for their peaceful participation in these demonstrations, and those courageous men and women who, unlawfully detained for exercising their freedom of expression face immense hard prison sentences , many of them confined to inhuman and degrading cells that are not even worthy for pigs.  This is the case of journalists Miguel Mora and Lucía Pineda Ubau, the latter postulated yesterday for the Courage in Journalism Awards, whom I greet from here. This was the scenario we were able to testify to in the territory. And we were also able to confirm that the alleged coup orchestrated by the United States is nothing more than pure propaganda, used by the Ortega-Murillo regime to justify the repression and undermining of the political rights of its fellow citizens.  Once, after our visit, the repression was further intensified, Mr Ortega has to show that he does not use attempts at national dialogue as a maneuver to buy time and avoid European Union sanctions. And this is only demonstrated by ending repression, nullifying the trials of all those in prison or on a home-to-jail basis, investigating abuses committed by state forces, returning the legal personality and confiscated property of civil society organizations and allowing presidential, legislative and municipal elections to be advanced and supervised by the international community.  The European Union should apply individual specific sanctions to those responsible for the Government of Nicaragua for crimes against humanity and activate the democratic clause of the Association Agreement between the Union and Central America.  I conclude, Mr President, by saying that , as is said in my country , you cannot close a door by leaving a window open, a window which, in this particular case, can mean that millions of euros of European taxpayers can serve to finance a bloodthirsty regime that has already caused more than 300 people dead, 600 imprisoned and thousands of exiles.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Mr President, democracy is not a model of political organisation independent of the cultural context and history of peoples. There are, however, principles, which are absolute conditions for the structuring of a democratic regime. These principles and values underpinning our project, Commissioner. And so we have in our identity matrix that promote these principles in our territory and in the world. These principles are based on respect for the rule of law, human rights and the identity of peoples. It is with these principles, while others seek the goods and resources in Venezuela, that we seek to return to the Venezuelan people the voice and choice in free elections and it is these principles also that we must continue to guide our attitude towards the authoritarian regime in Nicaragua.  This is the time to trigger the mechanisms that are within our reach within the framework of international law to side with the people of Nicaragua. For democracy and the dignity of peoples, we must continue to act with determination and courage, and the resolution that we will adopt tomorrow in this House is proof of that.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I am part of a generation that, in its teens, has accompanied with great enthusiasm and great hope the Sandinista revolution in Nicaragua. I remember that every day we expected new news from that country and I remember the days when we ate, with great joy, the fall of the dictator Somoza and the victory of the Sandinist revolutionaries. And yet this regime failed its people, it was not up to its historical responsibilities. And as is often the case with the regimes that degenerate, he now resorts to disinformation, intimidation and the invention of external enemies who serve as a scapegoat for his own failures.  Like the Bolivarian regime in Venezuela, the Sandinista regime has become a gross distortion of democratic values and the founding values of the democratic left. Instead of equality, poverty. Instead of freedom, the repression of civil society and the persecution of political opponents. Precisely in the name of the values of the democratic left, and I are here a socialist, we must condemn with all vehemence what is happening today in Nicaragua. And this resolution does just that. It is a tough and informed motion, does not conceal any of the blatant violations of human rights and the right that occur today in that country. It clearly calls for sanctions against members of the government and calls for the suspension of Nicaragua's participation in the EU-Central America association agreement. And all this in the name of one word: democracy. It was in the name of this word that once a democratic revolution was made and today we can say that this revolution was a revolution betrayed in recent years.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, First of all, I would like to thank those who initiated this question, this debate, and have proposed a resolution by the European Parliament, namely colleague Salafranc and others of you who have worked on this subject. This is extremely important because what is happening in Nicaragua is simply unacceptable. The situation there is starting to look very reminiscent of Venezuela, Cuba. In short, a leftist populist regime led by President Ortega, rooted in the Cold War and guerrilla war, has ruled there for decades, corrupting the country, manipulating elections, and allowing no functioning opposition. At the moment, it is therefore necessary to release several hundred political prisoners, representatives of the opposition. These people have been arrested, abused and dozens more protesters are being persecuted to protest the war.  I think it is appropriate for the European Parliament to raise a strong voice against this action by the President and his repressive government. It is important to know that it has support across the political spectrum.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I will begin by having a replica of what a colleague on the left said, that in his youth he fixed his eyes on Ortega with hope. I lived in communist Czechoslovakia in my youth and I remember Daniel Ortega going to Czechoslovakia and hugging communist dudes and the then Communist President Gustáv Husak. So I am not surprised where Daniel Ortega led Nicaragua and where he led his dictatorship. I am very sceptical, Commissioner, that it is possible to agree with Ortega on some long-term changes to this regime. In my opinion, the only solution is democratic choice and the departure of this political brontosaurus to the junkyard of history. He is a man who has destroyed this country, who cannot bring it any future, and we should use all the pressure, all sanctions, to push Nicaragua into free elections and regime change.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, allow me to thank all the honourable Members for their commitment in helping the Nicaraguans to find a democratic and peaceful way out of the current crisis. The cooperation between this Parliament and European diplomacy has been exemplary in many ways in making the EU voice heard in Nicaragua. I would also like to thank Parliament’s President, Mr Tajani, for his personal commitment in favour of democracy and human rights in Nicaragua. We have listened carefully to the many calls from honourable Members to adopt sanctions in the case of Nicaragua. I am confident that the European External Action Service and the Council will follow and monitor the process of the political dialogue that is now under way – or which we hope is under way – and that the Council will not lose any time in adopting sanctions, be it individual sanctions or an arms embargo, the moment we see that the political dialogue process is being derailed or used to buy time in Nicaragua. Allow me to conclude by saluting the Members of this House who, at the end of January, played an essential part in helping to unlock the situation in Managua, engaging with the Opposition and the Government and passing on the strong EU message. This has helped to open up a space for what we hope will be a serious and result—oriented dialogue.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: Six motions for resolutions have been submitted to close the debate in accordance with Article 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow. Written statements (Article 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. The situation is evolving from hour to hour in Nicaragua, in what has been called 'the other crisis', compared to perhaps the most glaring events in Venezuela. The situation is worrying, but there is a glimmer of hope, and that is what I want to focus on. The negotiations are continuing in hiccups and at the moment, the opposition is not taking part in the negotiating table, but after the surprise visit of the envoy of the Organization of American States, and the possibility of the OAS guaranteeing dialogue, I hope that the situation can be unblocked and the process can resume. Because we must be clear about this: there is no other form, there is no other way and there is no alternative to dialogue. Deserting the negotiating table or using it only as a means of taking time are not tolerable options, not when hundreds of political prisoners are still in prison. And expelling international monitors trying to shed light on the more than 350 dead and 1400 injured last year is not acceptable. It will also be up to us to keep our eyes on this negotiation and on the situation in general, so as not to let political games become more important than people's lives.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Tadeusz Zwiefka, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs, on the Council Regulation on jurisdiction, recognition and enforcement of judgments on matrimonial matters and parental responsibility, and on the international abduction of minors (recast) (COM(2016)0411 - C8-0322/2016 - 15401/2018 - C8-0023/2019 - 2016/0190(CNS)) (A8-0056/2019).

name: Julia PITERA
text: deputy rapporteur. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by A year ago, we debated the revision of the Regulation on jurisdiction, recognition and enforcement of judgments in matrimonial matters, parental care and international child abduction. As the Council's work has resulted in a very extensive text, the Council's decision to ask Parliament to consult again must be welcomed.  The European Parliament supported by a large majority the previous zwiefka report, pointing out several areas that were particularly important to us: the hearing of the child, the use of mediation in family matters and the placement of the child outside the family. It is to be welcomed that all these issues are included in the final text. This is particularly important in the often difficult situation of the court's decision to place the child outside his or her biological family.  I would like to point out here that it will still be up to the court to decide whether the child will be placed in foster care, a care institution or relatives after taking into account the origin and cultural environment in which the child has previously been present. The new rules on cooperation between the relevant services will allow reliable information to be provided and for the court to take a decision in the best interests of the child. However, it is necessary to warn against a false interpretation of that provision, which is that it requires courts to issue a child of a given nationality to a family from the same country. It is still up to the court to decide whether or not to do so.  New, more detailed rules and rules for determining jurisdiction in parental care cases are also a good solution. The starting point remains the court of the country where the child is permanent, but the emergency situations described in detail are foreseen. Now the consent of both parents may also determine changes of jurisdiction, or the court having jurisdiction may decide that another court may, for the best interests of the child, be more appropriate to hear the case.  There is also a new article in the procedure for the return of the child after parental abduction, which refers to the decision to refuse the return of the child under Article 13 of the Hague Convention. It concerns a situation in which the court or office called upon to deliver the child proves that it is impossible to return for the best interests of the child. These are dramatic situations where a child experiences physical, psychological or sexual violence. This is a good record that clearly defines the procedure to be followed.  Furthermore, as requested by the European Parliament, the enforcement procedure, that is to say, the certificate of recognition of a judgment of a court in another Member State, has been abolished.  Although it took the Council more than two years to establish a common position, it should be considered that the Member States were up to the task. The Council text takes into account many possible scenarios that occur in childcare cases and parental abductions, where often nothing is black and white. The presented text has been adapted to the complex life situations in which our citizens and, above all, children are located. In many places, it is emphasised that the court is to take into account, first of all, the best interests of the child as a determinant in decision-making. We should therefore support the draft report, which I present today on behalf of Tadeusz Zwiefka and which endorses the final text of the Council.

name: Julia PITERA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Brussels IIA regulation is a key tool for navigating cross-border legal issues in family matters and providing protection to children. We have proposed to recast this instrument with the goal of preventing children in cross-border situations from ending up taken hostage in long legal disputes. We have also aimed to reduce the length and cost of these procedures. Let me add here one point: all decisions concerning children should be covered, notwithstanding the marital status of the parents. As you know, in December last year, after two-and-a-half years of negotiation, the ministers agreed on new rules which will offer better protection of children and will facilitate the procedures for families. Let me thank the House for your support for this proposal. In particular, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Zwiefka, for his excellent cooperation and for the swift procedure for this second opinion. You will have noticed that many of Parliament’s requests expressed in the first opinion are included in the compromise text. On the other hand, I know that the text does not include everything that many of you asked for. We must remember that these rules were agreed by unanimity, that the negotiations were not easy and that the text includes significant improvements. In particular, a great achievement is the abolition of the intermediate procedures to obtain cross-border enforcement of all judgments – the so-called exequatur. The new rules on enforcement of judgments will provide more legal certainty. In child return proceedings, I am very pleased that there will be shorter deadlines applied to different stages in the return procedure. The text reinforces the rights of children by ensuring that their perspective, with only a few exceptions, will be heard in the legal proceedings concerning them. The mutual recognition of Member States’ practices in this respect will avoid refusal at the stage of recognition or enforcement, thus allowing proper circulation of judgments in the Union. Furthermore, the compromise will provide clearer rules on the placement of the child in another Member State by establishing an autonomous consent procedure for all types of cross-border placement. The rules also ensure more effective cooperation between central authorities, which should continue playing a key role in supporting courts and competent authorities in applying the regulation. I look forward to hearing your views and I trust that there will be strong support for this regulation from the European Parliament in the vote tomorrow.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, as European Parliament coordinator on children’s rights, I welcome the Brussels IIa Regulation because it strengthens our legal toolbox to protect children. It facilitates the mutual recognition of cross—border decisions in parental responsibility and child abduction. It improves the efficiency of judicial proceedings and gives more legal certainty. For example, when a cross—national couple splits up and one parent returns to the country of origin and brings a child without the other parent concerned, the procedures to return the child are now simplified and accelerated. This regulation affects the daily life of so many international families and children and child abduction has devastating and long—lasting consequences on the child. The longer the child is abducted the greater the impact is on the child’s life and time is key to reduce the harm on the child. Therefore, I welcome in particular the following major steps forward: clear time limits for both the decisions taken by the judge and the enforcement, restriction in the number of appeals that generally delayed drastically the return decisions and the obligation of the courts to hear and take into account children’s views in all proceedings concerning them. And this is crucial to uphold the fundamental guiding principle of the best interest of the child as a primary consideration and it also recognises that the child is a right holder. I regret, however, that Member States could not agree on common standards regarding hearings proceedings. Ensuring that the child’s voice is heard is not enough and this right can even become a burden for the child if it is applied without procedural safeguards and a child friendly practice. As coordinator for the European Parliament on children’s rights, handling many cases of parental abduction, I have seen that court hearings can be intimidating, with traumatic effects on children. I therefore call on you, Commissioner, on the Commission and on the Member States to develop common standards and to share best practices on safeguards for children. We need to avoid double victimisation and create a climate of trust and I’m also glad that mediation is given due weight. It often remains the best way to seek long—term, lasting solutions. Much more needs to be done to promote alternative dispute resolutions among parents and professionals involved in the cross—border family disputes. And in this respect the coordinator on children’s rights has an important role to assist parents and children in solving faster the disputes and fulfil every child’s right to see and meet both parents.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The situation of children of binational couples whose relationship has failed is complicated by the fact that different traditions, cultures and very different court systems are brought into play. That is why it is good that we have achieved an improvement in the law in this area. I am pleased that a whole series of proposals that I made in my final report as mediator of the European Parliament on child abduction have actually been incorporated into this piece of legislation, because they have also been highlighted from the experience of dealing with the real problems. It is therefore good that cross-border procedures on parental custody and child abduction are being shortened, that clearer deadlines have been set, that fewer remedies are needed, that more legal certainty is brought into these procedures. That is a very good thing, and I very much welcome that. That was also one reason why we Social Democrats said: yes, we are in favour of the faster procedure, that we have accepted a fast-track procedure, because we want these facilitations for citizens to come as soon as possible. I was also pleased that, in this case, the Council went much further than it did in earlier times, when it was still very, very reticent in the way in which we were able to introduce improvements. However, there are a few points that still need to be looked at that are not yet satisfactory. Why does this only apply to married couples, why not to registered couples? Why is there this discrimination against LGBTIs, for example, which are not taken into account? This means that today we are still faced with this very old-fashioned social life, which, however, no longer corresponds to the reality of life. Another missed opportunity is that European minimum standards for hearings of children would also have been necessary, which unfortunately have not been taken into account.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Family disputes are always a huge drama, the biggest victim of which is children. Foster care is in many such cases a necessity dictated by their well-being and safety. Situations where there is a need to provide such care in a country other than the child's country of origin are particularly difficult. A few months ago, the European Parliament drew particular attention in its resolution, which Mrs Pitera certainly remembers, to the outrageous practices of the German Jugendamts, which prevent children from foreign families living in Germany from contacting the language and culture of their home country. Thanks to the efforts of the Polish Government, this regulation obliges Member States to preserve the rights of the child to national, cultural, religious and linguistic identity in proceedings concerning the establishment of foster care. The procedure for exchanging information between authorities, which was also proposed by the Polish, will allow the government to quickly identify and identify, for example, the child's relatives who can take care of him. I hope that this regulation will finally put an end to the shameful practices of the German child and youth authorities.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, we are debating and voting on the amendment of an extremely important regulation, both because it lays down uniform rules on divorce, separation and annulment of marriage, and because it intervenes in disputes over parental responsibility in cross-border situations.  Overall, the Council's text can be regarded as satisfactory. We agree with most of the changes that have been made and are heading in the right direction. We think it is a good thing that the causes of children, and in particular the abduction of children, are being dealt with much more quickly and that there is better coordination of the national central authorities.  We also think that it is right to encourage the use of mediation, where of course it is possible. However, it is totally unacceptable that, as is the case today, there should be a clear and glaring disparity in rights between European citizens. Those same rights and the same advances in the legislation that we are valuing here do not apply to same-sex spouses or to those who have made a registered partnership. These people are completely excluded from the scope of this regulation and will therefore not be able to benefit from judicial cooperation in the field of family law. They are excluded from the scope of the Union's main legal instrument governing divorce, separation and annulment of marriage issues, as well as disputes concerning parental responsibility.  We are in fact defining that there are second-class citizens and second-class citizens, and they have lower rights. This is totally unacceptable. We have tabled a number of amendments seeking to extend the scope, but they have been found incomprehensibly ineligible. We believe that this is a serious mistake and that it is wrong not to extend to all and all the same rights.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, this Parliament’s first and foremost responsibility is to protect its citizens and, in particular, the most vulnerable, and no citizens are more vulnerable than children. In harrowing cases where custody of a child is disputed, and especially in the cases of international abduction, legal instruments must be clear and provide no grey areas or loopholes. I welcome many points of the proposal, in particular the mandatory hearing of the child. As a co-founder of the Children’s Rights Intergroup in this Parliament and as a longstanding advocate for children’s participation, I believe children’s voices must be included in matters that concern them and their future.  I must point out, however, that more progress must be made. Family units encompass many realities and registered partners should be added to the scope of the regulation. As a modern institution, the European Parliament must demonstrate that it understands the many forms a family can take, especially when failing to do so can be detrimental to the care of children, as is the case in examples of international child abduction.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today more than 16 million families in the Union are made up of parents of different Member States. This is a positive effect of European integration, but it requires an appropriate legal framework to settle family disputes and best protect children when, unfortunately, families break up. According to the Commission's most recent figures, there are in fact about 1 800 cases of international child abduction per year, i.e. cases of children contesteded between parents. The recasting of the Brussels II-bis Regulation intervenes to update the previous framework, simplifies procedures, including return procedures, and introduces positive innovations, in particular by imposing an obligation on judicial authorities to hear the child, even though – and this is a matter of regret – the provision could have been supplemented with a reference to the hearing arrangements and precautions to avoid interference. , disturbances or traumas to the child.  It is also welcome to provide for an additional obligation for the judicial authority to promote family mediation aimed at resolving conflicts between parents, also and above all in the interests of children, because children must always be protected.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I would like to welcome this amendment to the Brussels II Regulation. From my practice as a former Minister of Justice in the Czech Republic, I remember how the procedures of individual member courts were very different in cases of international child abduction. This proposal, which clarifies existing European legislation, will certainly contribute to bringing the practice of the courts closer and more predictable as individual courts decide. I very much welcome the introduction of time limits for decision-making by the courts, because the different courts in each Member State have decided very differently in the case of children. I think that's a big shift. It is good that the question of when the child is not issued is clarified, the question of questioning the child, and so on. So, as a practitioner, I say: it is certainly a good thing and it will contribute to better protection of children, and it is a clear response to the fact that we have more and more married couples from different countries of the European Union and the international abduction of children by one of the parents is a reality.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Mimica, it is or is not a giant step which, since the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, the European Union has, for the first time, legislative capacity in the field of family law, divorce, separation, annulment of marriages and parental obligations in cross-border relations. Of course it is.  But does that giant step have limits? It also has them: unanimity in the Council and the consultative process of the European Parliament. And yet, yes, we endorse the step being made, because it is a positive step in the abolition of exequatur, in strengthening the right of hearing of minors, in clarifying the rules on the abduction of minors and in the mutual recognition of cross-border judgments in the European Union.  But it is an occasion to underline what is pending — the recognition of the various forms of family, de facto couples, same-sex couples, same-sex marriages recognised in some relevant Member States, such as Spain — and, of course, to recall the importance of the legislative reinforcement of the European Parliament and the importance of the composition of the European Parliament which we decided on 26 May.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the revision of Regulation No 2201/2003 is really very interesting, as it covers a wide range of family law issues. Because, as we know, we have international marriages and, of course, divorces, marriage annulments and even major differences in parental responsibility for children, as well as in the obligations of parents, such as the maintenance obligation. The process of returning children is an important process, as we have often abducted the child. Many times, we also place the child in another state, i.e. it is given to a foster family or an institution. In the Committee on Petitions we have had many complaints about the discrimination made by the famous Jugendamt in Germany against European citizens who are not Germans. I therefore believe that everything we are discussing is interesting, it is very important, the question of declaring the enforceability of the decision must be resolved and, of course, there must be recognition of judgments. All the more so to limit the procedure by the many remedies.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, as has already been said here, there are also problems within the European Union that require our response, in this case legislation. As more and more marriages are made between persons of different nationalities, cross-border litigation is also increasing as a result. Practice shows that proceedings are lengthy, court interpretations inconsistent, and this, of course, has an impact primarily on children who live in uncertainty. I therefore see the automatic enforcement of judgments, the clarification of time limits, the clarification of cooperation between the authorities of the Member States and the taking into account of existing case-law as a positive step which should contribute to a faster and more uniform procedure. The best interests of the child must be the guiding principle of all proceedings. I just want to remind you that it's in the best interest of the child that the parents don't break up at all.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for this debate, which covered many valid points. Your vote tomorrow will pave the way for the successful conclusion of the negotiations under the Romanian Presidency so that the new rules can be applied to help families in difficult situations and to protect children in particular. So thank you once again for your support.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow. Written statements (Article 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Regulation on jurisdiction, recognition and enforcement of judgments in matrimonial matters and on international child abduction establishes uniform rules in cases of divorce, legal separation or marriage annulment, as well as on matters of parental responsibility in cross-border situations. It allows for the free movement of judgments, public documents and agreements throughout the European Union. The Regulation also clarifies issues relating to children and the procedure for dealing with judgments given in this field in other Member States.  In addition, the Regulation lays down conditions for the return of children wrongfully abducted to another EU country. In this respect, the Regulation strengthens the return mechanism provided for in the Hague Convention, which is the main legal instrument governing parental kidnapping. Please note that it applies only to international abductions and detentions. There is therefore a need to further improve judicial cooperation between EU Member States so that it can deal with the growing number of cases of citizens in cross-border relationships.

name: Emil RADEV
text: in writing. – When we talk about family law and parental responsibility, there is nothing more important than protecting the interests of the child. Very often, when parents have some kind of conflict or it comes to a breakup, the child can not understand what is happening. This is our role as legislators – to ensure that the best interests of the child are always put at the forefront. The revised text of the proposal to change the Brussels 2a Regulation does just that, with the text already containing a number of safeguards on the protection of the child's interests in the event of a separation between parents or in cases where one parent kidnaps a child. We see that an obligation has been put in place to enable the child to express their opinion during the process, which can be done directly or through a representative. We must keep in mind that the opinion of the child in such a proceeding is always extremely important and it must be heard and taken into account, regardless of his age. I have stated before that procedures should be as short as possible and conducted in a language that is understandable to the child. I am pleased that the Council has listened to Parliament and introduced a six-week deadline for returning the child to the family, which is also a significant step forward.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – A year ago, we debated the revision of the Regulation on jurisdiction, recognition and enforcement of judgments in matrimonial matters, parental care and international child abduction. The European Parliament has overwhelmingly supported my previous report, pointing to several areas that were particularly important to us: the hearing of a child, the use of mediation in family matters and the placement of a child outside the family.  I am pleased that all these issues are included in the final text of the Council. This is particularly important when the court decides to place the child outside his or her biological family. The new rules on cooperation between the relevant services will allow reliable information to be provided and for the court to take a decision in the best interests of the child.  I would like to warn against a false interpretation of this provision, which is that it requires the courts to give a child of a given nationality to a family from the same country. It is still up to the court to decide this independently, taking into account the origin, the cultural environment and, above all, the best interests of the child.  The Council text takes into account the many possible scenarios that occur in childcare cases and parental abductions, where often nothing is black and white. The presented text has been adapted to the complex life situations in which our citizens and, above all, children are located.
